meta_movie_name: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
moviename_x: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
summary: Very much a superhero film – "X-Men" as imagined by Edward Gorey. But it’s not populated with the sorts of characters we’ve come to expect – tormented anti-heroes or wisecrackin’ daredevils or noble demi-gods. Rather, it’s a film about a group of broken children, not off saving the world but being saved from the world.

author: Tom Russo
meta_movie_name: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
moviename_x: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
summary: The movie bogs down only toward the finish, when it turns into a metahuman free-for-all.

author: Michael O'Sullivan
meta_movie_name: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
moviename_x: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
summary: The relatable theme of the magical misfit may not be entirely original. But as brought to life by Burton, Riggs’s fictional vision of a world in which the nonconformist can flourish serves as both a self-portrait of the auteur and a “Wonderland”-like looking glass in which many in the audience will no doubt see a reflection of themselves.

author: Moira Macdonald
meta_movie_name: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
moviename_x: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
summary: The time-travel element gets awfully twisty, perhaps a little too much so. But there’s great pleasure to be had in the performances, particularly Green’s deliciously avian Miss Peregrine.

author: Ed Gonzalez
meta_movie_name: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
moviename_x: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
summary: Tim Burton's direction reminds us of the distinct, peculiar coyness that was always at the heart of his best films.

author: Raakhee Mirchandani
meta_movie_name: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
moviename_x: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
summary: Riggs' original story is strong, but the characters in the movie feel empty.

author: Barbara VanDenburgh
meta_movie_name: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
moviename_x: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
summary: Burton reins in his worst impulses, bad habits that he’s been cultivating for over a decade, to make a wickedly dark children’s movie that is, finally, blessedly, fun to look at.

author: Peter Debruge
meta_movie_name: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
moviename_x: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
summary: Goldman’s frequently amusing script is the secret ingredient that makes “Miss Peregrine” such an appropriate fit for Burton’s peculiar sensibility, allowing the director to revisit and expand motifs and themes from his earlier work.

author: Peter Rainer
meta_movie_name: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
moviename_x: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
summary: The children are under the aegis of Miss Peregrine – played with divaesque triumphalism by Eva Green – who is capable of transforming herself into a falcon.

author: Marc Ciafardini
meta_movie_name: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
moviename_x: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
summary: A mostly winning combination of the strange and unusual, the adventure is an entertaining, clever, and fun one.

author: Devan Coggan
meta_movie_name: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
moviename_x: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
summary: The film chooses style over substance, emphasizing how cool the children’s powers are without fleshing them out as full characters. To compete with Burton’s best, his heroic weirdos need a little more heart—and the monsters need sharper teeth.

author: Steve Persall
meta_movie_name: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
moviename_x: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
summary: Burton's manner is changed, not drastically or consistently but more controlled, making strangeness the story's accessory rather than its purpose. He seems inspired by this material for the first time in years, in a creative vein where he finds the most satisfaction.

author: Tirdad Derakhshani
meta_movie_name: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
moviename_x: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
summary: Tries - far too hard - to replicate the Alice effect and falls short.

author: Peter Travers
meta_movie_name: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
moviename_x: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
summary: The film feels overstuffed and way too familiar, with Burton repeating tricks from his greatest hits (think Beetlejuice and Edward Scissorhands). And the fun runs out much before the film ends. But stick with it just for those times when Burton flies high on his own peculiar genius.

author: Chris Hewitt (1)
meta_movie_name: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
moviename_x: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
summary: While it's neither as dark, funny nor peculiar as you’d expect from Tim Burton, there’s still much here to admire.

author: Todd McCarthy
meta_movie_name: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
moviename_x: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
summary: For a time, an appealing gentleness prevails that's rooted in this unique inter-generational romance, a feeling augmented in particular by Purnell's slow-blooming flower of a performance, and if the film had remained focused more on the improbabilities of this love story, it might have emerged as something rather special.

author: A.A. Dowd
meta_movie_name: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
moviename_x: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
summary: The problem is that everything fun and resonant about the movie (like a boy whose eye works as a movie projector, unspooling his dreams onto the wall) ends up feeling rather ornamental.

author: Roger Moore
meta_movie_name: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
moviename_x: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
summary: I was a little awestruck, here and there, at the world “Miss Peregrine” serves up. And I liked the dark and deadly sensibility Burton was reaching for. But the cast and the oh-so-conventional third act Battle Royale let a promising premise down.

author: Nick Schager
meta_movie_name: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
moviename_x: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
summary: This adaptation of Ransom Riggs’ children’s-lit novel offers up merely serviceable studio spectacle, minus any of Burton’s former malevolent mad-genius spirit.

author: Kyle Smith
meta_movie_name: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
moviename_x: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
summary: Burton may give us a bland hero, a tepid love story and a muddled plot but, hey, at least he’s got a skeleton army doing battle with giant tentacle monsters at an amusement park.

author: Peter Hartlaub
meta_movie_name: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
moviename_x: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
summary: A Burton film that mines the romantic fable elements of “Edward Scissorhands,” while pushing the disturbing limits of a film that seems to be marketed for small children, even if it isn’t really intended for them.

author: Michael Phillips
meta_movie_name: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
moviename_x: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
summary: Burton's never been especially good at finding the internal motor or the rhythmic drive within a scene. This, I think, is why Miss Peregrine stalls, again and again, while the bird woman or Samuel L. Jackson's pointy-toothed, fright-wigged Barron tells us what's up with what we just saw, and what'll happen next.

author: Britt Hayes
meta_movie_name: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
moviename_x: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
summary: If this were a better, more entertaining film, Miss Peregrine’s could have been a thoughtful and bold metatextual thesis on Burton’s entire career. Instead, like its partially-formed villainous apparitions, it comes frustratingly close to achieving substance.

author: Matt Donato
meta_movie_name: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
moviename_x: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
summary: With Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children, Tim Burton focuses all his energy on a dusty, far-too-droll buildup that's far from worth whatever short-lived excitement his finale brings.

author: Tasha Robinson
meta_movie_name: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
moviename_x: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
summary: Burton's adaptation of Ransom Riggs' 2011 bestseller is a manic but emotionally inert movie that packs on the quirks without finding any personality underneath them.

author: Allison Shoemaker
meta_movie_name: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
moviename_x: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
summary: It’s visually sumptuous, a heady blend of Burton’s usual broken-doll aesthetic and some seriously impressive visual effects. And most importantly, while long, it’s rarely boring. The bad: It simply doesn’t add up to much.

author: David Ehrlich
meta_movie_name: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
moviename_x: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
summary: “Miss Peregrine’s” is a hollow ode to wonder and weirdness that suggests we’re running perilously low on both.

author: Stephanie Zacharek
meta_movie_name: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
moviename_x: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
summary: Miss Peregrine’s Home for Peculiar Children could have been a return to form for Burton, but he loses his sense of direction halfway through. If only he could find his way back to his wild bread-crumb trail, the one that guided him so ably for years.

author: Robbie Collin
meta_movie_name: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
moviename_x: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
summary: It’s another flick through a familiar and by-now bulging scrapbook, but it leaves you craving less – and more.

author: Marc Savlov
meta_movie_name: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
moviename_x: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
summary: It’s a phantasmagorical chase movie that rarely takes a breather long enough for you to enjoy the sights along the way.

author: Tim Grierson
meta_movie_name: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
moviename_x: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
summary: For a movie that’s meant to have some magic in it, Peculiar Children displays little buoyancy, the proceedings weighed down by tedious world-building and perfunctory thematic lip-service about the need for community and the power that comes from finding one’s voice.

author: Tom Huddleston
meta_movie_name: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
moviename_x: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
summary: Like four or five Harry Potter books squeezed into a single movie: it makes precious little sense.

author: Christy Lemire
meta_movie_name: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
moviename_x: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
summary: Because even though I’d just seen the exact same movie my son had, I wasn’t sure I completely understood it, either.

author: Richard Roeper
meta_movie_name: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
moviename_x: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
summary: This is a messy, confusing, uninvolving mishmash of old-school practical effects and CGI battles that feels … off nearly every misstep of the way. It’s like watching a master musician play a piano he somehow doesn’t realize is out of tune.

author: Alonso Duralde
meta_movie_name: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
moviename_x: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
summary: This adventure should have been spooky and witty and exciting, but instead it’s just dreary and dull. Peculiarity has rarely been this tedious.

author: Peter Rainer
summary: The only heartfelt moment of this movie for me came in the end credits, with its dedication to the late Alan Rickman, who provided the voice for the blue butterfly (and former caterpillar) Absolem. What a voice, what an actor, what a loss.

author: Leah Greenblatt
summary: For better or worse, Looking Glass loses none of the first film’s muchness, with Bobin mimicking both his predecessor’s wildly saturated style and his general disregard for plot and substance.

author: Kyle Smith
summary: You certainly get your 20 bucks worth of spectacle out of Alice Through the Looking Glass. So breathtaking are the landscapes, so whimsical are the creatures, so marvelous are the marvels that I wanted to give a standing ovation to whoever signed the check to pay for all this. Expensiver and expensiver!

author: Tim Robey
summary: The whole business, this time, is passable eye candy without being any kind of brain candy.

author: Matthew Anderson
summary: Alice Through The Looking Glass is at its middling best when Wasikowska is at the reins.

author: Dave Calhoun
summary: The film’s pace barely leaves you time to think – blink and you’ll lose the plot. But there’s plenty of imagination here to honour the spirit of Carroll’s topsy-turvy tales, even if the emotional resolutions are of a distinctly twenty-first-century sort.

author: Andrew Lowry
summary: Wasikowska gives it her all, and Cohen shines, but while this is a better film than the first, that was a low bar to reach.

author: Neil Smith
summary: Bobin’s attempt to fill Tim Burton’s shoes generates a lively but ersatz sequel that only truly ticks when Baron Cohen and Bonham Carter are around.

author: Jesse Hassenger
summary: It’s briskly paced and sometimes neat to watch in reality-bending 3-D, but none of it is quite as head-spinning as it should be. The movie doesn’t dare alienate its family base with genuine trippiness; instead, it pacifies with tedious familial backstory.

author: Moira Macdonald
summary: Alice Through the Looking Glass isn’t without pleasures, but this empowerment-meets-fantasy mixture could have used a few more sprinklings of quirk.

author: Peter Travers
summary: The script by Linda Woolverton stays surface faithful to the characters created by Lewis Carroll, but the film has lost its soul.

author: Roger Moore
summary: Alice Through the Looking Glass, which has precious little to do with the rhyming collection Lewis Carroll penned with that title, is a dreary, joyless affair.

author: Daniel Schindel
summary: It’s not wretched; just boring. A faintly damned improvement, but an improvement nonetheless.

author: Dominick Suzanne-Mayer
summary: It’s a classic case of sequel bloat, a film that seems to exist less because of any extended story it wants or needs to tell than because it must repackage something that was once popular.

author: Joe Morgenstern
summary: The good news is that Mia Wasikowska is back in the title role, bright-spirited and skillful as ever, but she’s burdened by the manic direction of James Bobin, working from a dramatically inert script by Ms. Woolverton.

author: Bill Goodykoontz
summary: There should be a sense of, yes, wonder at play at all times here. Too often “Alice Through the Looking Glass” feels like a slog through time.

author: Stephen Holden
summary: The best and maybe the only way to appreciate Alice Through the Looking Glass is to surrender to its mad digital excess and be whirled around through time and space in a world of grotesque overabundance.

author: Marjorie Baumgarten
summary: This return to Wonderland is a dull outing, about which it can be said that Alice doesn’t live here anymore.

author: April Wolfe
summary: It’s so gorgeous you can sometimes forget the train wreck of a story. But only sometimes.

author: Nigel M Smith
summary: The studio has managed to deliver a follow-up that’s even weaker than its predecessor. In crude terms: Alice’s second trip to Underland wasn’t worth the wait.

author: Andrew Barker
summary: The problem with “Alice” is its lack of narrative imagination.

author: Sheri Linden
summary: Depp is convincingly vulnerable and forlorn, all while maintaining the Hatter’s otherworldly eccentricity, and Wasikowska has the requisite grit. But Alice’s mission feels as manufactured as the story’s whatsits and doodads, as Bobin struggles to infuse make-believe with emotion.

author: Kate Taylor
summary: As Alice, Wasikowska, who has lost the injured look that made her so effective the first time out, creates a character who is fundamentally sweet, likeable and loyal.

author: Katie Walsh
summary: The real problem is that there isn't enough whimsy in the world to save this unengaging story.

author: James Berardinelli
summary: The movie is frequently incomprehensible and, on those occasions when it makes sense, the viewer may wish it didn’t.

author: Brian Truitt
summary: Looking Glass is instead a competition to see how goofy Johnny Depp can be as the Mad Hatter and how many scenes (and hearts) Helena Bonham Carter can steal as the ragingly high-maintenance Red Queen.

author: Ty Burr
summary: To watch Alice Through the Looking Glass is to witness an army of smart, creative people dumbing themselves down into delivering what they think the market wants.

author: Tirdad Derakhshani
summary: A dull, formulaic theme-park ride whose only purpose is to make more pots of money.

author: Richard Roeper
summary: The sequel to Tim Burton’s 2010 mega-hit “Alice in Wonderland” is loud, frantic, stunningly unfunny, off-putting and riddled with mediocre, out-of-tune work from normally outstanding actors. It’s one of the great movie disasters of 2016.

author: Alonso Duralde
summary: What Alice Through the Looking Glass constantly underscores, however, is that even the greatest cinema trickery serves little purpose without stories and characters to support. The pictures are pretty (or scary or awe-inspiring) but they ultimately don’t mean anything.

author: Drew McWeeny
summary: I think it is precisely because the technical work by everyone from James Bobin down is so good that I find myself infuriated by the film. So much muscle, so much effort, so much raw talent on display, and all in service of demographic-and-merchandise-driven garbage that sullies the name of the source material.

author: Justin Chang
summary: At every turn the filmmakers have simplified, banalized and sentimentalized Alice and her psychological landscape in ways that reek of ignorance at best and cynicism at worst.

author: Erin Whitney
summary: Bobin’s visual palette merely hikes up the contrast of every scene, as if enough color might mask the frail narrative beneath.

author: Tim Grierson
summary: A parade of gaudy CGI and strained whimsy, Alice Through The Looking Glass proves even more manic and grating than its 2010 predecessor.

author: Nick Schager
summary: The off-putting aesthetics of ‘Looking Glass’ are complemented by an equally putrid tale that’s determined to make its protagonist loathsome.

author: Mick LaSalle
summary: If you see Alice Through the Looking Glass, prepare to lean forward in your seat just to stay awake.

author: Stephanie Merry
summary: Wondrous visuals only go so far, in a film that turns out to be lethally dull.

author: Mike Scott
summary: While infants and imbeciles might get caught up in whirlwind action, most viewers should brace themselves for a less-than-wondrous return to Wonderland.

author: Stephen Whitty
summary: Hugely expensive and extravagantly stupid, Alice Through the Looking Glass is just one more silly Hollywood mashup, an innocent fantasy morphed into a noisy would-be blockbuster.

author: Steve Persall
summary: It's difficult to not be cynical and redundant to declare this sequel needless for anyone except accountants, considering the studio involved. But this ranks among Disney's most shameless shirkings of its responsibility to creatively entertain, in order to pursue profits.

author: David Ehrlich
summary: As Alice runs from one hollow set piece to another, hitting every standard mark that a colossal movie like this must in order to pay for itself, her adventure grows less and less interesting with every turn. By the end, all that lessness is too much for the muchness to match it. Less is usually more, but when it comes to this franchise, none would be ideal.

author: Matt Zoller Seitz
summary: I removed my eyeballs from my head as soon as I got back from Alice Through the Looking Glass and cleaned them in a sink. I could have left them in and only cleaned the fronts, but I didn't want to take any chances.

author: Andrew Parker
summary: Every joke here hits its target, and while many of them will soar over the heads of youngsters, it will still send everyone home happy and satisfied.

author: Alonso Duralde
summary: Storks continually surprises with characters who are more complicated than we might expect in a kid’s animated movie, and a refusal to hit every single pre-programmed plot beat.

author: Robbie Collin
summary: A densely funny, lovingly orchestrated hour and a half of amiable chaos.

author: Michael Rechtshaffen
summary: Co-directors Nicholas Stoller and Doug Sweetland deliver big time with Storks, a fittingly buoyant, delightfully madcap animated romp.

author: Brian Truitt
summary: Good news, parents: Storks is bound to entertain you and your little ones. Bad news: Get ready to answer a lot more awkward questions about where babies come from.

author: Will Ashton
summary: Likable, heartfelt and sweet in all the right places, Stoller and co-director Doug Sweetland have put together a charming surprise that’s as joyful and friendly as it is funny and well-meaning.

author: Christy Lemire
summary: Zippy and zany, cute and cuddly, Storks manages to balance wild humor with winning heart—for the most part.

author: Peter Hartlaub
summary: Like Phil Lord and Christopher Miller’s stellar “The Lego Movie,” the filmmakers work with the confidence that if a joke fails, the one that follows a few seconds later will redeem the scene.

author: Tom Russo
summary: The result is a story that’s awfully scattered thematically, but one with such inventive wit and screwball-quick pacing that issues like spongy motivation hardly seem to matter.

author: Devan Coggan
summary: There’s a delightfully madcap pace to Storks, and most of the rapid-fire jokes land.

author: Justin Chang
summary: Like any pleasant surprise, this funny, frenetic, cheerfully nonsensical movie makes its own rules and gives you a few things that you weren’t, well, expecting.

author: Steve Persall
summary: It's occasional fun, but that's about all, folks.

author: Katie Walsh
summary: Storks is at times cacophonous and overly busy, and the animation tends toward the goofily humorous rather than the spectacular. However, Stoller manages to pull off a third act and emotional resolution that's genuinely moving.

author: Roger Moore
summary: It’s not as start-to-finish funny as Warner Animation’s “Lego Movie”, and that also goes for the quirky Lego cartoon short — basically the chicken-botched filming of the opening credits to a martial arts movie...But there’s wit, warmth and invention here, enough to make you hopeful for a Warner Animation future.

author: Alan Scherstuhl
summary: In between Storks' bumptious best and worst are its uncertain quiet patches.

author: Joshua Rothkopf
summary: Apart from one muted action sequence in which the participants try not to wake a sleeping bundle of joy (“Put that baby down,” one of them demands, and the order is obeyed, with a little tucking in), there’s scarce humor here for adults to relish. And Samberg’s characteristic snark has been sanded down to a nub.

author: Jesse Hassenger
summary: This is a lot of plot for a movie that endeavors primarily to entertain children, though the excess is more likely to give adults a headache.

author: Stephanie Zacharek
summary: As with most animated films today, there’s lots of boring bromides about “family” and “belonging” that you have to suffer through to get to the good stuff.

author: Tirdad Derakhshani
summary: Storks feels way too much like a belabored and mediocre SNL sketch. Each character has some neurotic tic or crazy fixation, which they expound upon in monologues that feel like material for a stand-up act or a sitcom.

author: Neil Genzlinger
summary: This film, directed by Nicholas Stoller and Doug Sweetland, is a harmless enough way to occupy a youngster for an hour and a half. It’s just not especially rich in extraordinary characters or moments.

author: Eric Henderson
summary: Maybe it's not the worst thing in the world that Storks doesn't take many cues from Pixar's tear-jerking playbook.

author: Michael O'Sullivan
summary: Storks delivers its package, but it’s a bundle of just-okay, not joy.

author: Steve Davis
summary: Animated films have trended toward a perceptive intelligence in the past few years, but Storks wades in shallow waters most of the time.

author: Owen Gleiberman
summary: In Storks, the jokes fall flat, but the pace is relentless, and those two things seem somehow intertwined, as if the filmmakers had convinced themselves that comedy that whips by fast enough won’t go thud.

author: Eric Kohn
summary: Neither wacky enough to work as pure punchline, nor smart enough to bend its looniness into something more substantial, Storks views the world with the same confused outlook of its wide-eyed infants.

author: Olly Richards
summary: Perhaps it’s fitting that this story about babies has the attention span and grasp of logic of a newborn.

author: Barbara VanDenburgh
summary: Storks is charmless with rote obligation. This is a kid’s film for hire, with none of the creativity, emotion and design that elevate the genre to art, or even simply a fun time at the movies.

author: Raakhee Mirchandani
summary: The jokes in Warner Bros.'s new animated flick mostly fall flat, the characters are largely unlovable and the simplistic plot expects more from its audience than it gives.

author: Matt Donato
summary: Storks is momentarily funny when it’s not boorishly and exhaustively begging for your attention.

author: Kyle Smith
summary: Less enjoyable than making a baby but more enjoyable than raising one, the animated feature Storks delivers a bouncing bundle of blah.

author: Joe Morgenstern
summary: The whole movie seems to be on fast-forward, with crushingly brainless dialogue, hollow imagery and no way of slowing down the febrile action or making sense of the chaotic plot.

author: Michael O'Sullivan
summary: For a movie that relies so heavily on a single, not especially groundbreaking visual effect — now you see the bogeyman, now you don’t — Lights Out is crazy scary.

author: Jordan Ruimy
summary: The difference between Lights Out and any other mainstream horror movie is that it actually uses the dark as the center of its plot, organically drawing out the majority of its jump scares in the process.

author: Josh Winning
summary: With characters you care about – principally Teresa Palmer’s appealingly edgy, cliché-bucking Rebecca – and a poignant denouement, this is horror with guts as well as gore.

author: Simon Crook
summary: A lean, mean scare-machine, and a surprise contender for horror of the year. Seek it out. Then, for God’s sake, buy a bedside lamp.

author: Edward Douglas
summary: While the central visual of the figure in the dark goes a long way to provide the essential scares, the success of the film is just as much about what the filmmakers do to develop the characters that the audience cares about.

author: Tirdad Derakhshani
summary: A well-shot, gore-free psychological thriller about our elemental fear of darkness, Lights Out has a good deal in common with "The Babadook." While it can't touch Jennifer Kent's masterpiece, it does mark the arrival of a major new talent.

author: Brad Wheeler
summary: Best of all, it’s tight at 81 minutes, which means a 7 p.m. screening gets you out of the theatre while it’s still light out, thank God.

author: Bill Graham
summary: Bolstered by the mythology it builds and scares that rarely feel cheap, it shows even wide-release horror doesn’t have to be a groan-inducing slog — and you’ll definitely think twice about turning the lights out.

author: Mick LaSalle
summary: Lights Out presents actual characters that are interesting, that have rough edges, that act like real people, not victims in waiting.

author: Michael Phillips
summary: Palmer and Bello really do seem like world-weary, spook-addled daughter and mother, and they play the stakes just so, favoring neither blase understatement nor yellow-highlighter melodrama. They're strong enough to take your mind off some lapses in narrative judgment.

author: Jeannette Catsoulis
summary: Spackling over any copycat cracks with strong acting and fleet editing, Lights Out delivers minimalist frights in old-school ways.

author: Justin Chang
summary: Bello gives a tremulous wacko-mom performance from which she has eliminated every whisper of camp. She’s both sympathetic and infuriating, and her scenes with her daughter hint at a more painful, complicated emotional history than the movie has time to explore, though it’s nice that it bothers to explore it at all.

author: Bill Goodykoontz
summary: The scares here are in the execution, aided by the acting. Bello is, like always, terrific, adding layers to what seems at first like the stereotypical mentally-ill movie character. She's fighting for something. Palmer, too, adds grit to her would-be iconoclast.

author: April Wolfe
summary: When Sandberg isn’t spinning his wheels in the why, he’s capable of doling out a steady diet of scares.

author: Christian Holub
summary: This movie purposely inspires viewers to think about serious topics, and then disregards the consequences of doing so, undermining the whole enterprise. The final physical sensation is not terror or relief, but disgust.

author: Peter Travers
summary: Predictable stuff, energized by some spiffy scare effects from cinematographer Marc Spicer who works wonders with underlighting. But the on/off tricks would grow tiring without actors who perform well beyond the call of fright-house duty.

author: Lou Lumenick
summary: The simple, highly effective gimmick of this straightforward shocker is a malevolent clawed spectre named Diana (Alicia Vela-Bailey), who only appears in the dark.

author: Moira Macdonald
summary: Lights Out is an effective, tidy little chiller; basically the same sneak-up-in-the-dark scare over and over. But hey, as we’ve learned through decades of horror movies, that stuff works.

author: Roger Moore
summary: You don’t realize how much a good horror movie depends on acting until you stumble in that rare one whose cast actually gets it right.

author: David Edelstein
summary: Bello is an excellent actress and makes Sophie’s anguish credible, although she can’t rise above the material.

author: Joshua Rothkopf
summary: The central idea here is as durable and effective as a well-told fireside ghost story, but in the cold light of day, the film fades.

author: Andrew Barker
summary: Very obviously a first feature, Lights Out is full of camp (most of it clearly intentional, some perhaps not), and its underlying mythology is confused and often ridiculous. But there’s an invigorating leanness — and a giddy, almost innocent energy — to the filmmaking.

author: Robert Abele
summary: That the film occasionally succumbs to certain rudimentary hallmarks of industrial studio horror is regrettable, but for the most part it’s agreeably suspenseful, date-night arm-squeezing genre fare.

author: Justin Lowe
summary: Coming in a few notches below the terror factor of Wan’s most exemplary material, this somewhat less-satisfying variation of an ill-fated haunting nonetheless represents a solid debut for Swedish filmmaker David F. Sandberg

author: Peter Sobczynski
summary: Lights Out has been made with a certain degree of style—enough to make you want to see what Sandberg might be capable of with a better screenplay—and it does contain one great moment that pays sly homage to the most famous moment from the classic thriller “Wait Until Dark.”

author: Kate Erbland
summary: Sandberg unquestionably has an eye for a great horror motif — and, given the frequent use of absolutely gut-churning ambient sounds and hair-raising scratching noises, an ear for it, too — and he’s assembled a strong cast to tell Heisserer’s expanded story, but even those smart decisions and clear talents can’t push Lights Out to brighter heights.

author: James Berardinelli
summary: Unfortunately, the film stumbles, offering too few legitimate scares and displaying an overreliance on traditional horror movie clichés.

author: Christopher Gray
summary: Few horror films are as insistent about the trauma mental illness inflicts on families as Lights Out, and still fewer are so insensitive about it.

author: A.A. Dowd
summary: The film is blatantly, unmistakably about mental illness, and that makes it hard to ignore or forgive what it ends up saying (hopefully by accident) on the subject.

author: Josh Kupecki
summary: It’s the cinematic equivalent to a carnival funhouse: a bit scary when you’re traversing it, but utterly forgettable (and mildly regrettable) once it’s over.

author: Jordan Hoffman
summary: Lights Out is yet another half-baked, PG-13 scare-em snoozer centered on an underdeveloped supernatural concept that won’t even give kids a good nightmare.

author: Randall Colburn
summary: Jump scares are all Sandberg seems to have in his bag of tricks, and each is clunkily executed and met with an agonizing, ear-piercing shriek. Watching Lights Out is like standing next to an idiot with an air horn, never quite knowing when it’s about to blow in your ear. It’s a far cry from the freaky grace of his short.

author: Rex Reed
summary: The fun wears out fast and so does the “gotcha” factor.

author: Joe Morgenstern
summary: This one, a debut feature, is awfully inept, whereas the short isn’t long enough for ineptitude to take hold, or for a story to develop.

author: Jesse Hassenger
summary: Maybe that call will be answered next time with enough incremental improvements to finally notch a good Divergent movie, a possibility Allegiant raises repeatedly and frustratingly. Ultimately, though, this movie isn’t just adhering to a formula; it’s carefully following a recipe designed to offset any good ingredients that get mixed in there by mistake.

author: Ben Croll
summary: “Allegiant” ends up feeling like a mid-season climax to serialized TV drama. The pieces are in play, the wheels in motion. Stay tuned, loyal viewers, and you’ll get your answers next year.

author: Bill Zwecker
summary: The special effects are among the more positive aspects of “Allegiant,” but those alone cannot rescue this highly flawed sequel.

author: James Berardinelli
summary: Allegiant tries to cram too little story into too much time. This results in dead spots and uneven pacing.

author: Steven Rea
summary:
Director Robert Schwentke and his writing team do their best to move things along.
Actually, who knows if it's their best? Maybe they're suffering from Divergent fatigue along with the rest of us.

author: Ariana Bacle
summary: Allegiant aches to be a thought-provoking, moving allegory of the current world. Instead, it’s an unwieldy two hours too unintentionally silly to validate how seriously it takes itself.

author: Kenneth Turan
summary: Because the series' plot reveal turns out to be more confusing than compelling, and because turning a novel into two films invariably leads to inflated productions, only the most devoted fans of the book will pledge allegiance to what's on the screen.

author: Mick LaSalle
summary: Combines the usual dumb ideas with one good one. And not just good, but impressive, in that it makes sense of much of what went before.

author: Tom Russo
summary: This doesn’t even feel much like Tris’s story anymore, just generically overdigitized combat. The main thing she’s diverging from at this point is the tone that hooked us in the first place.

author: Connie Ogle
summary: The film moves jerkily, in fits and starts, squandering its promising setup and bogging down in explanation.

author: Bill Goodykoontz
summary: Let's just call "Allegiant" what it is: A way for the studio to make money and bring you back next year for the real finale. See you then. Maybe.

author: Stephen Whitty
summary: The only thing that's revolting is how dull the series has gotten.

author: Kate Stables
summary: This over-extended teen dystopia is treading water, coming up short on its trademark punchy plotting, teen self-discovery and the wonderful Woodley.

author: Henry Barnes
summary: Big but boring, expansive but cheap-looking, Allegiant spins in place, waiting for next year’s Ascendent to come along and offer resolution. In all candour: you can do without it.

author: Robbie Collin
summary: Like the earlier Divergent films, Allegiant is studded with enticing science-fiction ideas, but it keeps such a poker-straight face while presenting them, you often can’t help but crack up.

author: James Dyer
summary: Instead of bringing much-needed clarity, Allegiant piles on yet more bamboozling mythology to flummox and confound.

author: Fionnuala Halligan
summary: Long, shiny, and treading a lot of water.

author: Tom Huddleston
summary: It all leads to a climax so staggeringly lazy and glib that you honestly expect Woodley just to turn to the camera in the final scene, shrug her shoulders and walk off.

author: Jordan Mintzer
summary: For a film that takes great pride in its heroine's nonconformism, pretty much everything in Allegiant feels conventional.

author: Peter Debruge
summary: Although “Allegiant” does recapture the original film’s sense of constantly discovering and adapting to fresh information, audiences no longer identify with anyone in particular.

author: Susan Wloszczyna
summary: As tedious as much of this sounds, an odd thing happened around “Allegiant’s” midway point. The fairly packed audience started vocally reacting “Rocky Horror”-style to some of the more overtly melodramatic turns with “oohs," “ahhs” and even laughter.

author: Soren Andersen
summary: All of it feels warmed over, reprocessed … and, yes, confused.

author: Michael Phillips
summary: It's a pretty dull picture, I must say, because it's my duty to say it. And it's a pretty dull picture, I must say, because something about its particular grade of dullness may cause memory loss.

author: Michael O'Sullivan
summary: Everything is needlessly tangled and bewildering.

author: Michael Snydel
summary: Above all of the tiresome, poorly constructed mythology, nonexistent stakes, and presentation of subtext as text, Allegiant’s greatest sin is its total contempt for its viewers.

author: Kimberley Jones
summary: Three films into the ongoing Divergent series, one would hope we’d moved beyond laying plates and folding napkins to get to something more substantial. Yet Allegiant barely makes it to the appetizer course.

author: Bilge Ebiri
summary: The actors still give it their all in Allegiant, but there's only so much they can do with such a clunky, verbose script. And on the rare occasion that the film actually quiets its characters down and delivers something resembling action, it's woefully inert.

author: Jeannette Catsoulis
summary: A story that kicked off two years ago at a reasonable gallop has now slowed to barely a limp.

author: Peter Travers
summary: If only their stuff had a spark of life it might be forgivable, but Allegiant plods along like a franchise on its last legs. Who remembers where we left off last time in Insurgent? My point exactly — no one.

author: Julia Cooper
summary: Try as I might, I cannnot activate your interest in this bloated excuse for a movie.

author: Steve Persall
summary: The pleasures of Allegiant are unintended, those little bits of business taken so seriously that serious viewers must laugh.

author: Roger Moore
summary: This sort of movie really should be about more than meekly obvious names for human traits separated into tribes, the future tech, the dystopian landscape, the fashions, the hair styles...But there isn’t a line that lands, a scene that sticks with you, an emotion you feel or a moment this movie drags you to the edge of your seat.

author: Lou Lumenick
summary: By the time David gets someone to unleash the gas, I was wishing he could simply erase all memories of the sorry “Divergent’’ franchise.

author: Owen Gleiberman
summary: It may be a slight entertainment in the grand scheme of things, but it’s been made with a busy, nattering joy that is positively infectious

author: Soren Andersen
summary: A confused mishmash of plot elements featuring overwrought extraneous characters. Kids likely will love it. Their parents will just have to grin and bear it.

author: James Berardinelli
summary: It is, at best, an oversized, overbudgeted Saturday morning cartoon.

author: Sara Stewart
summary: Feels both deeply rote and way overpacked with characters.

author: Tom Russo
summary: The riot of color here brings to mind what the makers of “Ice Age” delivered with “Rio,” which in turn reminds us that these animators certainly aren’t just one-trick talents. Could be time for them to show us some new ones.

author: A.A. Dowd
summary: Yes, yes, this is a kids’ movie, so it hardly matters that none of it makes one lick of sense, even on its own terms.

author: Raakhee Mirchandani
summary: Like the very asteroid that is hurtling toward Earth in the movie, Ice Age: Collision Course is chunky, clunky and bulky. Unlike the asteroid, the film seems to move at a glacial pace.

author: Susan Wloszczyna
summary: Don’t be distracted by the eye-pleasing purple and lavender hues that have been added to the typically chilly color palette. This plot is as disjointed as it sounds.

author: John Hazelton
summary: Collision Course is a colourful 3D romp that’s heavy on slapstick and cosy family comedy but light on real laughs and affecting drama.

author: Blake Goble
summary: Parents will nap, some kids will be amused, and the nerdiest viewers will have good reason to point out flaws in the movie’s not-so-intelligent designs.

author: Devan Coggan
summary: The Ice Age series was never great cinema, but there’s always been a sense of heart under all the wisecracks and zany antics. Collision Course abandons that in favor of already stale pop culture references and laughless jokes.

author: Glenn Kenny
summary: The movie’s actual entertainment value rises considerably during the dialogue-free sequences.

author: Barbara VanDenburgh
summary: It wouldn’t make the movie good, but at least a meteor strike would preclude the possibility of a sixth “Ice Age” film.

author: Helen O'Hara
summary: Even by the standards of animation, the logic fails here are impressive. But the bigger problem is the lack of charm, focus and original storytelling as the animals suddenly have to save the world instead of just surviving it.

author: Peter Bradshaw
summary: This could provide some small-screen entertainment for bored kids on a rainy day. But really: enough.

author: Michael Rechtshaffen
summary: It’s as if co-directors Michael Thurmeier and Galen Tan Chu, both veterans of the Ice Age franchise, sensed that there was essentially nowhere left to go with the concept and opted to instead overstuff the production with too many characters breathlessly doing tired, pop culture-heavy “bits” like it was open mic night at the Paleolithic Punch Line.

author: Roger Moore
summary: More Pegg, please. Less of everything else. But then, it’s too late for that. “Collision Course” is already a bomb.

author: Tirdad Derakhshani
summary: Four film sequels and 14 years later, the best I can say of Ice Age: Collision Course is that it has nice coloring and good picture contrast.

author: Eric Henderson
summary: If Ice Age: Collision Course gleefully fails at being a history lesson, at least it offers an energetic recess from reality.

author: Alonso Duralde
summary: There’s plenty of fart jokes, forward motion and bright colors to engage easily-entertained children, but their parents will be subjected to yet another movie that has all the zing of watching evolution in real time.

author: Marc Savlov
summary: Collision Course is overstuffed with meandering, unnecessary micro-storylines, far too many new characters, and an obvious lack of focus, none of which should impact the movie’s target demographic, kids under 10.

author: Peter Travers
summary: The fifth entry in the Ice Age series is a loud, lazy, laugh-starved cash grab that cynically exploits its target audience (I use the term advisedly) by serving them scraps and calling it yummy. Even two-year-olds can see through the hustle.

author: Brad Wheeler
summary: Toddlers will dig the shenanigans, but bewildered adults should root for the annihilation of this tapped-out series.

author: Peter Hartlaub
summary: The Ice Age screenwriters seem to be making up the rules as they go along, distracted by tired side plots to give the other characters a reason to exist in the film.

author: Stephanie Merry
summary: Lazy, scattershot and excruciatingly unfunny, the movie is a hazard to the very young, who might come away with the erroneous impression that movies don’t get any better than this.

author: Katie Walsh
summary: "Collision Course” is simply a perfunctory, watered-down entry in the series that feels like it should have been released on home video.

author: Tom Huddleston
summary: It’s time to put this franchise on ice for good.

author: Steven Rea
summary: An impossibly enjoyable live-action cartoon that plays on our real-life anxieties about vengeful cadres of foreign radicals blowing up people - and places.

author: Nick Schager
summary: Brash, brutal, and simplistic in equal measure, it’s a retrograde work that, for better and worse, delivers its old-school mayhem with punishing precision and unrepentant glee.

author: Brad Wheeler
summary: The film is a popcorn-crowd pleaser, but a “yippee ki-yay” or two away from something more memorable.

author: James Berardinelli
summary: As action-thrillers go, this one provides what the previews tease. Maybe that’s enough for an evening’s mindless, throw-away entertainment, but I can’t help but be disappointed that the filmmakers couldn’t have brought something more inventive to a genre that too often relies on worn-out tropes.

author: Todd McCarthy
summary: While not nearly as elaborate, nor as visually sophisticated as the last Mission: Impossible outing or the most recent Bonds, London Has Fallen is actually more plausible at its core, if not in its details, which is partly why it succeeds in laying claim to an audience's attention for the entirety of its swift running time.

author: Kate Lloyd
summary: It’s all so overly macho that it plays like a camp pleasure-cruise.

author: Soren Andersen
summary: The action is pumped up. The destruction is extreme. The whole thing is absurd.

author: Ed Gonzalez
summary: Like its predecessor, the film is content to dumbly relish in the inanity of Mike's rampage.

author: Christian Holub
summary: The new sequel, London Has Fallen, implausibly ups its predecessor’s stakes to "Die Hard in the City of London." Unfortunately, widening the scope this dramatically causes the entire fragile action-movie axis to spin wildly out of control.

author: Mike Scott
summary: Najafi's R-rated London Has Fallen doesn't target the genteel viewer. Rather, it aims squarely for moviegoers who like their action bloody, their fights brutal, their body count sky-high.

author: Stephen Whitty
summary: Remember “Olympus Has Fallen”? This one is worse.

author: Bill Goodykoontz
summary: It's all silly and meant to be fun, except when Najafi tries to throw in some serious bits, which wind up being sillier still.

author: Neil Smith
summary: Bloodthirsty, derivative and xenophobic nonsense.

author: William Thomas
summary: It’s a film that doesn’t so much invite you to switch off your brain as take it out and dump it in the nearest popcorn box.

author: Fionnuala Halligan
summary: Creepy “send them back to Fuckheadistan” sentiment overwhelms London Has Fallen’s guilty pleasures, its meaty violence and xenophobic nastiness giving the cheddar an unpleasant aftertaste.

author: Peter Bradshaw
summary: There is some surreal fun at the beginning as everything collapses.... But then it’s the same thing over again.

author: Richard Roeper
summary: It’s difficult to imagine anyone appearing in this film thought of it as more than a payday.

author: Roger Moore
summary: There’s little drama, but the fights and chases (Butler hanging out of a moving SUV) are exciting, if not very original.

author: Michael Phillips
summary: The film, with its wearying gamer-style rounds of death, is routine at best.

author: Andy Klein
summary: Iranian-born director Babak Najafi (“Sebbe”) and the four credited screenwriters... make things move fast enough to keep you awake, but not fast enough to finesse its plot absurdities past an alert viewer’s mind.

author: Robert Abele
summary: As long as there are enemies in Islamic lands, we'll probably have to endure risible time-wasters like London Has Fallen, designed to justify blinkered foreign policy attitudes and stoke jokey hatred.

author: Scott Tobias
summary: The action never stops once the first car bomb is triggered, but the second half of London Has Fallen takes place mostly in the dark, where nobody can see the budget.

author: Guy Lodge
summary: For all the slicing and dicing of the editing, narrative momentum grinds to a trudge after the synthetic spectacle of the capital’s undoing.

author: Lawrence Toppman
summary: No characterization. A plot you could write on a single sheet of toilet paper. Sadistic violence we’re meant to cheer. A surprise that wouldn’t fool anyone who left the theater after the opening credits and came back for the last 10 minutes.

author: Tom Russo
summary: For the sequel, London Has Fallen, Butler and director Babak Najafi (HBO’s “Banshee”) strike a tone that’s more consistent — consistently dumb.

author: Randall Colburn
summary: London Has Fallen is terrorism porn, an alarmist, jingoistic piece of CGI-soaked garbage that implores its audience to fear nothing after sensationalizing the slaughter of innocents and the destruction of a major city.

author: David Lewis
summary: When viewing the action thriller London Has Fallen, there’s no escaping the reality that you’ve seen everything on the screen before — many, many times. For every bullet, and you will lose count, there is a cliche.

author: Daniel Schindel
summary: The special effects are worse than I thought modern studio filmmaking allowed for. Actors such as Robert Forster and Melissa Leo reprise their roles from the first film with maybe half-a-dozen lines apiece. Were it not for the presence of said actors, this could easily pass for a DTV spin-off.

author: Neil Genzlinger
summary: Will this hard-luck president again defy death while his stoic sidekick vanquishes the nasty, uncivilized terrorists? It’s hard to care when a movie is this formulaic and moronic.

author: Stephanie Merry
summary: London Has Fallen is remarkable only because of how much worse it is than its inane predecessor.

author: Peter Sobczynski
summary: A horrible and wildly unnecessary follow-up that might actually be worse than its predecessor.

author: Marc Savlov
summary: Perhaps these are dark times, both onscreen and off, but even if they are not, London Has Fallen is an hour-and-a-half of viciously Us vs. Them, Trump-style bad filmmaking on all known levels.

author: Peter Travers
summary: Make American movies great again. You can start by boycotting this one.

author: Lou Lumenick
summary: Racist, stupid and boasting cheesy effects.

author: Ignatiy Vishnevetsky
summary: Perhaps the movie’s politics—which range from tone deaf to irredeemable—would be more of an issue if it weren’t so inept.

author: Calvin Wilson
summary: This is very much an ensemble film, with Wahlberg, Hudson and Russell turning in performances that get the job done without begging for attention.

author: Bob Mondello
summary: An action flick entertaining enough to justify the more than $100 million it took to make it come alive on-screen. And come alive, Deepwater Horizon does, in 107 minutes of terse, tight storytelling, a good 95 of which are white-knuckle tense.

author: Amy Nicholson
summary: It’s a hero story for wonks and scientists, people who spend their days surrounded by dry-erase boards inked with numbers and grids and yet go to work in a jumpsuit, their faces smeared with muck.

author: Peter Rainer
summary: Their chief adversary is the greedy, heedless BP executive played by John Malkovich in his finest slinky-slimy mode. At its best, the movie is like “The Towering Inferno” but without all the sudsy subplots that doused that film’s fires.

author: Leah Greenblatt
summary: What works almost disturbingly well is the way Berg calibrates his delivery of the disaster while still holding on to the human scale of it.

author: Michael Roffman
summary: Berg offers a visceral experience that overwhelms with startling humanity.

author: Stephanie Zacharek
summary: Malkovich sure isn’t subtle, either, but that’s the point: his job is to get your blood boiling, and boy, he’s good at it.

author: David Edelstein
summary: My only serious complaint about Deepwater Horizon is that it’s not quite the muckraker I’d hoped for.

author: Tim Robey
summary: Berg’s favourite subject...is heroism at the brink, but the rescue efforts here aren’t pushed to the outsize or sentimental extremes they might have been.

author: Stephen Whitty
summary: It's an impressive achievement, and even Berg's taste for the obvious — like shots of Old Glory, still waving through the worst of it — can't overwhelm the humanity behind the drama. Real people, real danger — and real self-sacrifice.

author: Mike Scott
summary: With Deepwater Horizon, Berg strikes an unlikely but impressively delicate balance. On one hand, his film honors the men and women killed and injured in the explosion off Louisiana's coast. At the same time, it works just as well as a fast-moving and absorbing disaster drama.

author: Bilge Ebiri
summary: [Berg] keeps things simple, tight and taut, and does right by the folks who were there for the real thing. He’s made them the heroes of a genuinely exciting action movie.

author: Matt Donato
summary: Deepwater Horizon is effective, efficient and furiously paced.

author: Chris Hewitt (1)
summary: An efficient and no-nonsense depiction of the worst disaster in US oil drilling history, buoyed by excellent performances.

author: Todd McCarthy
summary: Director Peter Berg and star Mark Wahlberg deliver the goods again with a rugged drama about an incident that created an environmental disaster and a worldwide scandal.

author: Benjamin Lee
summary: When all hell breaks loose, Berg stages the action horribly well, capturing the panic and gruesome mayhem without the film ever feeling exploitative. It’s spectacularly constructed, yet it doesn’t forget about the loss of life, ensuring that, despite thin characterisation, the impact is felt.

author: Tirdad Derakhshani
summary: I've rarely encountered such pure poetry of action as in the opening minutes of Deepwater Horizon, director Peter Berg's exciting and emotionally wrenching thriller.

author: Lou Lumenick
summary: What we’ve got is a highly entertaining nautical version of “The Towering Inferno’’ (still my favorite guilty pleasure of all time).

author: Barry Hertz
summary: The overall product is so tightly assembled, and so emotionally satisfying, that any complaints end up being inconsequential.

author: Peter Travers
summary: Berg does a tremendous job of throwing us into the action with the help of dizzying handheld camerawork from Enrique Chediak.

author: James Berardinelli
summary: Although engaging, Deepwater Horizon ultimately offers a mixed bag of an experience. The setup is considerably better than the payoff, front-loading the experience.

author: Ann Hornaday
summary: When disaster strikes, about an hour into the movie, we’re put in the uncomfortable position of admiring the fiery spectacle that Berg has created with sophisticated visual effects, cinematography and editing, while being aware that unspeakable real-life suffering has been packaged for mass entertainment. Berg does a good job of maintaining a thoughtful balance between those somewhat uneasy stances.

author: Michael Phillips
summary: Berg sticks to the job at hand, imagining what it is was like to be there, and to be the victim of sloppy, deadly safety practices in the name of a good day on Wall Street.

author: Lawrence Toppman
summary: The film’s well-paced and well-acted, and I couldn’t take my eyes off it most of the way. I faltered as projectile followed projectile and explosion topped explosion, yet even then the excitement held up.

author: Brian Truitt
summary: While Deepwater Horizon effectively shows its mettle as a proper action film, it goes the extra mile and drills a little deeper to unearth a lot of heart as well.

author: Steve Persall
summary: Deepwater Horizon is a brawny hybrid of technical expertise and real-life tragedy, with neither quality getting shortchanged.

author: Richard Roeper
summary: It’s a well-made, sometimes horrifyingly realistic re-creation of events — but it often feels like a formulaic disaster film.

author: Roger Moore
summary: Berg reminds us that even in the worst disaster, people can be selfless, heroic, and in the case of Aaron Dale Burkeen, professional even if those who gamble with their fates are not.

author: Gregory Ellwood
summary: Outside of the Berg’s incredible depiction of the Deepwater’s destruction and the escape of a majority of its crew, the picture also benefits from two fantastic performances by Wahlberg and Rodriguez.

author: Anthony Lane
summary: In short, Peter Berg has done it again. You come out shaken with excitement, but with a touch of shame, too, at being so easily thrilled.

author: Justin Chang
summary: Swift, no-nonsense and pummelingly intense, this is the big-budget Hollywood disaster flick on a CrossFit regimen and a Paleo diet — a hellish cataclysm that never risks overstaying its welcome.

author: A.O. Scott
summary: The film itself is as much a feat of engineering as a work of art, an efficient machine for delivering intricate data and blunt emotions.

author: Bill Goodykoontz
summary: Berg keeps the story personal, which is certainly one way to tell it, though it would have been nice to see a little more about the devastating effects of the massive oil spill triggered by the rig's destruction.

author: Matt Singer
summary: As a director, Berg is known for his brutal action scenes, and while Deepwater Horizon’s second half is full of intense sequences, the film’s first half is just as exciting thanks to the wonderfully uncomfortable dynamics between Wahlberg, Russell, and Malkovich.

author: Peter Debruge
summary: For a movie in which you can’t follow what’s going on for 75% of the time, Deepwater Horizon proves remarkably thrilling.

author: Bryan Bishop
summary: There’s no question that Deepwater Horizon delivers thrills, but you may feel awfully empty afterward.

author: Soren Andersen
summary: The picture’s pyrotechnics are first rate, and the acting by the principals is more than serviceable.

author: Ty Burr
summary: A taut, engrossing action movie about real-life heroes, so why is it a disappointment? Because director Peter Berg is telling the wrong story.

author: Rex Reed
summary: This is a movie about action, not acting, and although, under the circumstances, the cast does yeoman work in roles that can only be called generic, in the long haul they can’t save the script and direction from being sometimes boring and always predictable.

author: Rebecca Onion
summary: I left the film moved to tears, and still feeling like something huge was missing.

author: Neil Smith
summary: As crude as the oil it revolves around, Deepwater provides combustible entertainment without leaving the shallows.

author: Tom Huddleston
summary: Accusations of tastelessness are bound to arrive, with some justification. If your priority is to respect the dead, why hire the director of Battleship?

author: Fionnuala Halligan
summary: If nothing else, Deepwater Horizon makes a case for going back to basics with action films. It’s classically framed, executed, and feels like the real deal, and while it clearly boasts some fine effects work, it manages to lose the cartoonish aspect of so many recent tentpoles.

author: Ignatiy Vishnevetsky
summary: As entertainment, it works in the most rote way: the star power of Wahlberg, Russell, and Kate Hudson, who plays Mike’s worried wife; Malkovich’s predictable sliminess; the minor pleasure of seeing the good guys get out; the slight kick of watching something big crumble and burn while knowing that it’s only a special effect, real-world basis be damned.

author: Jordan Ruimy
summary: Deepwater Horizon reminds us just how talented an action director Berg is and how often substance becomes a second thought for the director.

author: Sam Fragoso
summary: It’s a thrilling film with impressive set pieces, solid acting and a pulse-pounding climax. Movie-wise, mission mostly accomplished. But to experience Deepwater Horizon and ignore the external circumstances surrounding its creation is a difficult task.

author: Joe Morgenstern
summary: It’s ultimately a genre film with all that implies, meaning omissions, simplifications, conventional heroics, dramatic banalities and, given the narrative’s limited scope, little sense of the event’s complex causes or its environmental cost.

author: Mick LaSalle
summary: It has scale, spectacle and a cast of good actors who seem to believe in what they’re doing. But the movie springs to life only in spurts.

author: Brian Tallerico
summary: As is often the case with Berg’s films, it’s technically accomplished, but it’s lacking the depth of a project that comes from a creative spark. Everything here feels routine—more like an inevitability than a work of art or even a piece of entertainment.

author: Eric Kohn
summary: It turns a major tragedy into a minor disaster movie.

author: Josh Kupecki
summary: That Berg and writers Matthew Carnahan and Matthew Sand stick strictly to the day of that explosion and subsequent fire that sank the Deepwater Horizon certainly presents a narrative opportunity, but the lack of any resonance to larger issues is troubling (the end-credit coda is woefully thin).

author: Jake Cole
summary: The film should have been a cautionary tale, but in Peter Berg's hands, it's a hollow account of the resilience of the human spirit.

author: Richard Roeper
summary: A sequel that’s never subtle, rarely surprising — and as rich, syrupy, sweet and satisfying as a tray of homemade baklava.

author: Tim Cogshell
summary: It’s sweet, just like the original movie. It was faint praise then, and it still is.

author: Tom Russo
summary: If you appreciated the first movie’s sweetness, then you’ll likely be charmed enough. Otherwise, you’ll find the oof-to-opa! ratio hasn’t changed.

author: Rebecca Keegan
summary: The sequel is a little like a bear hug from a beloved old relative — the embrace is too tight, the perfume is too strong, but ultimately it still leaves you feeling good inside.

author: Joe Dziemianowicz
summary: Among the lessons learned: marriages need tending and distance can make people closer. Not earth-shaking, but harmless. Like this sequel.

author: Frank Scheck
summary: That it all works to the extent that it does is due to its undeniably sweet depiction of a close-knit extended family whose members truly care for and help each other. It's cinematic wish fulfillment in this era of broken families and far-off relatives who keep in touch via social media.

author: Eric Kohn
summary: Despite some clumsy moments, My Big Fat Greek Wedding 2 handily revives the first movie's appeal.

author: Kate Taylor
summary: There are many plot lines here, but little tension.

author: Sara Stewart
summary: Some things, like ouzo and flaming cheese, are best left at single servings.

author: Moira Macdonald
summary: None of this has any real reason for being; even the tiniest bit of drama that Vardalos’ screenplay scares up...gets wrapped up by the hour mark. But Vardalos has created a community of characters and players so likable, it seems almost mean to criticize.

author: Roger Moore
summary: My Big Fat Greek Wedding 2 is a veritable feast of low-hanging fruit. The laughs are obvious, we see them coming a mile away.

author: Clint Worthington
summary: My Big Fat Greek Wedding 2 is about as unmemorable a movie as you’ll find in 2016. Everything about it, from Vardalos’ screenplay to the limp retreads of the first Greek Wedding’s better moments, stinks of an extended HBO special that somehow made its way to theaters.

author: Daniel Schindel
summary: My Big Fat Greek Wedding 2 commits the perennial sequel mistake of indulging the breakout characters, letting them run rampant over everything in the process. Giving everyone the spotlight only diffuses the heart.

author: Jesse Hassenger
summary: Maybe Vardalos should revisit this material when she’s ready to write "My Big Fat Greek Funeral."

author: Devan Coggan
summary: The winking ethnic jokes weren’t all that revolutionary in the first film, and this time around, they feel even more stale.

author: Stephanie Zacharek
summary: Those jokes are mostly just toothless and silly. The plot is barely serviceable, but it will do, and most of the first movie’s cast has been reassembled under its flimsy umbrella.

author: Kate Lloyd
summary: If you loved the first one, you’ll happily sit through this one. It’s just not quite as good.

author: Steve Davis
summary: Admittedly, the original had its unruly moments, but there’s little to no discipline here. The storyline goes in six different directions, and the actors are unleashed in an apparent free-for-all as they vie for center stage at the Parthenon.

author: Fionnuala Halligan
summary: Even given that lazy stereotyping is the point of her schtick, Vardalos’ broad routine hasn’t aged well, her heavily-(and widely-) accented ‘oily’ Greek family an uncomfortable, almost retro fit for today’s global sensitivities. Apart from that, the gags just aren’t that funny.

author: Bilge Ebiri
summary: There's little drama here, but there is a touching sense of reflection.

author: Geoff Berkshire
summary: Every bit as sitcom-ish and saccharine as its predecessor, but considerably less distinctive.

author: Tirdad Derakhshani
summary: Predictable, tired, formulaic, it makes up for its lack of originality with a bigger budget, louder jokes, louder costumes, and louder music.

author: Eric Henderson
summary: As far as shameless excuses to rehash crowd-pleasing gags from the first film go, it doesn't particularly go about its duties cynically.

author: Stephanie Merry
summary: With so many warmed-over jokes, you’d think that the delivery would at least be on point. But everything, including the timing, feels off.

author: Randy Cordova
summary: The script, written by the actress, is downright wretched at times.

author: James Berardinelli
summary: This is a sit com. An ‘80s-style sit-com. A bad ‘80s-style sit-com.

author: Peter Travers
summary: What once bubbled up from a sincere love of Greek family has now congealed into the all-too-familiar Hollywood tale of  milking a cash cow until cries for mercy.

author: Christy Lemire
summary: Over and over again, this is the level of humor in My Big Fat Greek Wedding 2 — this is the shrill note it hits.

author: Mick LaSalle
summary: Nia Vardalos has such a warm, alert energy that’s impossible to hate My Big Fat Greek Wedding 2, even as it’s impossible to like it, even a little.

author: Steve Persall
summary: In 2002, "My Big Fat Greek Wedding" was at least a unique cultural take on movie cliches typically reserved for Italian and Jewish squabbles and makeups. Now it's all stale baklava, made with love but past its prime. Opa? Nope-a.

author: David Ehrlich
summary: Here is a movie that encourages you to give it the benefit of the doubt at every possible turn but has no interest in offering anything in return. If you liked the original, you’ll like this one less. If you loathed the original, may God be with you. Opa!

author: Jeannette Catsoulis
summary: The comedy is forced, the drama nonexistent and the actors melt into a yapping clan that seems to go everywhere en masse — a gesticulating blob of upraised shoulders and upturned palms.

author: Terri White
summary: A simply extraordinary film without crashes, bangs and wallops but full of towering performances delivered with intelligence, power and heart.

author: Odie Henderson
summary: The masterful thing about Denzel Washington’s direction here is that he doesn’t exactly open up the play. Instead, he opens up the visual frame around the players.

author: Ann Hornaday
summary: Ringing with both ancient wisdom and searing relevance, Fences feels as if it’s been crafted for the ages, and for this very minute.

author: Moira Macdonald
summary: Though every performance is splendid, it’s Washington and Davis who create a mesmerizing symphony of emotion, finding both love and tragedy in every look, every line.

author: Rex Reed
summary: The best ensemble work of the year

author: Mick LaSalle
summary: Washington delivers not only one of the year’s best performances, but one of the best self-directed performances in cinema history.

author: Joe Morgenstern
summary: It’s all too seldom that a feature film combines brilliant acting with a spellbinding flow of language.

author: April Wolfe
summary: This screen adaptation...is vital because it has the potential to reach marginalized communities. But it also stands as an aching, lyrical, performance-driven masterpiece in its own right, a film so intense and engrossing that movie houses really should screen it with an intermission.

author: Chris Nashawaty
summary: It’s as good as screen acting gets.

author: A.O. Scott
summary: Even as it properly foregrounds Wilson’s dialogue — few playwrights have approached his genius for turning workaday vernacular into poetry — Fences is much more than a filmed reading. Mr. Washington has wisely resisted the temptation to force a lot of unnecessary cinema on the play.

author: Marc Savlov
summary: This is Denzel Washington’s third at bat behind the camera while directing himself and, holy smokes, does he knock it out of the park with a vicious, visceral performance that fairly sets the screen ablaze.

author: James Berardinelli
summary: Yes, Fences suffers somewhat from the bare-bones transferal of the “action” from stage to screen but the material is so compelling that viewers can easily lose sight of the movie’s “play nature.”

author: Roger Moore
summary: A Great American Play becomes a Great American Film with Fences, Denzel Washington’s letter-faithful adaptation of August Wilson’s Pulitzer Prize winning masterpiece.

author: Ty Burr
summary: You don’t get groundbreaking cinema from Fences, but what you do get — two titanic performances and an immeasurable American drama — makes up for that.

author: Lawrence Toppman
summary: Denzel Washington directed and stars in Fences, and he has translated every element of August Wilson’s play to the screen: A language that’s naturalistic yet gently poetic, a detailed sense of America at mid-century...drama that turns to melodrama at key points, characterizations that seethe and explode, the touch of the fantastic (or is it the supernatural?) that pervades most of Wilson’s stories.

author: Tirdad Derakhshani
summary: Fences is also very much an actors' movie, with breathtaking performances from Washington and his costars, including Davis, Stephen Henderson, Jovan Adepo, Russell Hornsby, and Mykelti Williamson.

author: Michael Phillips
summary: Robust, delicate, sublimely acted and a close cinematic cousin to the theatrical original, director Denzel Washington's film version of Fences makes up for a lot of overeager or undercooked stage-to-screen adaptations over the decades.

author: Brian Truitt
summary: Washington has put together a troupe that crafts a retro story that’s still completely relatable, no matter one’s race, and brilliantly plays a protagonist that finds the sweetest spot between lovable and loathsome.

author: Peter Travers
summary: The movie of Fences doesn't need Hollywood bells and whistles. This writer, this director and these actors are all the magnificence required to grab your attention and hold it.

author: Steve Persall
summary: If Fences occasionally feels cinematically inert, it's emotionally resonant thanks to Davis and Washington the actor, not the director as much.

author: Tim Robey
summary: The great coup Washington delivers, beyond framing his co-star’s virtuous anguish so well, is the risky, brilliant, and frequently alienating performance he gives as Troy.

author: John Bleasdale
summary: With its depth and power, Wilson's play is a blue-collar Death of a Salesman and the music of the dialogue, with Davis and Washington at the peak of their powers, makes the whole thing sing.

author: Neil Smith
summary: Denzel Washington and Viola Davis excel in a well-crafted drama that’s sure to bring the late August Wilson’s words to a much wider audience.

author: Dave Calhoun
summary: It’s easy to throw accusations of staginess at film adaptations of theatre like this, which honour the limitations of theatre and make only limited attempts to open up the play. But there’s a hothouse atmosphere to this domestic drama that works well on screen.

author: Bill Goodykoontz
summary: Fences is a feast of brilliant acting, in a story that’s sometimes as difficult as it is powerful.

author: Kenneth Turan
summary: Every moment on screen may not be enthralling, but the moments that are are such knockouts they make the enterprise essential viewing.

author: Stephen Whitty
summary: Washington isn't a visionary director, something he's proved before in "The Great Debaters" and "Antwone Fisher." But he is a fine actor, and if nothing else Fences preserves his career-best performance, as a loving, bullying, wounded, roaring bull of a man.

author: Tim Grierson
summary: Fences is a deeply affecting treatise on marriage, poverty and the struggles of sons to confront the long shadow of the man who brought them into this world.

author: Catherine Shoard
summary: This film is conceived as a showcase for its performers, and, as that, it is immaculate.

author: Barry Hertz
summary: In Fences, every time a character opens their mouth is an opportunity to savour the playwright’s impeccable ear for language – for capturing the joys and frustrations that come when someone simply tries to say something – anything – about the daily struggle that is life. It’s as much workaday poetry as it is dialogue and Washington knows better than to dilute it or make it his own.

author: Calvin Wilson
summary: Fences is perhaps best appreciated as a showcase for the brilliant acting of Washington and Davis.

author: Richard Roeper
summary: What works: the brilliant dialogue, and the raw intensity of the performances. It’s a privilege to watch Washington and Davis lay it all on the line.

author: Michael Snydel
summary: Fences is a reasonably strong adaptation and further evidence that Washington has an assured hand with both actors and the camera, but it feels stuck between its reverence to the source material and its desire for a more distinctive vision.

author: David Ehrlich
summary: Washington, Henderson, Davis, and Hornsby are each “holy shit” great in their own ways, the four of them deepening the dynamics they forged together during their time on stage.

author: Dana Stevens
summary: Fences functions as a faithful—sometimes doggedly faithful—record of a remarkable ensemble performance of one of the great works of American drama. Granted, it’s never exactly a great movie, but given the chance to see actors of this caliber tear into material this rich, you would be foolish to pass up the chance.

author: Matt Donato
summary: Fences is old-school Americana that's driven by dynamite performances all around, albeit a bit stuffy in nature.

author: Todd McCarthy
summary: Denzel Washington and Viola Davis know their parts here backward and forward, and they, along with the rest of the fine cast, bat a thousand, hitting both the humorous and serious notes. But with this comes a sense that all the conflicts, jokes and meanings are being smacked right on the nose in vivid close-ups, with nothing left to suggestion, implication and interpretation.

author: Robert Abele
summary: Can you tell it’s a play? Absolutely. Does that mean a damn thing? Not when the writing is this richly evocative, and the cast so often soars with it.

author: Randall Colburn
summary: In this instance, the medium just doesn’t elevate the material. That said, Fences is still a gripping watch, but it’s gripping for the reasons the play has always been gripping: the language and performances.

author: Ignatiy Vishnevetsky
summary: Washington gives a magnetic, layered performance, backed by a largely superb cast, most of whom reprise their roles from the Broadway revival of Wilson’s classic. But the film itself is eluded by the epic qualities of the original text, which play directly to the captive space of the theater.

author: Peter Rainer
summary: The result, as might be expected, is strong on acting and overly stagey.

author: Chuck Bowen
summary: Danzel Washington honors the manna of the play's being: the micro of romantic longing, self-loathing, and nostalgia.

author: Kyle Smith
summary: Honorable, worthy and windy, Fences is essentially a PBS episode of “Great Performances” that is inflated for the big screen without ever quite belonging there.

author: David Edelstein
summary: It’s not cinematic enough to make you forget you’re watching something conceived for another, more spatially constricted medium, but it’s too cinematic to capture the intensity, the concentration, of a great theatrical event.

author: Joshua Rothkopf
summary: Wilson’s play, about dreams deferred and a son seeking approbation (The Leftovers’ Jovan Adepo), could have used a more cinematic rethink. But even flatly presented, it has a richness of rage that’s unmistakable.

author: Stephanie Zacharek
summary: In the end, it feels too much like a school assignment. Washington approaches the material with canonical reverence, but that isn’t the same as shaking it up and bringing it to life on-screen.

author: Owen Gleiberman
summary: Fences has passages of fierce and moving power, but on screen the play comes off as episodic and more than a bit unwieldy.

author: Rodrigo Perez
summary: There’s nothing lost in the translation of Fences, but its high fidelity means there’s little, if any, inspiration to be found within.

author: Lawrence Toppman
summary: A gently spellbinding drama that captures the old-fashioned enchantment of Roald Dahl’s book.

author: Robbie Collin
summary: It’s a weighty technical accomplishment – the extraordinary detailed motion-capture technology alone, which stretches Rylance’s human performance to giant-sized proportions, is river-straddling bounds beyond anything you’ve seen before.

author: Peter Debruge
