summary: This is a prequel superior to its predecessor – we’re not bored with board-game ghoulishness yet.

author: Tirdad Derakhshani
summary: While it's not entirely successful, this stylish shocker is a big step up from the earlier film.

author: Roger Moore
summary: Reaser, Thomas, Basso and especially the demonically playful Miss Wilson play the Mike Flanagan, Jeff Howard script like a fiddle.

author: Katie Walsh
summary: For a horror sequel built around a foundation of genre trends, Ouija: Origin of Evil contains far more goofy-spooky fun than one might expect.

author: Ed Gonzalez
summary: The film complements its goose-pimply frights with an unabashedly naked emotional gravitas.

author: Edward Douglas
summary: Ouija: Origin of Evil offers some easy scares and cheesy fun, but if nothing else, it gets points for not losing sight of its characters amidst those scares.

author: Stephen Kelly
summary: Unlike the stock teenagers of Ouija, the Zander family are likeable and convincing. Scares are still rudimentary, but rooted in a sharper script.

author: Matt Donato
summary: Ouija: Origin Of Evil would have been better than Ouija with even a quarter of the screams evoked, which makes the tremendous jump in quality quite refreshing despite derivative storytelling.

author: Mike McCahill
summary: It’s still no scarier than any branded content, and perhaps only the most lukewarm slumber party would truly need it. Yet if you were to ask whether Origin of Evil offers a better quality of timewasting than its predecessor, my finger would hover inexorably over YES.

author: Tom Huddleston
summary: Origin of Evil takes a while to get going, and the demonic possession plot pretty much runs on rails. And yet there’s plenty to admire here: strong performances (‘ET’ legend Henry Thomas is a welcome sight as a kindly priest), top-notch jump-scares and some unexpectedly lovely, almost ‘Far From Heaven’-ish autumnal photography.

author: Christian Holub
summary: Effective horror relies on the actualization of some deep-seated cultural fear, but Ouija: Origin of Evil supplies only ineffective clichés and half-hearted attempts at franchise building.

author: Michael Ordona
summary: There’s nothing unique about the setup. But Flanagan and Howard’s script has charming touches, wringing humor out of characters rather than gags. Even the retro opening title card foretells its self-aware sense of humor.

author: Jane Horwitz
summary: Ouija: Origin of Evil is, somewhat unexpectedly, not that bad.

author: Mick LaSalle
summary: It is a satisfying but thoroughly idiotic film, in which relationships make no sense, character motivations change on a dime, and Tom Hanks has weird hair. But brainless as it is, it’s artful. It is a well-made bit of silliness, a piece of construction optimally designed to maintain audience interest while garnering absolutely no one’s respect.

author: Bill Zwecker
summary: Inferno delivers as an engaging thriller that I frankly enjoyed far more than Howard’s last Brown outing.

author: Simon Perry
summary: Bourne it is not, but the twists come with enough regularity to keep the squishier parts of the plot from mucking up the works.

author: Edward Douglas
summary: It's fair to say that Inferno won't be for everyone, but those who have stuck through Howard and Hanks' previous Dan Brown adaptations should find enough thrills to keep them interested in solving the mystery.

author: Fionnuala Halligan
summary: Koepp has managed a brisk adaptation, although some of the dialogue can feel very forced, particularly when it comes to the clue-solving set-ups. Still, Howard keeps the viewer constantly occupied, Felicity Jones is an engaging sidekick, and there’s clearly a lot more mileage left for Tom Hanks in this franchise’s tank.

author: Leslie Felperin
summary: Although some of the film’s many twists are not that surprising, they’re satisfyingly delivered, and with a strong supporting cast ...plus striking dream imagery, this adds up to arguably the best in the franchise so far.

author: Kimberley Jones
summary: Returning director Ron Howard somewhat belabors the Botticelli-inspired hallucinations Langdon suffers from following a konk on the head – though you really can’t oversell the creepiness of a beaky plague mask – but he continues to have an inspired hand in casting his supporting players.

author: Brad Wheeler
summary: Perhaps Howard’s dutiful obligation to Brown’s treasure-hunt oeuvre will end here, with the temperate Inferno sparking a resurgence to follow. Dante wrote that “The poets leave hell and again behold the stars.” Here’s hoping that Howard has some shine left in him.

author: Ty Burr
summary: Inferno is the exact cinematic equivalent of an airport paperback, which is what’s fine and forgettable about it.

author: Neil Smith
summary: Early promise proves misleading in a sequel that should be far better than The Da Vinci Code than it actually is.

author: Ignatiy Vishnevetsky
summary: This latest film, which was made on about half the budget of either of its predecessors, is as close as the Langdon-Howard cycle has gotten to actually being fun.

author: Dan Mecca
summary: The first two — The Da Vinci Code and Angels & Demons — left much to be desired. This one emerges as a marked improvement, though that’s not saying a whole lot.

author: Will Ashton
summary: Whatever inspired the compulsively addictive (I assume) fast-selling book series isn’t found in yet another dull, tiresome race-against-the-clock European mystery thriller with a historical twist.

author: Roger Moore
summary: The most interesting character and performance come from the great Indian actor Iffran Khan (“Life of Pi,” “Jurassic World,” “The Lunchbox”). He brings a wonderful world weariness to this “dark money” criminal mastermind.

author: Peter Rainer
summary: Unless you are a Dante scholar, and perhaps not even then, following Inferno is a wild goose chase – without the goose.

author: Manohla Dargis
summary: Part of the draw of these movies is that they don’t create beauty, but instead borrow the emotions of the beauty they depict. (This, more or less, is one definition of kitsch, courtesy of the philosopher Tomas Kulka.) That makes the movies easy to watch and easy to forget.

author: Kyle Smith
summary: The film is never gripping, but at least it moves. Director Ron Howard does his best to spark excitement with cheesy horror-movie editing — brief shots of the damnation in store if the virus is unleashed — and there are a couple of twists to keep things lively. Nothing is what it seems, unless it seems ridiculous, in which case it’s exactly what it seems.

author: James Berardinelli
summary: The "Da Vinci Code" was adequate but forgettable. "Angels & Demons" was godawful. Inferno is somewhere in between - watchable but by no means worth the money and effort necessary to see it theatrically.

author: Calvin Wilson
summary: Don’t get burned by Inferno.

author: Kenneth Turan
summary: It's not that "Inferno" as it stands doesn't provide hints of better things. The plot has its share of unexpected twists, peripheral characters hold our attention, wide-screen vistas of tourist destinations Florence, Venice and Istanbul are easy to take, and stories involving the end of the world have a certain built-in interest. But as presented on screen, none of this gels as it should.

author: Steve Persall
summary: Inferno is another docent tour dressed as an action movie, a baby boomer's fantasy of travel and intrigue.

author: Christy Lemire
summary: The multiple twists, double-crosses and leaps in logic are more likely to prompt giggles than gasps, despite the impressive production values and the earnest efforts of an A-list cast.

author: Lawrence Toppman
summary: Ron Howard, who’s tied to this franchise like a man trapped in a decaying house by a huge mortgage, tries without success to blow life into David Koepp’s script.

author: Soren Andersen
summary: The chase, chase, chase pace is tiring, not least because it’s not clear who many of these people are and what agendas they’re following. Mixed-up confusion is the result.

author: Brian Truitt
summary: Even with a wealth of talent involved, Inferno is missing some serious heat.

author: Amy Nicholson
summary: When it was all over, I found myself googling Dante for my own clue as to what I’d just suffered: “He who knows most grieves most for wasted time.”

author: Clint Worthington
summary: Inferno, much like its predecessors, simply can’t work its way out of the disappointing middle ground between a slick, technically competent thriller and tongue-in-cheek absurdity.

author: Demetrios Matheou
summary: If the first film was ploddingly, airlessly faithful to its source, this follows the second in being frantically paced, chaotic and increasingly exasperating.

author: David Edelstein
summary: Tom Hanks takes his art down a peg with another paycheck performance as the dramatic cipher Robert Langdon in Inferno, Ron Howard’s mostly lame adaptation of Dan Brown’s wholly lame novel.

author: Joe Morgenstern
summary: This gets to be exhausting, since there’s hardly a scene that isn’t manipulative or assaultive.

author: Matt Donato
summary: Inferno feels every bit like the second sequel in an exhausted franchise, stunted by unfocused storytelling and a blandness that's almost sleep-inducing.

author: Bill Goodykoontz
summary: Inferno...is the kind of movie that stops — and stoops — to explain, early and often. Not that the explanations amount to much; the movie makes almost no sense.

author: Mike Scott
summary: Howard's film, particularly early on, ends up being too fast, too dense and too smart for its own good. Keeping moviegoers guessing is one thing. Keeping them confused is quite another.

author: Helen O'Hara
summary: It’s not the worst of the trilogy, but this is less for fans of thrillers and more for people who are pining after last year’s holiday to Florence.

author: Tom Huddleston
summary: By the end, even Hanks looks a bit bored.

author: Guy Lodge
summary: There’s a stern, let’s-get-to-work air to the film’s craft and conception that hampers whatever thrill of the chase “Inferno” has to offer. Fundamentally silly the film may be, but it never graduates to spryness.

author: Peter Travers
summary: Hanks is one of the most likable actors on the planet. But Inferno just lays there onscreen, pancake-flat and with no animating spark to make us give a damn.

author: Tirdad Derakhshani
summary: The more movie magic Howard piles on, the less we care. And, boy, does he pull out all the stops, stocking the pic with a tub of red herrings, half a dozen plot twists, and more complex set pieces than a comic-book flick. I felt relieved when it was finally over.

author: Michael Phillips
summary: This is a franchise with lead weights tied around its ankles.

author: Michael O'Sullivan
summary: Say what you will about Dan Brown’s books. They may be, as some have noted, poorly written, formulaic and pretentious. But at least they hold a reader’s attention, in ways that this excursion — as sleep-inducing and rigidly predictable as a train ride — does not.

author: Matt Singer
summary: The Da Vinci Code wasn’t Da Vinci, but it was an actual movie with texture and characters. Inferno is dumbed down to a shocking degree.

author: Jake Cole
summary: It's impossible to even laugh at Inferno given how Ron Howard reduces the material to a dull spectacle of earnest puzzle-solving.

author: Joe Walsh
summary: Like The Da Vinci Code and Angels & Demons before it, Inferno stumbles into the same pitfalls of convoluted plotting, kindergarten art history and conspiracy theories of the daytime-slot-on-the-Discovery-Channel sort.

author: Robbie Collin
summary: While the plot’s endless lurches and jinks are designed to hold you in a constant state of pleasurable bafflement, the cumulative effect is desensitisation: no single thread holds long enough to give you anything to cheer for or believe in.

author: Jason Solomons
summary: Ron Howard allows all manner of contrivances to pile up in David Koepp‘s screenplay, as if relying on constant reference to Dante’s Divine Comedy would make people think, “Ooh, this is clever stuff.”

author: Peter Bradshaw
summary: Once upon a time, this wackiness had some novelty value. Now it’s tedious.

author: Bilge Ebiri
summary: Take the Dan Brown out of a Dan Brown movie and all you’re left with is Tom Hanks jogging in mild irritation.

author: Rebecca Hawkes
summary: It’s utterly ridiculous – and impossible to resist.

author: James Berardinelli
summary: Gods of Egypt is often sloppy and fails in many ways but the cheesy momentum is hard to resist.

author: Brad Wheeler
summary: It’s all quest, flash and high action.

author: Nick Schager
summary: It’s a spectacular mess that’s shameless in its desire to entertain through sheer, misbegotten excess.

author: Ignatiy Vishnevetsky
summary: A treasure trove of gilded fantasy bric-a-brac and clashing accents, Proyas’ sword-and-sandals space opera is a head above the likes of Wrath Of The Titans, but it rapidly devolves into a tedious and repetitive succession of monster chases, booby traps, and temples that start to crumble at the last minute.

author: Matt Zoller Seitz
summary: The alternately cornball and self-aware dialogue and the clearly not state-of-the-art CGI would seeming charmingly retro (like something from a TV miniseries two decades ago) if the movie didn't trot out one epic action film cliche after another.

author: Michael Snydel
summary: While the film becomes a constant test to outdo itself, the raw ambition isn’t nearly enough to make up for the content of the actual film: an ungainly, ugly, nearly interminable monstrosity.

author: Bilge Ebiri
summary: It’s both thin and overstuffed, filled with intricate, at times dazzling set-pieces peopled by characters we don’t care about, and an irreverent sense of fun that nevertheless leaves us cold. It tries so hard… and ultimately achieves so little.

author: Manohla Dargis
summary: If Gods of Egypt were any worse, it might be a masterpiece.

author: Sarah Ward
summary: As audience-friendly as they may be, the cast is left wading through the middle ground between the unengaging narrative and over-emphasised aesthetics.

author: Roger Moore
summary: There’s a long year ahead of us, but Gods of Egypt is going to stand out as one of the sillier, more puzzling big budget, special-effects driven period pieces to come out.

author: Clint Worthington
summary: Gods of Egypt is a dull, meandering, plastic mess of pre-2002 CGI and performances as flat as the green screens behind them.

author: Justin Chang
summary: This is by any measure a dreadful movie, a chintzy, CG-encrusted eyesore that oozes stupidity and self-indulgence from every pore. Yet damned if Proyas doesn’t put it all out there with a lunatic conviction you can’t help but admire.

author: Kyle Smith
summary: Like the lobby of a Donald Trump building, it looks ever so expensive and amazingly cheap at the same time.

author: Soren Andersen
summary: Imagine the worst costume epic imaginable. Imagine no more. It exists.

author: Drew Hunt
summary: Its virtues as throwback don't elide the foolhardly decision to imprint an ancient mythology on a contemporary superhero framework.

author: Alonso Duralde
summary: Gods of Egypt might have merited a so-bad-it’s-good schadenfreude fanbase had it maintained the unintentional laughs of its first 10 minutes. Instead, it skids into dullness, thus negating the camp classic that it so often verges on becoming.

author: Chris Nashawaty
summary: A shoddy special-effects howler that makes a hash out of both Egyptian mythology and human logic.

author: Michael Phillips
summary: Call it "Clash of the Whitans," and call it a folly that doesn't have the energy or delirium to qualify as entertaining crap. It's just crap.

author: Anna King
summary: As the film totters to its predictable finale, the closing moments set up a sequel, a prospect far more terrifying than anything we've just seen.

author: Frank Scheck
summary: This overstuffed, witless and bloated stillborn $140 million epic is unlikely to spawn the studio's intended franchise — unless, as is so often the case, international audiences come to the box-office rescue.

author: Stephen Whitty
summary: Director Alex Proyas’ movie feels like a bad video game.

author: Steve Davis
summary: Avoid it like the plagues.

author: Peter Travers
summary: Some movies are so effing awful they're hilarious. Gods of Egypt falls short of that lofty goal. Not because it isn’t effing awful — it so is — but because it pretends to be in on the joke.

author: Mick LaSalle
summary: Gods of Egypt is an epic — an epic disaster.

author: Richard Brody
summary: A comedy, and a scintillating, uproarious one, filled with fast and light touches of exquisite incongruity in scenes that have the expansiveness of relaxed precision, performed and timed with the spontaneous authority of jazz.

author: Andrew O'Hehir
summary: Underneath the laff-riot and the Hollywood satire, Hail, Caesar! is a curiously delicate film built on profound affection for American movies and the illusions they build, and loaded with in-jokes the mainstream audience will grasp incompletely or not at all.

author: Glenn Kenny
summary: An exhilarating switchup: A comic fable that’s both deftly clever and irrepressibly goofy.

author: David Ehrlich
summary: If the Coen brothers’ dramas are cautionary tales, their comedies are veritable how-to guides for people who can’t help but enjoy a mirthless chuckle at the humility of human existence. Yeah, the joke is on us, but that doesn’t mean it isn’t funny.

author: Richard Roeper
summary: Hail, Caesar! is pure, popcorn fun — a visual treat, a comedic tour de force and a sublime and sly slice of satire.

author: Michael Snydel
summary: Just as the brothers themselves love to present dialectics about the duality of triviality and seriousness, so, too, does Hail, Caesar! constantly skate back and forth between feeling slight and monumental.

author: Kenneth Turan
summary: The great thing about Hail, Caesar! is that it is fun whether you get all its references or not.

author: Ty Burr
summary: There are the serious Coen brothers movies, like “No Country for Old Men” and, um, “A Serious Man,” and there are the not-so-serious ones. Hail, Caesar! is the opposite of their serious ones, and it is delightful.

author: Peter Travers
summary: Hail, Caesar! is basically a day in the life of this studio cop, whose job is his religion. And Brolin, in a heart-and-soul performance, takes this crazy quilt of a movie about a man surrounded by nut jobs and plays it for real. He's just tremendous.

author: Ann Hornaday
summary: Slick, silly and often extravagantly pretty, it’s a pastiche that threads a tricky needle, conveying the dual nature of cinema as an enchanting art form and a ruthless, rationalized industrial practice.

author: Alonso Duralde
summary: The Coens revel in both the glamour and the squalor of post-war Hollywood with a film that more than makes up in wit and flash what it might lack in substance.

author: Drew McWeeny
summary: Even when they're silly, Joel and Ethan Coen are as smart as any filmmakers working, and Hail, Caesar! is a clever cartoon filter through which they examine some very sincere spiritual ideas.

author: Leah Greenblatt
summary: It's Coen lite, basically, but still filled with their best signatures: cracked humor, indelible characters, and cinematography so rich and saturated you want to dunk a cookie in it.

author: Eric Kohn
summary: The Coens get their cake and eat it, too: The lavish period details, paired with marvelous song-and-dance routines, work on their own terms while a firm self-awareness looms over every scene. It's a tricky balance indicative of directors who know exactly what they're going for: An old-fashioned homage to classic Hollywood and a send-up of the very same thing.

author: Dan Jolin
summary: It’s not like the film is hollow — hidden at its heart, in fact, is a struggle for the soul of Hollywood — it’s just that it feels more like a series of pleasant diversions rather than a single, solid journey.

author: Manohla Dargis
summary: It’s a typically sly, off-center comedy, once again set against the machinery of the motion-picture business. And, as usual with the Coens, it has more going on than there might seem, including in its wrangling over God and ideology, art and entertainment.

author: Jamie Graham
summary: Hail, Caesar! is a love letter inked in arsenic, at once celebrating the artistry of Hollywood and cringing at the crass commercialism and rampant phoniness of it all.

author: Andrew Pulver
summary: Hail, Caesar! is a lot of fun, and beautifully crafted, too. One to savour.

author: Justin Chang
summary: This gorgeously crafted romp through the backlots and Malibu enclaves of Hollywood’s Golden Age tosses off plenty of eccentric comedy and musical razzle-dazzle before taking on richer, more ruminative dimensions, ultimately landing on the funny-sad question of whether life is but a dream factory.

author: Matt Singer
summary: Beneath the (sometimes hysterically funny) gags, is a surprisingly thoughtful examination of the same issues that bubble through Joel and Ethan Coen’s more serious pictures; the folly of man, the nature of faith, and the terror of trying to figure out what path through life is the correct one to take.

author: Joshua Rothkopf
summary: It doesn’t seem new for them, yet as super polished, mannered, slightly surreal comedies go, the movie feels as rare as a unicorn.

author: Tasha Robinson
summary: Hail, Caesar! is immensely entertaining, but it's also frustratingly discursive, with so many incomplete sidelines and distractions that it suggests an overcrowded but exciting TV pilot more than a self-contained film.

author: James Berardinelli
summary: The absence of a strong narrative is the film’s weakest aspect. The Coens are so absorbed by their mimicry that they don’t invest a lot of effort in the connective tissue.

author: Peter Rainer
summary: The film is often​ sharp and amusing, but it’s a doodle in the Coen canon.

author: Lou Lumenick
summary: What really makes Hail, Caesar! sing are the Coens’ painstaking period simulations of scenes from five films,including not only “Hail, Caesar!” but a synchronized swimming routine a la Busby Berkeley and a corny musical Western.

author: Steven Rea
summary: A goofy conflation of Coenian elements: the numbskull huggermugger of "The Big Lebowski", the La La Land surrealness of "Barton Fink", the Old Testament overlay of "A Serious Man."

author: Mick LaSalle
summary: One of the Coens’ most inspired, bizarre touches is to cast Tilda Swinton as rival gossip columnists, twins who hate each other. She’s quite funny — blithe and vindictive in one incarnation, insecure and vindictive in the other.

author: Moira Macdonald
summary: Hail, Caesar! isn’t the great film you might like it to be, but it’s very, very good fun.

author: Brian Truitt
summary: Some bits fall flat, yet when the Coens hit, there’s nothing better, especially with their usual ridiculously sublime banter.

author: Jake Cole
summary: Joel and Ethan Coen's idiosyncrasies elevate the film above the level of a mere creative exercise.

author: Tim Grierson
summary: Unquestionably uneven and only occasionally inspired, Hail, Caesar! is nonetheless engrossing and funny thanks to its off-kilter energy and a lead performance from Coens regular Josh Brolin that’s a model of quietly controlled chaos.

author: Joe Dziemianowicz
summary: Star-studded and stylish, this addition to the brothers’ acclaimed canon is a looker with laughs and, alas, dull stretches. It’s fun and entertaining — no more, no less, no exclamation point.

author: Collin Brennan
summary: There’s a lot going on in Hail, Caesar!, but in the end, it’s all a bit too silly to register as important.... Nonetheless, Hail, Caesar! satisfies that one criterion that matters most in Hollywood, and will for time immemorial: it’s entertaining as hell.

author: Ignatiy Vishnevetsky
summary: Somewhere in there are stretches of the Coens’ funniest comedy since "The Big Lebowski"; it just takes a little patience.

author: Marc Savlov
summary: It’s both more and less than the sum of its parts, but its never less than thoroughly watchable.

author: Nick Schager
summary: Identifying the method behind the Coens’ madness takes some work, as the film moves at such a rat-a-tat-tat screwball speed that following along often feels like clinging for dear life to the side of a speeding train.

author: Calvin Wilson
summary: Unfortunately, Hail, Caesar! comes across as far less than the sum of its parts.

author: Michael Phillips
summary: The tone of "Hail, Caesar!" is even and assured, yet the comic inspiration is sporadic.

author: Stephanie Zacharek
summary: Hail, Caesar! doesn’t completely hang together. But Johansson in a mermaid’s tail? Really, why else make movies—or go to them?

author: Bill Goodykoontz
summary: While individually some of the scenes are terrific, they don't add up to much, making Hail, Caesar! one of the Coens' lesser comedies, better than "Intolerable Cruelty," say, but nowhere near the genius of "The Big Lewbowski."

author: Tim Robey
summary: Hail, Caesar! keeps stumbling over its own best ideas as we stop to appreciate them – ditching momentum, preferring gaps for applause.

author: David Edelstein
summary: Their amalgamations can be feats of genius, like their stoner-gumshoe farrago "The Big Lebowski." Or they can pretty much lie there, like much of their new, star-packed comedy, Hail, Caesar!, which is nothing but movie fodder.

author: Lawrence Toppman
summary: The Coen brothers’ new movie, set in Hollywood in 1951, brings easy laughs but dissipates from memory moments later, like the cheesy films to which it pays homage – or, perhaps, mocks.

author: Rene Rodriguez
summary: The Coens feel out of step this time; they’ve lost their rhythm the way they did in The Hudsucker Proxy, where the style consumed the entire picture, turning what should have been humorous and snappy into a grating chore.

author: Steve Persall
summary: Hail, Caesar! is maddeningly hit-and-miss.

author: Todd McCarthy
summary: There is amusement to be had, engaging actors to admire and beautiful craftsmanship to behold, but the entertainment quotient is below their usual standard when it comes to the films they target for a mass audience, of which this is one.

author: Roger Moore
summary: When the Coen Brothers miss, they miss with gusto. Images of Babe Ruth, swinging and collapsing in a heap from the effort come to mind.

author: Melissa Anderson
summary: The brothers' latest also has a certain buoyancy...The fizziness, though, proves fleeting, and Hail, Caesar! too often goes flat.

author: John Anderson
summary: A dispiritingly vitriolic, only sporadically funny satire of ’50s Hollywood, Hail, Caesar! verifies a suspicion long held here, that the Coen brothers, Joel and Ethan, really hate the movies.

author: Kate Taylor
summary: In short, there are an awful lot of subplots and comic characters but none of the actors in this star-studded cast is allowed to build his laughs and the Coens just abandon several of these vivid personalities along the way.

author: Gersh Kuntzman
summary: Did you like “Zoolander”? Good, then you’ll like Zoolander 2.

author: Glenn Kenny
summary: It then becomes very funny, funny enough that my wife observed that she thought I was going to have a stroke, as I was laughing so much.

author: Mick LaSalle
summary: Sometimes unapologetically stupid and joyously crass, it’s often brilliant in its absurdity, one of those rare comedies where the audience sits there dumbstruck, wondering what crazy thing will happen next. It takes really smart people to make a movie this silly.

author: Jesse Hassenger
summary: It’s a bizarre and pointless spectacle, but not an unamusing one. Characters like Alexanya and Atari feel very much like try-outs for Saturday Night Live characters — not surprising, given that at least four of the cast members have worked on that show.

author: Peter Travers
summary: Zoolander 2 sweats its silly ass off to please. The results are scattershot. But when it works — oh, baby. There's a bit with Justin Bieber and a selfie that, well, no spoilers.

author: Olly Richards
summary: It’s fun to take another turn with Derek and Hansel, but they probably don’t have another season in them.

author: James Mottram
summary: More Blue Steel than Magnum, this is a perfectly serviceable sequel, but dogged by repetition, it lacks the original's speed and sizzle.

author: Helen O'Hara
summary: It’s fun to see Zoolander once more. It seems unlikely that the premise could ever sustain a third film, but if this is Derek’s swan song then he leaves amid a flurry of feathers and bustle – surely all a male model could wish for.

author: Peter Bradshaw
summary: There are always some laughs to be had here, and Ben Stiller’s couture legend now has an endearingly muppety look.

author: James Berardinelli
summary: Zoolander would have been better left as a stand-alone cult classic.

author: Moira Macdonald
summary: A mostly agreeable but empty-headed mess. It’s sort of the movie equivalent of Derek Zoolander himself.

author: Molly Eichel
summary: For every laugh that Zoolander 2 elicits, there's a pang that all this was funnier the first time around.

author: Tasha Robinson
summary: Where the first film was content with straight-faced silliness, Zoolander 2 tries to blow the same silliness out to epic, world-spanning proportions, and it just winds up feeling overstretched. Like Stiller with his ridiculous characters and stylized performances, it's consistently trying way too hard.

author: Daniel Schindel
summary: Hits a decent count of guffaws and chortles, enough to make for a solid rental or something you settle on while channel surfing on an idle afternoon.

author: Rodrigo Perez
summary: Zoolander 2 is no disaster, but it’s almost worse; a tedious jag that barely works as a disposable and mild, if-its-on-cable-TV, diversion.

author: Chris Nashawaty
summary: Zoolander No. 2 is embarrassing, lazy, and aggressively unfunny. The only good news is that at the pace the franchise is moving, we won’t get Zoolander 3 until 2030.

author: Kenneth Turan
summary: Zoolander 2 defines haphazard. You may smile at times, but not as often as you'd like.

author: Barbara VanDenburgh
summary: It’s a stumble down the catwalk not even Blue Steel can save.

author: Tim Grierson
summary: The stakes are higher, the action is bigger, the ambitions are grander, the jokes are appreciably less funny. Like many comedy sequels, Zoolander 2 supersizes everything in such a way that it’s that much more apparent how few of the jokes are connecting.

author: David Rooney
summary: Sure, it's a kick to see Stiller and Wilson back in the shoes of these camera-ready cretins, but for every joke that sparks there are several that just lay there.

author: Barry Hertz
summary: Zoolander 2 feels like a hasty collection of last-minute comedy panic attacks.

author: Richard Roeper
summary: Stiller the director does a fine job of making Zoolander 2 look like an actual spy movie, but we’ve seen far better takeoffs, including “Spy” and “Kingsman: The Secret Service” in just the last couple of years. As for the jabs at the transient nature of popular culture and the ridiculousness of high fashion world — easy, tired targets.

author: Brian Truitt
summary: Moviegoers may wish that Will Ferrell's megalomaniacal supervillain Mugatu had won in the first Zoolander and saved us from another film with these boneheads.

author: Ty Burr
summary: This needless sequel amps the silliness to DEFCON-4 levels of frantic surrealism and overstuffs the running time with famous faces. It’s a pop quiz instead of a movie, and it’ll be dated by tomorrow morning.

author: Roger Moore
summary: A “high concept comedy” from the days when those were a thing, it’s basically a cacophony of cameos and random sight gags hurled at the viewer in a tsunami of haute couture hype.

author: Anthony Lane
summary: The first film scored a few palpable hits, but the new one barely makes the effort.

author: Stephen Holden
summary: Zoolander 2 has enough plots for several movies. They are so jammed together that they more or less cancel each other out.

author: Melissa Anderson
summary: Wiig's cheering presence in an otherwise depleting project/cross-promoted product highlights the fact that Zoolander 2 is a referendum on dying industries: not just the portfolio of Condé Nast titles that Wintour oversees as artistic director, but also the Frat Pack.

author: Matt Singer
summary: If Zoolander 2 was a party, the guest list alone would make it the greatest ever thrown. But Zoolander 2 is not a party. It is a movie. A bad movie.

author: Steve Persall
summary: What truly becomes aggravating about Zoolander 2 is its dependence upon a parade of famous people doing supremely unfunny things.

author: Kyle Smith
summary: Stiller’s one good idea is turning things over to Will Ferrell, who does some amusingly demented things while haranguing Anna Wintour and Tommy Hilfiger and is probably funnier in his sleep than Stiller is at his best.

author: Jake Cole
summary: The film is frequently guilty of the same obsolescence it accuses the characters of embodying.

author: Drew McWeeny
summary: Brutally unfunny, visually off-putting, and filled with cameos so embarrassing I am bruised from holding a cringe for a full half-hour, Zoolander 2 is every horrible decision you can make with a comedy sequel wrapped up into one nigh unbearable film.

author: Alonso Duralde
summary: There are no build-ups or pay-offs here, just a lot of random moments of people saying stupid stuff, and fashion people being gently lampooned.

author: Steve Davis
summary: The movie is as lifeless as a mannequin until Ferrell appears near the end as the absurdly coiffed villain Jacobim Mugatu.

author: David Ehrlich
summary: There are any number of reasons why the vast majority of comedy sequels are borderline unwatchable, but there’s ultimately only one thing that the worst of them all share in common: They give the audience what they think they want, not what they don’t yet know they want.

author: Justin Chang
summary: The results may delight those who believe recycled gags and endless cameos to be the very essence of great screen comedy, but everyone else will likely recognize Stiller’s wannabe Magnum opus as a disappointment-slash-misfire, the orange mocha crappuccino of movie sequels.

author: Blake Goble
summary: Zoolander No. 2 invokes that old Simpsons headline: “old man yells at modern culture.”

author: David Edelstein
summary: How bad is Zoolander 2? It’s "Batman and Robin" bad. It’s so bad that it makes you feel sorry for the scores (literally) of celebrities who show up in cameos, even the ones (Anna Wintour, Tommy Hilfiger, Susan Sarandon, Ariana Grande, Kimye ...) who actively resist your sympathy, whom you maybe want to see taken down a peg.

author: Joe Morgenstern
summary: Some movies keep you in a state of suspense. Zoolander 2, a dud glitter-bomb of a sequel, eventually leaves you in a state of suspended animation, with eyes glazed over and brain in sleep mode.

author: Ann Hornaday
summary: Lazily written by Stiller and three collaborators (including Justin Theroux), this is the kind of lame, warmed-over movie that gives sequels a bad name. For “Zoolander” fans, however, it resembles a betrayal of public trust.

author: Marc Savlov
summary: Carter Burwell’s score is particularly thunderous, mirroring the onscreen action, and the 3-D really is – for once – superb, making for a rather breathtaking two hours. Well done.

author: Kate Taylor
summary: There’s nothing subtle about The Finest Hours, but much that is satisfying.

author: Rex Reed
summary: For the most part, this is a film with a pulse that wastes no time—a highly invigorating crowd pleaser that does nothing momentous but packs a big entertainment wallop doing it.

author: James Berardinelli
summary: One would be hard-pressed to consider The Perfect Storm “triumphant” or “uplifting” but both terms could be used to describe The Finest Hours.

author: Lawrence Toppman
summary: From the first gentle meeting of its hero and heroine to the last line of dialogue, The Finest Hours executes all the traditional moves beautifully.

author: Mick LaSalle
summary: What happens is important, but more important is how it happens and whom it happens to.

author: Michael Phillips
summary: The script embraces certain character archetypes wholeheartedly (pig-headed crew mate; ramrod-stiff officer) and not always successfully. Yet the tone, the mood of the picture, with its desaturated color palette, maintains the right atmosphere.

author: Roger Moore
summary: An adventure drama with sea legs, a story of heroism steeped in period detail, played with sympathy and stoicism by people who respect such old fashioned virtues.

author: Kenneth Turan
summary: This tale of nautical derring-do has several things going for it to counteract the inherent obviousness of the material. These include a director who knows his way around this kind of material, special effects work that makes the peril fearfully alive, and a pip of a true story of what is considered as daring a rescue mission as the U.S. Coast Guard ever attempted.

author: Matt Singer
summary: If The Finest Hours is light on surprises it’s still heavy on suspense, as the script by Scott Silver, Paul Tamasy, and Eric Johnson treats each new obstacle in Bernie and Ray’s paths as a new brainteasing puzzle with an impossible solution.

author: Blake Goble
summary: The Finest Hours is exactly that. Fine, while embracing its studio aesthetic and morally true heroism.

author: Nick Schager
summary: An old-fashioned tale of heroism in the face of insurmountable odds, The Finest Hours is never less than aggressively hokey and manipulatively sentimental — and, in the end, better off for it.

author: Lou Lumenick
summary: The true story behind a Coast Guard rescue depicted in Disney’s The Finest Hours is amazing enough that it didn’t require corny romantic embellishments that threaten to capsize everything.

author: Michael O'Sullivan
summary: Somewhere in here, there’s a pretty decent movie. The Finest Hours is probably the best of a bad bunch of recent releases. But it’s a shame that this terrific story’s engines keep flooding in the face of wave after wave of narrative inertia.

author: Ty Burr
summary: It’s a movie made for the kind of audiences who feel that movies aren’t made for them anymore — you know who you are. If you go, you might want to bring a raincoat.

author: Peter Travers
summary: On the waves, The Finest Hours finally finds its sea legs and delivers an old-school adventure based on a heroic deliverance that deserves its day in the sun.

author: Soren Andersen
summary: The storm effects are first-rate, immersive all the way. The tale-telling ability of director Craig Gillespie is frustratingly inconsistent.

author: Tasha Robinson
summary: This isn't just an action film; it's a multi-pronged assault on the heartstrings, with plenty of wide-eyed, apple-cheeked Norman Rockwell Americana saturating the pounding digital waves.

author: Stephanie Zacharek
summary: As Pine’s Webber navigates that seemingly helpless little boat, squinting into the driving snow and more than once nearly falling victim to the ocean’s mighty maw, he’s the movie’s finest special effect — not because he’s mindlessly brave, but because he lets us see how scared he is.

author: Alan Scherstuhl
summary: Just as Pine's Bernie Webber grits his teeth and pilots his 36-foot Coast Guard boat into seas that rise up like angry gods, Gillespie steers head-on into clichés, powering through. They never quite capsize his film, but it does take on some water.

author: Stephen Holden
summary: The Finest Hours is a moderately gripping whoosh of nostalgia that shamelessly recycles the ’50s cliché of the squeaky-clean all-American hero.

author: Stephen Whitty
summary: Despite some great effects, and one good performance, it never quite gets underway.

author: Mike Scott
summary: Drama is one thing. Resonance is another. Without digging deeply enough, "The Finest Hours" seems content to capture the former while ignoring the latter.

author: Peter Rainer
summary: It’s not just the technique of this movie that is resolutely old-fashioned. So are its attitudes. The film may feature practically wall-to-wall monster storms but undergirding it all is a cushion of straight-arrow sentimentalism. It harks back to a rosy neverland when men were men and women stood by them.

author: Jesse Hassenger
summary: As charming as the early scenes are, The Finest Hours doesn’t really come together as a love story, either, and Affleck’s scenes on the tanker are too abbreviated to really sink in as great survival drama.

author: Chris Nashawaty
summary: An intermittently affecting, sanded-edge adventure that feels as if it trundled off the studio production line back when Eisenhower was in office.

author: Peter Sobczynski
summary: For the most part, it is a solid film that bolsters its innately compelling narrative with effectively low-key performances, some genuinely thrilling sequences and only a few moments here and there that lean towards hokeyness.

author: Joe Morgenstern
summary: The drama is almost stillborn, thanks to a slow, deadly dull romantic preface, and it’s subverted by incessant switching between spectacular struggles on the Atlantic and generic anxieties on shore.

author: Randy Cordova
summary: The Finest Hours is set in the early '50s. But did it really need to feel like it was made during the Eisenhower era?

author: Brian Truitt
summary: The rescue drama The Finest Hours rocks the boat in terms of blizzard-blitzed sea thrills but leaves you cold with its side love story.

author: Steve Persall
summary: It's a story told accurately, if not particularly well.

author: Richard Roeper
summary: The Finest Hours feels stitched together. None of the three main plot lines is particularly powerful or moving.

author: Christopher Gray
summary: A square journey through choppy waters, it boasts a Greatest Generation nostalgia so thoroughgoing it might as well be called Boys Becoming Men.

author: John Hazelton
summary: The climactic rescue sequence has tension and some thrills, but it’s over fairly quickly and the film settles back into a sentimental lull

author: Andrew Barker
summary: Perhaps the worst one could say about Craig Gillespie’s film is that, rather than their finest hours, the whole cast and crew all put in a solid shift at the office making the movie, producing a perfectly entertaining, sometimes quite well-crafted disaster drama that nonetheless retreats from the memory almost as soon as the credits roll.

author: Sheri Linden
summary: At the helm of this ultra-earnest entertainment, with its expository dialogue and meticulous visuals, Craig Gillespie isn’t able to conjure a stirring cinematic experience. The pieces don’t fuse so much as fit together, and much of the action feels instructive rather than immersive.

author: Alonso Duralde
summary: This is the sort of film in which we’re told that a certain action is impossible, until it isn’t, or that a certain thing would never happen, and then it does, so even with all those lives on the line, the movie can’t effectively build up stakes or consequences.

author: Jose Solís
summary: While the rescue scenes are exceptionally shot, and the visual effects are quite remarkable, the predictable plot, and its tonal inconsistencies, make The Finest Hours feel like an endless cruise.

author: Ian Freer
summary: A strong cast and impressive action sequences can’t find subtleties or surprises to enliven a rote period disaster movie. It hits the right points, but mechanically.

author: Steven Rea
summary: And Bridges? What's there to say about a man who makes it look so easy, and who - in one breathless, pivotal scene - runs through a range of emotion like a wild pony running across the land. Genius, any way you look at it.

author: Joe Morgenstern
summary: By turns funny, elegiac and thrilling, it’s a tale of brotherhood and family that takes in the harsh beauty of the land, the elusive nature of right and wrong and the quirky delights of human connections in a time of bewildering change.

author: Calvin Wilson
summary: The year’s most exhilarating film.

author: Steve Persall
summary: Hell or High Water is a terrific piece of entertainment.... It isn't a highbrow indie but a gritty work of art. Mackenzie's movie thrills for all the right reasons and will be fondly remembered at year's end.

author: Jeannette Catsoulis
summary: Furnished with faces as beaten as the vehicles the brothers drive and discard, Hell or High Water is a chase movie disguised as a western. Its humor is as dry as prairie dust...and its morals are steadfastly gray.

author: Walter Addiego
summary: What Mackenzie has crafted here is a crowd-pleaser with undeniable art-house elements.

author: David Edelstein
summary: This is the kind of Western in which we know there will be blood but pray there won’t be, because the violence is bound to be gratuitous, absurd, with a needless finality. Hell or High Water is a rare humanist Western: Finality is the true villain.

author: Chris Nashawaty
summary: Hell or High Water isn’t a flashy movie, but it has an undeniably resonant sense of small-scale justice, not to mention an authentic sense of place that will remind you of other Texas-set masterpieces like John Sayles’ "Lone Star" and the Coen brothers’ "No Country for Old Men." See it, and then spread the word.

author: Richard Roeper
summary: With electrifying, graceful direction by David Mackenzie...a rich, darkly humorous and deeply insightful screenplay by Taylor Sheridan...and no fewer than four performances as good as anything I’ve seen onscreen this year, Hell or High Water is an instant classic modern-day Western, traveling down familiar roads but always, always with a fresh and original spin.

author: Bill Goodykoontz
summary: Foster was born to this kind of role, rugged but soulful, and he’s outstanding. The surprise is Pine, giving by far his best performance.

author: Owen Gleiberman
summary: Hell or High Water is a thrillingly good movie — a crackerjack drama of crime, fear, and brotherly love set in a sun-roasted, deceptively sleepy West Texas that feels completely exotic for being so authentic.

author: Peter Rainer
summary: A lean, efficient modern Western that is so satisfyingly constructed I’m tempted to say it’s just about perfect. There’s a special pleasure in watching a movie that knows exactly what it’s after and then, in scene after scene, gets it.

author: A.A. Dowd
summary: Hell Or High Water is the kind of movie that makes you fall in love again with the lost art of dialogue, getting you hooked anew on the snap of flavorful conversation.

author: Bernard Boo
summary: Pulpy, old-fashioned Western action and terrific performances make Hell or High Water one of the most satisfying releases of the summer.

author: Stephanie Zacharek
summary: Bridges knows just what he’s doing, and with the splendid West Texas waltz of a drama, Hell or High Water, British director David Mackenzie has given him the perfect hook on which to hang his hat.

author: Robert Abele
summary: Hell or High Water is that rare offering that both feels old-fashioned in its action-thriller gratification and in-the-moment about everything else.

author: Glenn Whipp
summary: That Hell or High Water makes you empathize with and understand (though not excuse) each member of this disparate quartet is a tribute to the way Taylor Sheridan’s screenplay works equally well as a thriller, character study and pointed social commentary.

author: Danny King
summary: When the movie just sits with the characters on front porches or in backyards, Mackenzie's generous, hands-off approach with his actors — most of the conversation scenes play out in long takes with minimal camera movement — yields poignant rewards.

author: James Berardinelli
summary: From a purely narrative perspective, there’s nothing new here but like a new arrangement of a familiar tune, the slight changes make it fresh and enjoyable.

author: Brad Wheeler
summary: Scenic, well-paced and rich in dialogue and character, the film is Coen brothers for the squares, and maybe the best middle-of-the-seat drama of the summer.

author: Rene Rodriguez
summary: It’s ABOUT something, which has become a rarity in Hollywood pictures. Sometimes, the smallest stories cast the largest shadows.

author: Tasha Robinson
summary: For all the methodical pacing and old archetypes, Hell or High Water is a thoroughly contemporary action film, complete with fast chases and flashes of dark comedy. But like the classic Westerns, it invites viewers to evaluate, one more time, the myth of the American outlaw, and the idea of criminals as heroes.

author: Peter Travers
summary: Chris Pine proves he can act. Ben Foster, well, he always could. And Jeff Bridges shows them both how it's done. Those are just three riveting reasons to pony up for Hell or High Water.

author: Ann Hornaday
summary: In a word, Hell or High Water is terrific.

author: Ty Burr
summary: The dialogue is terse and funny while hinting at much larger matters, such as the way poverty can be handed from generation to generation like a bad gene or a disease.

author: Michael Phillips
summary: What the movie has, above all, is a dramatic line, clean and straight. In its faces, its scenery and its plain satisfactions it makes us feel like we've been somewhere, when we get to the end of that line.

author: Moira Macdonald
summary: In this bleak West Texas landscape where everyone seems to be struggling, you find yourself rooting, inexplicably, for all of them against a clear villain: the faceless, predatory bank.

author: Roger Moore
summary: A terrific heist picture.

author: Randall Colburn
summary: A rich, complex drama that’s as much about consequence and justification as it is destiny.

author: Eric Kohn
summary: Grounded in lively performances by Chris Pine and Ben Foster as a pair of bank-robbing brothers, with a capable assist from a no-nonsense Jeff Bridges as the sheriff on their tail, Hell or High Water tries nothing new but delivers a fun ride.

author: Kevin Harley
summary: Mackenzie goes western in satisfying style, while Bridges, Pine and Foster bring true grit to Sheridan’s tight script.

author: Jimi Famurewa
summary: Taut, tense and burnished by Jeff Bridges at his best. This is a deceptively simple tale of Texan cops and robbers that drags the Old West into the modern age.

author: Matt Singer
summary: The surprise standout is Chris Pine. Maybe because he possesses unfairly good looks and outrageous charisma, Pine hasn’t received much recognition as an actor. He is outstanding in Hell or High Water.

author: Stephen Whitty
summary: The terrific Hell or High Water is like a gritty new retelling of the Frank and Jesse James story — only with getaway cars instead of horses, and assault rifles replacing six-shooters.

author: David Rooney
summary: As much as all four men are familiar types, the director, writer and actors imbue them with humanity, steering their arcs through tense action — including a nice throwback Western shootout on rocky terrain — to a quietly moving conclusion.

author: Charles Gant
summary: The film’s ace card is its intertwining of not one but two mismatched buddy relationships.

author: John Bleasdale
summary: Despite treading some familiar territory, British director David Mackenzie's new film Hell or High Water proves itself a brilliantly executed, sharply written genre gem.

author: Peter Bradshaw
summary: It’s an action-thriller with punch; Bridges gives the characterisation ballast and heft and Pine and Foster bring a new, grizzled maturity to their performances.

author: Tim Robey
summary: It has a straight-down-the-highway momentum, interesting stakes, and more textured character work than you can shake a stick at.

author: Marjorie Baumgarten
summary: Hell or High Water is a good but not great movie with sensational lead performances that elevate it to enjoyably memorable status.

author: Kyle Smith
summary: A desperado drama wrapped around a Bernie Sanders campaign speech, Hell or High Water overcomes its vapid political leanings with loads of West Texas atmosphere, smart dialogue and acutely observed relationships.

author: Amy Nicholson
summary: This solid genre pic salutes its touchstones.

author: Rory O'Connor
summary: David McKenzie’s Hell or High Water is a gritty, darkly humorous, and fiendishly violent neo-western.

author: Nikola Grozdanovic
summary: Hell or High Water might walk over familiar ground with second-hand boots in terms of character development and structural beats, but it does so with great personality and zero pretension of wanting to be anything more.

author: Peter Sobczynski
summary: While moviegoers desperate to see anything that doesn’t involve a superhero may be willing to overlook its shortcomings, others will undoubtedly be disappointed to find that it's somewhat less than the sum of its parts.

author: Jake Cole
summary: As with Sicario, the broad strokes of the film's Southwestern stereotypes gradually sharpen into focus as the story pivots to a look at the systemic forces that shape the characters.

author: Tom Huddleston
summary: A film with a fistful of memorable moments—most of them involving Bridges hurling insults at people—but not a great deal new to say.

author: Glenn Kenny
summary: I’m not qualified to say whether it’s an effective delivery system for its Christian message, but I think I can credibly pronounce it a good popcorn movie.

author: Jason Ooi
summary: In spite of its various imperfections, Ben-Hur always manages to entertain, proving the timelessness of epic structure and scale. And even if nothing about the movie particularly stands out on its own, when all the pieces come together, one cannot help but feel immersed in the world and ideals presented.

author: Ignatiy Vishnevetsky
summary: The Wyler film’s rousing chariot sequence—filmed separately and at lavish expense by Andrew Marton and Yakima Canutt, one of the greatest stuntmen who ever lived — is hard to beat. But Bekmambetov acquits himself nicely, offering up a loud and vicious circular chase, with point-of-view shots of people getting hit by chariots as armored Romans scamper around like rodeo clowns.

author: Michael Nordine
summary: In paring down and streamlining its source material, this new version also saps its heft.

author: Jordan Hoffman
summary: Surprisingly, many of Bekmambetov’s updates work well.

author: Blake Goble
summary: This Ben-Hur is closer to an ‘80s actioner about two men who once loved each other parting ways, only to reunite and settle their differences through vicious means.

author: Steve Persall
summary: Let's cut to the chariot chase. The latest screen version of Ben-Hur would be little more than a condensed miniseries without it, framed for small television screens, with performances to fit.

author: James Berardinelli
summary: An amateurish effort that boasts direct-to-video characteristics, the latest version disappoints in almost every production aspect.

author: Tirdad Derakhshani
summary: The new Ben-Hur isn't much of an improvement. Dominated by CGI effects, it's a soap opera better fit for basic cable.

author: Roger Moore
summary: Everyone, from director to cast, seems so rushed that there’s no time for romance, less time for leaps of faith and every moment of conversion is abrupt, dictated by the script and not by the heart.

author: Mark Feeney
summary: That Morgan Freeman voice! It’s so rich and full and authoritative that even when he’s telling Judah, “OK, OK,” you almost believe people used that word in the year 33. If they were very progressive.

author: Michael Phillips
summary: The leading actors labor valiantly and to little effect.

author: Richard Roeper
summary: Ben-Hur struggles to find an identity and never really gets there. The well-intentioned efforts to achieve moving, faith-based awakenings are undercut by the casually violent, PG-13 action sequences.

author: Joe McGovern
summary: This arena, unfortunately, is no Thunderdome. The chariot race is sloppily framed, choppily edited, and droopily choreographed, with special effects that look like they needed another few passes through the CGI machine.

author: Stephen Whitty
summary: All the flash and sizzle of modern movie effects can't make up for a once spectacular tale that feels not just scaled-down, but shrunk.

author: Tim Grierson
summary: Timur Bekmambetov’s Ben-Hur remake offers robust spectacle and some decent performances. But ultimately, the director of Wanted and Abraham Lincoln: Vampire Hunter is, perhaps unsurprisingly, not the ideal filmmaker to capture this timeless story’s more nuanced emotional range.

author: Peter Rainer
summary: As Judah Ben-Hur – full names, please – Huston is serviceable, but he’s a finer actor than this costumed kitsch allow him to be. As Judah’s boyhood best friend and adoptive brother, Messala, against whom Judah will eventually square off in the Roman Circus, Toby Kebbell has even less to work with than Huston, and he bears a disconcerting resemblance to motivational guru Tony Robbins.

author: David Ehrlich
summary: The good news is that the story of Ben-Hur is so rock solid that not even the director of “Abraham Lincoln: Vampire Hunter” can screw it up completely.

author: Kevin Harley
summary: Wanted director Timur Bekmambetov stresses spectacle over subtext – and, effectively, leaves the cast floundering fast.

author: Joshua Rothkopf
summary: Taking the worst of it on the chin is star Jack Huston, whose Jewish prince turned galley slave, Judah Ben-Hur, suffers from a distinct lack of personality—he’s like a boulder that someone forgot to chisel into a statue.

author: Stephen Holden
summary: Overseen by a director not known for his human touch and lacking a name star, except for Mr. Freeman, Ben-Hur feels like a film made on the cheap, although it looks costly.

author: Kenneth Turan
summary: As directed by Timur Bekmambetov, this 21st century Ben-Hur is more phlegmatic than awful, a by and large dull and lethargic piece of work that is not bad enough to get mad at. What it lacks most of all is a convincing reason to exist.

author: Jonathan Pile
summary: It’s an adequate retelling, mostly, but with moments of eye-rolling ineptitude.

author: Owen Gleiberman
summary: Minus a hero who has the macho charisma to wrap a movie around him like he owned it, the new Ben-Hur is an oddly lackluster affair: sludgy and plodding, photographed (by Oliver Wood) in nondescript medium close-up, an epic that feels like a mini-series served up in bits and pieces.

author: Soren Andersen
summary: Cheap and cheesy at every level, this Ben-Hur barely qualifies as an epic. It’s a wholly unnecessary addition to the venerable franchise.

author: Michael O'Sullivan
summary: Bekmambetov and Co. have created a redesigned product that is at once inferior to the original and a slavish imitation.

author: Robert Abele
summary: This Ben-Hur may not be an epic fail, but its steady stream of shortcomings are certainly a cautionary journey for anybody with the hubris to try and rebuild the monuments of movies past.

author: Kimberley Jones
summary: It’s not the unmitigated disaster early reviews suggested. Instead, it is a blandly competent and doggedly uninspired redo of material adapted a half-dozen times already.

author: Todd McCarthy
summary: Misguided, diminished and dismally done in every way, this late-summer afterthought will richly earn the distinction of becoming the first Ben-Hur in any form to flop.

author: Peter Travers
summary: The last of the summer's movie epics is a digitalized eyesore hobbled in every department by staggering incompetence.

author: Mick LaSalle
summary: The problem comes down to this: If you take the spirituality out of Ben-Hur, you take the Ben-Hur out of Ben-Hur.

author: Kate Taylor
summary: As the new Ben-Hur unspools into insignificance and sentimentality, there are fleeting moments that suggest someone behind this $100-million movie was actually thinking hard about how to replay a schlocky biblical epic for a secular audience in 2016.

author: Keith Watson
summary: Ben-Hur director Timur Bekmambetov offers nothing new to the cinematic lexicon of the chariot race.

author: Lou Lumenick
summary: There’s a fatally miscast lead (Jack Huston, you are no Charlton Heston), cut-rate special effects, reams of eyeball-glazing dialogue, and a schmaltzy “inspirational” script that pointlessly alters the story in ways that make absolutely no sense.

author: Serena Donadoni
summary: As much as this latest installment draws on affection for the snappy first film, it's the differences that make Bridget Jones's Baby the warmest and most satisfying of the series.

author: Kevin P. Sullivan
summary: The script contains some genuinely uproarious laughs and is sharper than it needs to be, even if some of the jokes feel as old as Bridget’s condoms.

author: Randy Cordova
summary: The film could merely coast on the charms of its three stars, but it's smarter and brighter than you'd expect.

author: Katie Walsh
summary: Zellweger plays Bridget just as charmingly as she always has -- flawed but endearing; just right in her own idiosyncratic way.

author: Cath Clarke
summary: I’ve never liked Renée Zellweger more as a warmer and wiser Bridget Jones – but still capable of making a total prat of herself.

author: Jane Crowther
summary: A warm, witty and welcome return – intelligently evolved and an absolute hoot. As Bridget would say: ‘v.good’.

author: Terri White
summary: Though the story occasionally stretches credibility, the warmth and wit so reminiscent of the original Bridget Jones's Diary propels you along, being due in large part to the return of one woman: director Sharon Maguire. You feel her filthy, funny thumbprints pressed on almost every scene.

author: Julia Cooper
summary: So despite the conventionalism of the film’s final minutes, I’d like to raise a glass of Chardonnay and toast Bridget Jones’s Baby on its (mostly) hilarious, and long-anticipated, homecoming.

author: Molly Eichel
summary: The movie's greatest misstep - other than Dempsey's boring romantic foil - is that, at one point, Bridget flashes back to events from the first movie. It's a reminder of how much fun the first film was, and it'll make you want to run out and watch that rather than the finish the one you bought a ticket for.

author: James Berardinelli
summary: Bridget Jones’s Baby exceeds expectations and, as a result, makes us willing to forgive the delay in bringing the character back to theaters.

author: Brian Truitt
summary: While it unabashedly leans into its chick-flick nature, returning director Sharon Maguire — who helmed 2001’s franchise-starter "Bridget Jones’s Diary" — manages to craft the strongest and funniest film of the series.

author: Peter Travers
summary: Sounds godawful in title and concept — but which in execution is a fizzy delight.

author: Susan Wloszczyna
summary: There is a welcome sense of familiarity in Bridget Jones's Baby — but also of the fresh and au courant.

author: Stephanie Hayes
summary: There's a funny, healthy element of slapstick at play, as with all Bridget movies. A doctor played dryly by Emma Thompson is a biting, welcome addition.

author: Moira Macdonald
summary: The whole endeavor is so relentlessly lovable, like Bridget herself, that I defy anyone to not enjoy themselves.

author: Jason Solomons
summary: She’s a woman gamely surviving the pitfalls and pratfalls of her own desperation and insecurities, and Zellweger creates a hugely sympathetic character.

author: David Edelstein
summary: Although it’s patchy and gives off an air of trying too hard, the movie is surprisingly funny.

author: Robert Yaniz Jr.
summary: Bridget Jones’s Baby effortlessly reminds audiences why this character and her world were so compelling in the original film.

author: Ariel Scotti
summary: This somewhat predictable and trend-obsessed comedy about what happens when a woman of a certain age ends up expecting, and unsure of the parentage, is pregnant with comedy gold.

author: Allison Shoemaker
summary: The most surprising thing about Bridget Jones’s Baby has nothing to do with the perennial singleton’s offspring or the tropes of romantic comedies. What’s surprising is that, despite all the contrivances and stale conventions, this movie’s not half bad, and occasionally better than that.

author: Kimberley Jones
summary: Is this latest outing as bold or bracing or funny as the original film? Certainly not. We’re well settled into our seats now, but there’s some comfort in how the cushion already knows a body’s grooves.

author: Will Ashton
summary: Bridget Jones’s Baby is not a game-changer, but that’s not what it sets out to be. It’s a goodnatured, accessible, persistently endearing matinee, and sometimes it’s nice to be won over by simple sincerity and commercial likeability.

author: Sara Stewart
summary: On one hand, third installment is series of hilarious meditations on trials of being middle-aged woman, co-written by feminist goddess Emma Thompson, who gives self all best lines as deadpan OB-GYN.

author: Roger Moore
summary: Zellweger shows flashes of her Oscar winning talent and is certainly not past her sell-by date, even if she’s tampered entirely too much with the packaging.

author: Mike Scott
summary: Delivers a rare perfect ending to a perfectly likeable trilogy.

author: Peter Bradshaw
summary: What sealed the deal for me – by a whisker – was the gigantic physical comedy that Dempsey, Zellweger and Firth uncorked as they try to get through the hospital revolving door as Bridget is about to give birth, the traditional romcom rush to the airport having been re-invented for this maternal drama.

author: Tim Robey
summary: It's a comeback you root for, then, even while it’s wobbling and occasionally falling in the mud. But goodwill gets it home.

author: Fionnuala Halligan
summary: In its own deja vu way, Bridget Jones Baby is intermittently entertaining, mainly thanks to Zellweger’s performance.

author: Catherine Bray
summary: Despite Zellweger’s appealingly warm, vulnerable performance, the film itself is a mixed bag.

author: Conor O'Donnell
summary: In spite of its slightly excessive runtime and a handful of millennial-pandering beats, Bridget Jones’s Baby is brought to term by the buckets of undeniable charm and charisma present in its performances.

author: Jesse Hassenger
summary: In other words, 12 years have elapsed since the last Bridget Jones movie. A skinnier, more put-together Bridget isn’t necessarily a more interesting character; she’s a little more "Sex And The City" this time out, however incrementally.

author: Ann Hornaday
summary: Even considering its optimistic, open-ended conclusion, Bridget Jones’s Baby feels like an affectionate, slightly overdue goodbye to characters whose time has inevitably passed.

author: Joe Morgenstern
summary: Of all the performances in a patchy production, only one achieves perfection. We get to see it through the modern medical miracle of ultrasound.

author: Walter Addiego
summary: The film is sprinkled with “f” bombs, which fails to disguise that the enterprise is based on a surprisingly dated notion of what’s racy. Also, you simply may not find Bridget quite as adorable as the filmmaker’s clearly believe her to be.

author: Stephen Holden
summary: Despite an abundance of mostly tepid jokes that keeps the comedic tone at a quiet simmer, Bridget Jones’s Baby doesn’t jell. Ms. Zellweger floats through the picture, charming but strangely detached from her suitors.

author: Demetrios Matheou
summary: Once again excelling, Zellweger has much to do with the safe transition of this new Bridget, maintaining all the old quirks and sweetness, but in a believably more mature shell.

author: Leslie Felperin
summary: There are crisply folded lines, and pleasingly peppery performances from the supporting cast especially, but where its beating heart should be there is a splinter of ice, the sense that no one involved is really doing this for that much love.

author: Dana Stevens
summary: Still, the movie’s mores can feel cluelessly retro as the ever-dithering Bridget lurches between one man and another.

author: Ty Burr
summary: “Baby” is to Helen Fielding’s original 1996 novel and its 2001 movie adaptation what “Sex and the City 2” was to the HBO series — a cause not for celebration but overdue burial.

author: Richard Roeper
summary: From start to finish, this film seems strangely out of touch, never more so than when it tries to come across as enlightened.

author: Eric Henderson
summary: The Pinkberry solipsism of this particular franchise all but requires our heroine persist as a lovelorn martyr for her audience’s benefit.

author: Anthony Lane
summary: Maguire has the nerve to give her heroine a big speech on the “integrity” of proper journalism — this after Bridget Jones’s Baby has made fun of foreigners’ names, and arranged for her to put the wrong Asian guest in front of the cameras. (Do all Asians look alike to her? Is that the joke?) So reliably does she embarrass herself at every public event that the film, trudging by on automatic, becomes an embarrassment, too.

author: Alonso Duralde
summary: The acting is universally excellent, particularly Fey, who’s shrewdly fulfilling our expectations while playing off them.

author: Stephanie Zacharek
summary: Boldly entertaining.

author: Joshua Rothkopf
summary: Robustly entertaining.

author: Jordan Hoffman
summary: Ficara and Requa have an irreverent streak, one that even might strike some as a little flippant against the gravity of the war.

author: Richard Roeper
summary: Fey is such a likable and funny screen presence, but she’s no lightweight when it comes to playing subtle, honest drama.

author: Molly Eichel
summary: Whiskey Tango Foxtrot isn't a great movie, but it is something rare and important: a woman's story of self-discovery - having nothing to do with her finding a husband - that has gotten room on the big screen.

author: Kyle Smith
summary: There aren’t enough movies in which Tina Fey fires an AK-47 while grinning maniacally. Whiskey Tango Foxtrot turns out to make excellent use of her established skills while revealing new ones: It’s “30 Rock Me to the Casbah.”

author: Rex Reed
summary: I found it flawed but fascinating, and a no-fail showcase for Tina Fey’s real talents as a serious actress. Best of all, this movie is never boring for a single minute.

author: Mick LaSalle
summary: Margot Robbie plays Tanya, Kim’s best friend and professional rival, and it’s a real asset to have someone with that kind of a star wattage in a supporting role.

author: Elise Nakhnikian
summary: Its feminist perspective checkmates the frat-boy misogyny and machismo that too often mar films set in combat zones.

author: Steve Persall
summary: Certainly this could've been a bolder, angrier movie than what it became. After so much grimness in movies about U.S. military actions in the Middle East, it's good finding one dedicated to the kind of humor getting a lot of folks through over there.

author: Brian Truitt
summary: Even with the occasional misfire in the plot, Fey’s strong performance throughout the film lets Whiskey go down in smooth and satisfying fashion.

author: Peter Travers
summary: There's a lot going on here. Maybe too much. The filmmakers can't draw coherence out of chaos. But Fey does.

author: Roger Moore
summary: Tina Fey gives her finest, funniest big screen performance by essentially doing in Whiskey Tango Foxtrot what she did so well on TV’s “30 Rock.”

author: Tasha Robinson
summary: It's a frequently funny film that comes packed with the thrills of real combat, with real consequences for the characters. But the basic premise does make one question its priorities.

author: Andrew O'Hehir
summary: There’s a freshness and an unjaded quality to almost every scene that makes you want to keep watching.

author: Drew McWeeny
summary: Whiskey Tango Foxtrot is a film of modest pleasures, but what I liked about it, I liked a lot. I hope more filmmakers figure out how to write to Fey's strengths, because she's really engaging here.

author: Marjorie Baumgarten
summary: WTF is on the right track, even if it never pulls all the way in to the station.

author: Blake Goble
summary: Fey delivers the performance like the super-capable talent she is, with range and authenticity. She’s a character with a fully expressed arc, foibles and all. She’s the dramedy’s best weapon.

author: Leah Greenblatt
summary: What work better in the movie are mostly smaller moments: the jokes that land, the rapport between the reporters, and all the weirdly ordinary ways people manage to find a new normal, even in the most WTF circumstances.

author: James Berardinelli
summary: Whiskey Tango Foxtrot has surprisingly dull fangs.

author: Connie Ogle
summary: Fey is a good fit with the material, and her co-stars are all solid, including Billy Bob Thornton as a laconic general; Martin Freeman as a boozy, charming Scottish journalist; Alfred Molina as a local politician with a crush on Kim; and Christopher Abbott (Girls) as Kim’s fixer and translator (he tries to keep her out of trouble).

author: Ann Hornaday
summary: True to its title, as well as its flawed but sympathetic protagonist, Whiskey Tango Foxtrot is more confused than cynical or opportunistic. Its bewilderment is contagious, and ultimately endearing.

author: Susan Wloszczyna
summary: Is Whiskey Tango Foxtrot a horrible movie about a white outsider plopped in the middle of Afghanistan? No, that would be last year’s “Rock the Kasbah.” But neither does Whiskey Tango Foxtrot fulfill its assigned duty to provide evidence of Fey’s versatility.

author: Jimi Famurewa
summary: Comedy for grown-ups that sometimes struggles with its ambitious brief, but always remembers that the best laughs contain the odd shard of shrapnel.

author: Stephen Whitty
summary: It's tasty at times, but feels like a very special episode of "30 Rock." Halfway in, you're still expecting Kenneth the Page to show up.

author: Bill Goodykoontz
summary: Ficarra and Requa never quite strike a successful balance between comedy and drama, making the whole thing feel a bit off.

author: Britt Hayes
summary: For all its failings (of which there are many), Whiskey Tango Foxtrot is still a rather enjoyable and mostly pleasant viewing experience, the kind of movie that’s easy to watch and digest when taken at its glossy face value.

author: Richard Brody
summary: The filmmakers keep to the surface of the bluntly rowdy story while conveying apolitical layers of regret and exasperation, in wanly comic and affectingly melodramatic action alike.

author: Jesse Hassenger
summary: A movie like this doesn’t require 30 Rock’s joke density or silly streak, but it’s surprising that Fey and Carlock’s satirical eyes aren’t a little more alert.

author: Joe Morgenstern
summary: As for Ms. Fey, Whiskey Tango Foxtrot doesn’t serve her fully, but this is her best work yet on the feature screen.

author: David Edelstein
summary: It’s not so much bad as dismayingly bland. It’s WTF for all the wrong reasons.

author: Nicolas Rapold
summary: As written by the TV veteran Robert Carlock, Kim’s rise-and-fade arc is sympathetically rendered, with humor and the urgency of an underhand pitch.

author: Calvin Wilson
summary: There’s a sharp comedy to be made about America’s misadventures in Afghanistan. This isn’t it.

author: Michael Phillips
summary: While it's no disaster, it's oddly indistinct and uncertain.

author: Russ Fischer
summary: Fey's work is strong, yet it's difficult to squash the impression that this could be a more powerful movie, and an even more significant showcase for Tina Fey.

author: Soren Andersen
summary: Strange movie. And despite the presence of Tina Fey playing its lead character, a cable-TV reporter named Kim Baker, it’s not a funny one.

author: Tim Grierson
summary: It’s to Ficarra and Requa’s credit that they try to juggle romance and political commentary, daring to make a studio movie that doesn’t fall into cookie-cutter genre rules. But the overriding problem is that Whiskey doesn’t go far enough in its risk-taking, settling for a story that gets more predictable as it rolls along.

author: Michael Snydel
summary: Whiskey Tango Foxtrot is a galling, casually offensive, and deeply unsatisfying film.

author: Todd McCarthy
summary: As in their previous films (I Love You Phillip Morris; Crazy, Stupid, Love; Focus), directors Glenn Ficarra and John Requa enjoy just scattershot success in hitting their seriocomic targets, scoring from time to time with their more coarse and outlandish gambits but rarely inducing one to take what they're watching very seriously.

author: Simon Houpt
summary: The dialogue is sour, the politics problematic (Broadway veterans as Afghan locals? Why not?!), and the sentiments sometimes eye-rolling. Whiskey Tango Foxtrot, indeed.

author: Ty Burr
summary: The movie plays like a global-political farce made by people who’ve never left the Upper West Side.

author: Justin Chang
summary: Despite the script’s direct acknowledgment that it’s telling a “white-American-lady story,” the movie never quite shakes off a glib, incurious outsider’s perspective that can tilt into outright cluelessness, particularly where some of its more egregious casting choices are concerned.

author: Melissa Anderson
summary: The mild Islamophobia and highly questionable casting choices in the film call to mind other texting abbreviations, namely AYFKMWTS and GTFOOH. In the end, though, it's an armed-forces acronym dating back to World War II that best describes this dismal project: FUBAR.

author: Kate Taylor
summary: DeGeneres goes much further, though, maintaining a delicate balance between Dory’s optimistic personality and the hovering anxieties created by her imperfect memory.

author: Peter Hartlaub
summary: The sequel is filled with crowd-pleasing action, adventure and characters — sometimes too many characters. But it rises above its crowded narrative with an intense emotional core, taking a protagonist whose affliction had been played mostly for comedy, and exploring the emptiness and loneliness of her plight.

author: Owen Gleiberman
summary: It’s a film that spills over with laughs (most of them good, a few of them shticky) and tears (all of them earned), supporting characters who are meant to slay us (and mostly do) with their irascible sharp tongues, and dizzyingly extended flights of physical comedy.

author: Allison Shoemaker
summary: Pixar’s latest has all the sweet, ricochet-fast humor of the original, the same brilliant animation and rich color, the same winning performances (complete with a few new scene-stealers), and the same simple, staggering emotional intelligence of its predecessor.

author: A.O. Scott
summary: What “Dory” lacks in dazzling originality it more than makes up for in warmth, charm and good humor.

author: Tim Grierson
summary: Finding Dory is a supremely delightful sequel.
