summary: This is a boxing drama that scrappily battles for its recognition, determined to win you over at any cost.

author: Peter Debruge
summary: Teller is terrific, which should come as no surprise to “Whiplash” fans, though no less significant, the film represents a significant return for writer-director Ben Younger.

author: Brad Wheeler
summary: The soundtrack is effective and overt – from the badass rock blare of Billy Squire, Bad Company and AC/DC to the atmosphere compositions of the indie musician Julia Holter to the riveting nu-blues of Willis Earl Beal. The camera work is slick, too; tricky sound-editing notions are pulled off with aplomb.

author: Walter Addiego
summary: Teller’s work is the film’s soul, and he completely convinces us of Vinny’s affability, flaws and steely determination. The performance has intelligent touches, some of them comic — such as the hint that Vinny’s rehab battle is heroic but also a bit goofy. It’s the kind of thing that first-rate actors can pull off.

author: Michael Phillips
summary: Don't expect miracles. Not every biopic needs to reinvent the form. Sometimes it's enough to inhabit it, engagingly.

author: Ty Burr
summary: Teller is cornering a market on recklessness in the roles he chooses -- the energy from that demonic drum solo at the end of “Whiplash” seems to carry over into the ferocity with which Vinny pounds at life. He’s not very smart, he’s kind of a jerk, but he never, ever stops, and Bleed for This earns your respect for him.

author: Rex Reed
summary: Nothing much revelatory here, but what makes the movie a keeper is the energy of director Ben Younger (Boiler Room) and the charisma of Miles Teller, the sensational young actor from "Whiplash," who invests the role of a prizefighter with the same intensity he brought to the role of an obsessively driven drummer in that film.

author: Wendy Ide
summary: Rather than bring anything new to the genre, director Ben Younger settles for adding a distinctive bracing energy to the somewhat timeworn tropes.

author: Todd McCarthy
summary: Bleed for This is a gritty, pungently Rhode Island working class-set boxing drama that connects with most of its punches.

author: A.A. Dowd
summary: Bleed For This looks at Vinny Paz and sees only unshakable determination, and though there’s a certain queasy, even darkly comic thrill to seeing the man (courageously? foolishly?) bench press his injuries away, Teller can’t make much of a character out of nothing but raw conviction and a spectacularly crappy mustache.

author: Chris Nashawaty
summary: With the exception of maybe two scenes, you’ve seen everything in this movie before.

author: Jared Mobarak
summary: You won’t get the gravitas of Rocky, Raging Bull, or Creed, but you will get a character worthy of immortalization thanks to spirit and shenanigans.

author: Chris Willman
summary: Paz’s story is obviously a feel-good one, which somewhat hamstrings a writer-director who you can feel chafing against the constraints of fidelity to sheer uplift.

author: Peter Travers
summary: Younger jacks up the action in the last third, but the air goes out of a fight movie when you can see the next jab coming.

author: Matt Zoller Seitz
summary: The problem, though, is that we never get enough sense of Paz's interior life to judge this movie as anything other than a comeback story about a nice guy who got knocked out by the cosmos and hauled himself up.

author: Roger Moore
summary: Teller, who takes us from grins to grimaces with skill, and Eckhart, given his best role in years and his most likable performance ever, make Bleed for This worth the pain.

author: Jamie Graham
summary: Bleed for This is made with palpable commitment by all involved and there are scenes to jolt viewers out of their déjà vu.

author: Matthew Anderson
summary: [Miles Teller] does dogged, unerring determination very well and makes Younger's film an engaging rollercoaster ride.

author: Tim Robey
summary: Middleweight, non-intelligence-insulting fare right to the core, Bleed For This keeps you squarely in your seat, but barely once excites you enough to leap up out of it.

author: Bill Goodykoontz
summary: Yes, it’s a boxing comeback story. But the car accident makes it different, and Teller and Eckhart make it better than it ought to be.

author: Stephen Whitty
summary: The movie's no knockout, but at least it gives us one good performance, and one great one.

author: Tom Huddleston
summary: Overall, Bleed For This is difficult to dislike: the story may be hokey but it’s real, and so is the sentiment behind it.

author: Claudia Puig
summary: The boxing drama Bleed for This has a powerful story and a strong lead performance in its corner, but falls short of knockout status. Hampered by clichéd writing and stereotypical portrayals, this extraordinary true-life account feels run-of-the-mill.

author: Soren Andersen
summary: In the central role, Miles Teller is impressively bulked up, but there’s a flatness in his performance. It’s a dogged, rather than an inspired, portrayal. The best work is done by Aaron Eckhart, who plays Vinnie’s trainer, Kevin Rooney.

author: Stephanie Merry
summary: The halfhearted attempt to tweak the boxing-movie formula is a diversionary tactic. No amount of feints will change one fact: Bleed for This has no new moves.

author: Marjorie Baumgarten
summary: Despite its narrative familiarity, the film is suffused with such contagious enthusiasm, distinctive performances, and local color that it stands out nevertheless.

author: Michael Roffman
summary: Despite Pazienza’s own pitfalls and perils, the film never registers as anything more than a boilerplate boxing drama, which is a shame because the material is all there, it’s just hamstrung by a flimsy screenplay that refuses to let its characters exist on their own.

author: David Ehrlich
summary: Every original drop of Bleed for This is lost in a sea of cliché and convention, and Younger seems totally incapable of separating the singular verve of his protagonist from the hackneyed arc of his defining ordeal.

author: Mike Scott
summary: Along the way, Bleed for This rarely, if ever, surprises. Younger -- working from a script he wrote -- never feints, never dodges, never does anything unexpected. Consequently, his film never delivers anything resembling a knockout blow.

author: Henry Barnes
summary: For all its smashed open cuts and swollen eye sockets, Younger’s film remains an oddly sterile experience. For a biopic, it is remarkably featureless.

author: Kenji Fujishima
summary: Any initial gestures toward acknowledging Vinny Paz's macho egotism are eventually downplayed as the film becomes just another formulaic triumph-over-adversity saga.

author: Soren Andersen
summary: The acting in all roles is first rate, but in this one De Niro regains the title of undisputed champion.

author: Richard Roeper
summary: Writer-director Jonathan Jakubowicz’s Hands of Stone is a rousing, well-filmed and solid (if at times overly generous to Duran) biopic with a bounty of charismatic performances, two of the sexier scenes of the year, some welcome laughs and a few above average fight sequences.

author: Peter Travers
summary: The Venezuelan-born writer-director Jonathan Jakubowicz (Secuestro Express) knows how to muscle up momentum and bring the best out of actors.

author: Calvin Wilson
summary: Isn’t a knockout of a film, but it’s light on its feet and throws a lot of good punches.

author: Roger Moore
summary: Hands of Stone is still a first-rate boxing picture, a B-movie with just enough A-picture touches to make it sting.

author: Joe Dziemianowicz
summary: Ana de Armas makes a lasting impression as Felicidad, the angelic girl (her hair is braided, like a halo) who’s the love of Duran’s life. Too bad their relationship is underexplored and left to a quickie montage of baby-making and deliveries. That’s one of the reasons the film’s not a knockout.

author: Leslie Felperin
summary: Hands of Stone is far from perfect, but it punches above its weight enough to prevent it from being easily dismissed.

author: Tim Grierson
summary: Hands Of Stone tests how far a film can go solely on heart, and in this case, it turns out to be just enough to overcome biopic conventionality.

author: Josh Kupecki
summary: I could watch Ramírez read the phone book, as the old saw goes. He is one of the most vibrant and charismatic actors working today. He infuses Durán with a charm and a recklessness that is tempered by De Niro’s quiet, understated performance, something he can do in his sleep.

author: James Berardinelli
summary: Traditional and uninspired, it does an adequate job of relating Duran’s story but falls short of providing an engaging cinematic experience.

author: Tom Russo
summary: The highlight is Duran and Arcel’s bonding in the corner between rounds. We’ll take more of this revealing brand of drama anytime.

author: Michael Phillips
summary: With Hands of Stone, Robert De Niro officially enters his Burgess Meredith-in-"Rocky" phase, bringing the ringside grizzle and rumpled gravitas by the pound.

author: John Anderson
summary: Jakubowicz has made a muscular, messy and vulgar film based on a life that has been all those things.

author: Bill Goodykoontz
summary: Helped by good performances from Edgar Ramirez as Duran, Usher Raymond as Leonard and Robert De Niro as Duran’s trainer, Ray Arcel, the film chugs along well enough, but never rises close to boxing films like “Raging Bull” (few films do) or “Creed.”

author: Owen Gleiberman
summary: Gets the job done, but it’s hard to escape the feeling that you’re watching a routinely conceived, rather generic boxing flick. It’s utterly competent, yet it makes Duran’s story seem a little so-what?

author: Chris Nashawaty
summary: Falls victim to too many trite boxing-movie clichés and is in way too much of a rush to cover too much narrative ground. It sometimes feels like you’re watching it with a finger on the fast-forward button.

author: Christy Lemire
summary: The performances are really strong, though. That’s what’s so frustrating; you just know there’s a better movie in here waiting to burst free.

author: Glenn Kenny
summary: Hands of Stone...is absolutely a boxing movie. A corny and sometimes clumsy one, it scatters pleasures here and there, Mr. De Niro’s alert performance among them.

author: Tirdad Derakhshani
summary: This should have been an easy knockout. Yet the pieces just don't fit together. Hands of Stone lurches back and forth between well-crafted dramatic scenes and shabby, cliché-ridden sequences that sap the viewer's energy.

author: Peter Hartlaub
summary: A film that can’t decide whether it wants to be “Raging Bull” or “Remember the Titans.” In the end, it’s a little too much of both.

author: Steve Greene
summary: In trying to squeeze a half-dozen life stories into its running time, Hands of Stone, the new film about legendary Panamanian boxer Roberto Durán, magnifies that disappointing mistake.

author: Ignatiy Vishnevetsky
summary: Somehow, Hands Of Stone even manages to make Don King (Reg E. Cathey) seem bloodless.

author: Brian Truitt
summary: Even though the film can’t focus on one subject, Hands of Stone does boast notable performances from its leads, especially Ramirez.

author: Robert Abele
summary: Unfortunately, the new biopic Hands of Stone...is too often content to play like a lot of other boxing flicks instead of forging its own path.

author: Vadim Rizov
summary: The bouts are all muddles lacking sustained choreography or a sense of trajectory, with crowd-reaction shots and sports-announcer voice-over carrying the slack.

author: Joshua Rothkopf
summary: A boxing movie in desperate need of Martin Scorsese (aren’t they all?).

author: Jordan Hoffman
summary: One sees film-making like this and can only say: no más.

author: Elise Nakhnikian
summary: The Panamanian-born Roberto Duran's story has all the makings of a fascinating film, but Hands of Stone isn't it.

author: Stephanie Merry
summary: The drama stars Edgar Ramírez as Roberto and Robert De Niro as his legendary coach. The two are exceptionally well cast, but they can’t save an unfocused jumble of a movie that doubles as a cautionary tale about the importance of film editing.

author: Will Ashton
summary: An unsavory, underdeveloped and uninspired bore, it takes too many blows and doesn’t give nearly enough counterpunches. It doesn’t cut. It doesn’t bleed. It doesn’t even hit. Hell, it barely puts up a fight. It comes out the gate frail and disoriented, already down for the count before the picture has started.

author: Kyle Smith
summary: Trite and vulgar boxing flick.

author: Rex Reed
summary: Another illuminating performance by Rachel Weisz and a brilliant screenplay by the distinguished British playwright David Hare make Denial one of the most powerful and riveting courtroom dramas ever made.

author: Darren Ruecker
summary: Beneath this movie’s conventions are some interesting gender politics that perhaps could have been made more apparent, but to its credit, are pleasantly subtle.

author: Deborah Young
summary: Rachel Weisz’s arresting, combative Lipstadt, a shining woman warrior, is a role she will be remembered for, while as her antagonist Timothy Spall (Mr. Turner) makes a spookily stubborn, thoroughly despicable, but still human Irving.

author: Steve Persall
summary: David Hare's screenplay based on Lipstadt's book is intrinsically stacked toward her eventual triumph, with each familiar step worth watching.

author: James Berardinelli
summary: The performances are universally strong - not that one would expect anything else considering the quality of the cast.

author: Moira Macdonald
summary: Ultimately Denial works, thanks to its strong cast — particularly Spall, who gives Irving a slightly mad gleefulness, and Weisz, whose smart, tough Deborah chafes against the quiet acquiescence expected of her.

author: Roger Moore
summary: The film’s courtroom concentration — the suit, prep and trial took years — makes it one of the driest treatments of The Holocaust ever. But Weisz and Wilkinson find emotions around the edges of all that be-wigged legal wrangling.

author: Kate Taylor
summary: As her adversary, the ghastly Irving, Timothy Spall is excellent, creating a man of great insecurities hidden behind blustering self-confidence. The actor is happily willing to manufacture a thoroughly oily and dislikeable figure as he and Jackson successfully balance their villain on the knife edge of caricature.

author: Mick LaSalle
summary: Weisz’s conviction, passion and galvanizing outrage drive Denial. For a Jewish academic, this was no intellectual exercise, and Weisz lets us see it. Between the frames, Weisz likewise assures us that Denial is no routine movie for a Jewish actress.

author: Calvin Wilson
summary: The fact-based Denial is a well-crafted and skillfully acted drama about standing up for the truth, regardless of how challenging that might be.

author: Richard Roeper
summary: A powerful but often stilted drama bolstered by two great performances from accomplished actors and nearly sunk by an unfortunately (and surprisingly) off-key performance from another fine actor.

author: Oleg Ivanov
summary: Denial shows that people’s misfortunes need not preclude them from living virtuous lives founded on basic human decency.

author: Jordan Ruimy
summary: While Denial doesn’t do anything new on a technical side, it is fully aware of its gripping plot, one that welcomely avoids pushing its inherent clichés to the forefront of its story.

author: David Ehrlich
summary: A simple courtroom drama that never betrays its convictions, the film is a basic but bitterly urgent reminder that history is far more fluid than fact, a garden that must be tended to at all times lest it wither and grow weeds.

author: Kenneth Turan
summary: Denial periodically plays like a standard-issue drama. But because Hare's script grapples with serious themes and singular events whose ramifications are still being felt, it is effective when it counts.

author: Stephen Whitty
summary: The action inside the courtroom is compelling. This is a place where people duel with words, not swords, but the wounds can be just as deep and permanent.

author: Fionnuala Halligan
summary: Jackson’s film is best enjoyed for the quality of the performances and the typical richness of Hare’s screenplay.

author: Marc Savlov
summary: Courtroom dramas can be tricky, tetchy things, but director Jackson, working from a script by David Hare (The Hours) keeps the suspense and moral indignation peaking high throughout Denial’s slightly overlong running time.

author: Peter Rainer
summary: Wilkinson’s acting is likely to be undervalued simply because it seems effortless.

author: Leah Greenblatt
summary: Sadly, it’s hamstrung by a patchy script (by David Hare) and an oddly flat-footed performance by Rachel Weisz as Lipstadt.

author: Stephanie Merry
summary: The movie may be competent at telling its story, but it’s missing one key ingredient: feeling.

author: Peter Keough
summary: The film works adequately as a historical drama.

author: Susan Wloszczyna
summary: At the nasty center of the otherwise dutiful Denial is a slimy, self-aggrandizing upper-class blowhard of a bigot who believes he has every right to circulate hateful and hurtful falsehoods to his followers.

author: Lucy Popescu
summary: Given the alarming rise of far right xenophobia, a film that portrays this memorable defence against fascism and the rewriting of history, feels exceptionally timely. There are more than a few parallels to be drawn between the swagger and deviousness of Irving and another well known falsifier, President Trump.

author: Tim Robey
summary: Denial certainly isn’t great cinema – it gets stuffy and repetitive, and Lipstadt’s frustration at not being allowed to testify herself isn’t the burning issue it ought to be. Still, it’s textbook advocacy, and a teaching tool of genuine value.

author: Olly Richards
summary: A sturdy by-the-numbers legal drama that really belongs on the small screen.

author: Tom Huddleston
summary: Denial cries out for a little more subtlety.

author: Alan Scherstuhl
summary: The movie is fascinating in its approach to legal arguments, forensic evidence, and the uses and abuses of history — but, like the courtroom at its center, it doesn't have much feel for the feels.

author: Jesse Hassenger
summary: Intentionally or not, Denial is perfectly timed to a season of insane conspiracy theories and feelings-based readings of facts.

author: Stephen Holden
summary: The absence of an emotional catharsis in the film, efficiently directed by Mick Jackson (“The Bodyguard,” “Temple Grandin”) from a screenplay by the British playwright David Hare, leaves a frustrating emptiness at its center.

author: Gregory Ellwood
summary: What’s most disturbing is Jackson’s pedestrian direction has resulted in a film that barely recognizes how powerful this is in contemporary society.

author: Owen Gleiberman
summary: For all the powerful relevance of its subject, Denial, directed by Mick Jackson from a script by David Hare, never finds its grip. It’s a curiously awkward and slipshod movie that winds up being about nothing so much as the perverse, confounding eccentricities of the British legal system.

author: Nigel M Smith
summary: Under the workmanlike direction of Mick Jackson (The Bodyguard), what should have been a rousing and ragingly topical crowdpleaser, instead feels more like a Lifetime movie.

author: Farran Smith Nehme
summary: The movie sneers at the journalists covering the trial, but for those of us who followed it at the time, the newspaper accounts were a lot more engrossing than this film.

author: A.A. Dowd
summary: From its thinly sketched teen protagonist to its deluge of hero-will-rise clichés, Max Steel evinces all of the imagination and ambition you’d expect from a movie based on a bestselling line of action figures.

author: Noel Murray
summary: At its best, “Max Steel” shares elements with “Smallville” and “Teen Wolf,” using the supernatural as a metaphor for awkward adolescence. At its worst, it’s more like “Transformers” — an extended toy commercial, noisy and forgettable.

author: Frank Scheck
summary: As the stuntmen duke it out and we see close-ups of the two actors making silly faces, it's hard not imagine a Mystery Science Theater 3000 feature in the making.

author: Sam Fragoso
summary: If the past is any indication, Hendler, Winchell, Bello and everyone else involved have the capacity to create interesting, original, and engaged art. Max Steel is none of those things.

author: Robert Yaniz Jr.
summary: Max Steel may promise a change of pace from all the Marvel and DC adaptations, but it’s subpar to both those shared universes on every level, telling an origin story that brings little new to the table and a cast that deserves far better.

author: Joe Leydon
summary: [A] drearily lame time-waster.

author: Christy Lemire
summary: A movie based on a toy should be a whole lot more fun than this.

author: Stephen Holden
summary: The wonder of the movie, which Mr. Beatty wrote and directed from a story he wrote with Bo Goldman, is that it is so good-humored. Fools and idiots abound, but demonic, systemic evil does not.

author: Robbie Collin
summary: Beatty’s casting of Collins and Ehrenreich is inspired: it’s easy to imagine both of these beautiful young things thriving in the Hollywood of the 1950s and 60s, in much the same way Beatty himself did.

author: Joe Morgenstern
summary: Somewhat unshapely, though not shapeless; often repetitive; gleefully reckless with facts; probably too long (I say “probably” because I enjoyed every one of its 126 minutes); at times demandingly dense, with the kind of sizzling crosstalk that hasn’t been heard since Robert Altman, and as madly fragmented as its hero’s mind must have been.

author: Allen Salkin
summary: Like Cohen's output, Rules Don't Apply as a whole is strangely hypnotizing. It has not been edited as so many other recent movies have, down to the nub, removing everything but the highlights you can produce movie trailers from. This thing breathes and creaks. It works. Maybe the cracks are what let the light in.

author: Matt Zoller Seitz
summary: It's a mess, but a glorious one, and it's so clearly the expression of one artist's vision, seemingly immune to studio notes, that when you find yourself wondering "Who on earth could this possibly be for?" you realize that it's a compliment. As an entertainment, Rules Don't Apply deserves an extra half-star for audacity.

author: Peter Rainer
summary: This is a movie about how one’s passion can burn away and leave in its place a vast nostalgia.

author: Mick LaSalle
summary: Rules Don’t Apply feels unbalanced in terms of story, and it has a big sag in the middle. But the good things in it are so good that they make it a fairly worthwhile experience.

author: Kyle Smith
summary: This is Beatty’s first film in 15 years, a project he’s been working on for 40 years, and it’s immensely pleasing to see him in such fine form. Or, as his obsessive-compulsive subject would say, such fine form. Such fine form.

author: Leah Greenblatt
summary: It turns out that Rules Don’t Apply is hardly about Hughes at all. Instead, it’s a small-scale, lovingly filmed study of the blossoming romance between two fictional show-business newbies.

author: Blake Goble
summary: Hughes has seen his fair share of dramatizations on film (The Aviator, Melvin & Howard, The Hoax, even The Rocketeer), but Beatty delivers a fresh, idiosyncratic take, about the figure and the people in his orbit of oddity.

author: Eric Kohn
summary: Beatty’s long-gestating project is a modestly enjoyable, well-acted nostalgia piece with just a touch of edge.

author: Kevin Jagernauth
summary: If its somewhat unfocused narrative comes at the cost of a picture that could be more cohesive and concise, it still gifts viewers with characters and an era that’s entertaining to explore.

author: Stephanie Zacharek
summary: This is a picture Beatty has wanted to make for years, and if the movie isn’t the achievement it should be, it’s at least entertaining in fits and starts.

author: Todd McCarthy
summary: This is a fitfully funny quasi-farce that takes off promisingly, loses its way mid-flight and comes in for a bumpy but safe landing.

author: Alonso Duralde
summary: While writer-director Warren Beatty’s movie about Hughes is crafted of the finest materials, it too remains mostly earthbound, defying gravity only in fits and starts.

author: Jared Mobarak
summary: If anything it simply reminds us of his onscreen charisma and endearing humor, his handle of Hughes’ descent into eccentricity and insanity proving memorably entertaining. While he’s not the lead, he is the glue.

author: Peter Travers
summary: It's clear that Beatty, who has studied Hughes for decades, has an instinctive understanding of the man, from getting stuck on phrases he repeats endlessly to making deals he can't wait to run away from. No kids. No roots. Sex, movies and aviation are the only constants. Why? Beatty hints, but never tells us. But his performance, filled with comic bite and aching confusion, teases a much deeper portrait.

author: James Berardinelli
summary: Rules Don’t Apply is a strange, schizophrenic sort of movie. Despite moments of emotional strength and bursts of quirky comedy, the film is undone by its generally lethargic tone and the film’s insistence to shift its focus from the putative lead characters to a supporting player.

author: Brian Truitt
summary: Tthe writer/producer/director/star’s first film in 15 years struggles with its tone and is a solid if unspectacular effort, though Beatty smartly takes a supporting role to the youngsters by playing the kookily eccentric Hughes.

author: Ty Burr
summary: This is not a well-made film but it is an enjoyable one, in part because it’s genuinely unpredictable and in part because it’s a pleasure to see one of the great stars of his era on a movie screen once more.

author: John Bleasdale
summary: There's a wry comic sensibility that sees Hughes himself as an absurdity who seems half aware of his own ridiculousness.

author: Joshua Rothkopf
summary: Rules Don’t Apply flies along at an inhuman speed; the edits are sharp, skipping years at a time, and the production values are unshowy. Like everything this star-director has done, the film is deceptively smart. It’s just a little too late to the game.

author: Bill Goodykoontz
summary: It’s kind of funny, it’s kind of revealing, it’s kind of insightful as a glimpse into Hughes’ increasingly twisted mind, but it never adds up to more than the sum of its parts.

author: Kenneth Turan
summary: Rules Don't Apply, as its name implies, is a movie intent on going its own way. It's not without its charms, but there aren't enough of them and they don't readily cohere.

author: Jordan Hoffman
summary: It doesn’t make sense as a comedy, it doesn’t quite work as a drama, and it doesn’t follow the typical roadmap of a biopic, but Rules Don’t Apply is strangely compelling nonetheless.

author: Tim Grierson
summary: The romantic comedy-drama Rules Don’t Apply is, by turns, fizzy and melancholy, nostalgic and clear-eyed, but it never builds to anything especially substantial.

author: Peter Debruge
summary: Beatty tries hard to re-create the look and feel of late-’50s Hollywood as it existed both on-screen and off, aided by DP Caleb Deschanel and terrific costume and set contributions. And yet, it actually comes off too conservative for its own time, with stiff performances from Collins and Ehrenreich.

author: David Edelstein
summary: Beatty is trying to elevate the material while at the same time draining it of energy. The movie is so misbegotten that it’s almost poignant. But I hope Beatty has a few more left in him.

author: Erin Whitney
summary: Rules Don’t Apply could have been an insightful look at a tragic, troubled figure. Instead Beatty made a conventional romance with lead characters we hardly care about.

author: Johanna Schneller
summary: If you call your movie this, you’re kinda asking for it. Some rules should apply. For example, characters should make a little sense, so when they behave in “unpredictable” ways, we can tell. But Warren Beatty, back in the director’s chair after 18 years, has gone rogue.

author: Stephanie Merry
summary: If Beatty was not trying to make a movie about Hughes, he utterly failed, because the love story of Frank and Marla is more like a framing device — a gateway drug to get the audience into the theater so that Beatty can chew some scenery. Even so, he chews it quite well.

author: Ignatiy Vishnevetsky
summary: Aside from Beatty’s performance, the only consistent thing the movie has going for it is ineffable strangeness; it seems to be trapped at the bottom of the chasm that separates its subversive aims from its nostalgic pursuits.

author: Soren Andersen
summary: Beatty directed and wrote the script, but from a man who made the weighty epic “Reds” and the corrosively funny “Bulworth,” Rules Don’t Apply feels curiously weightless and as forgettable as its title.

author: Richard Brody
summary: Beatty packs the movie with labored period references and unsubtle allusions to Donald Trump. He delights in Hughes’s high-handed wisdom, his high-stakes gamesmanship, and his petty idiosyncrasies, while looking ruefully at his paranoid reclusiveness.

author: Steve Persall
summary: Rules Don't Apply is affably mediocre, even tolerable between brief pleasures. The movie's lone constant amusement is Beatty's madcap portrayal of Hughes, keeping aloft his Spruce Goose of nonromantic not quite comedy.

author: Matt Donato
summary: Warren Beatty's Howard Hughes retrospective, Rules Don't Apply, is equally tone-deaf in humor and drama, cobbled together in ways that never seem to fit.

author: Roger Moore
summary: Beatty, who plays Hughes in the picture, tries to give us a movie as wildly eccentric and asymmetrical as the man himself. He’s concocted a random romantic farce that isn’t romantic or particularly farcical. But random? Yeah.

author: Kimberley Jones
summary: Either way, Beatty has taken an object of enduring fascination and made him … not so much.

author: Elise Nakhnikian
summary: Warren Beatty's portrayal of Howard Hughes has the overly polished feel of an anecdote that's been told too often.

author: Katie Walsh
summary: It would still be a stinker even if it wasn't cloaked in a dark shroud of cultural and political relevancy. It's just that bad.

author: Barry Hertz
summary: It’s a delightfully cruel work of high tension, perfect in just how quickly and easily it gets under your skin.

author: Steven Rea
summary: Green Room is just as accomplished a film, with the writer/director doing everything right: the cast, the music, the editing, the way he leads you one way and then clobbers you (and some of his ill-fated characters) when you (and they) are least expecting it.

author: Drew McWeeny
summary: Just on a technical level, the film represents such a big jump forward for Saulnier that you should expect the studios to immediately start arguing over which giant soulless franchise should occupy his time in the near-future.

author: Jason Gorber
summary: Littered with clever dialogue, a beautifully constructed narrative, as well as moments that shift between the energizing and sheer terror, there are a slew of endearing qualities worth sifting through.

author: A.A. Dowd
summary: Green Room is a rare gift from the genre gods: a nasty, punk-as-f..k midnight movie made by a genuine artist, a filmmaker with a great eye and a true understanding of the people and places he’s splattering in viscera.

author: Chris Nashawaty
summary: Part of being in a punk band involves having to play some pretty hostile venues. But the one in writer-director Jeremy Saulnier’s new white-knuckle thriller, Green Room, makes the typical mosh-pit dive look like a kindergarten run by nuns.

author: Oliver Lyttelton
summary: An exciting, splattery, funny genre movie that somehow never once feels disposable.

author: Emily Yoshida
summary: While Green Room shares an aesthetic sensibility with his last film (he shot and directed all his features), Saulnier is up to something very different this time around — something simpler, perhaps, but more immediately satisfying.

author: Jeffrey Bloomer
summary: Green Room proves to be an exquisitely crafted love letter to John Carpenter, and the rare horror ensemble that gives as much care to the villains as to the victims.

author: Robert Abele
summary: While thrashing chords score this gutbucket nightmare, Saulnier's way with overwhelmed characters, pressing evil and dangerous escape mechanics is practically symphonic.

author: Bilge Ebiri
summary: Jeremy Saulnier's Green Room is an impeccably crafted cinematic torture machine — in the best possible way.

author: Andrew O'Hehir
summary: It’s gruesome and funny and dark and incredibly tense.

author: Matt Singer
summary: The brilliance is all in the execution, which is just about perfect, from the score of hard-rocking music (and ear-piercing feedback) to the gritty cinematography by Sean Porter.

author: Josh Kupecki
summary: Saulnier and co. have crafted a gleefully merciless update on Deliverance, except instead of city folk vs. hillbillies, it’s punk rockers vs. neo-Nazis, and it is one of the most brutal, visceral films to come along in quite some time.

author: Richard Roeper
summary: The cinematography, the set design, the all-important soundtrack, the editing: all first-rate. This is one smart chiller.

author: Ty Burr
summary: Violence in Green Room is just bad. Unfortunately for its heroes and for us all, it’s also sometimes inevitable.

author: Steve Persall
summary: Green Room is a blunt instrument of terror announcing Saulnier as a filmmaker to watch, just as soon as you pry those fingers off your eyes.

author: Sarah Kurchak
summary: The plot unravels beautifully, at a pace that’s methodical but still anxiety-inducing, building up an air of psychological fear so impenetrable that the only relief from it is an occasional splattering of visceral horror or an even more rare quip along the way.

author: Bill Goodykoontz
summary: Yelchin and Poots are especially good.

author: Kim Newman
summary: A riotous, rough-hewn and rousing punk reinvention of ’70s-style grindhouse exploitation-with-a-brain-cinema.

author: Sam Fragoso
summary: Despite the descent into madness that appears on screen, the movie is controlled and measured.

author: Edward Douglas
summary: For those who enjoy the goriest of thrillers, there is plenty of red running through Green Room.

author: Joshua Rothkopf
summary: This is a brutal movie that finds unusual freedom in limitations, as do wiry bassist Pat (Anton Yelchin) and bleach-blond concert attendee Amber (Imogen Poots), who both turn out to be pretty handy with weapons. Chalk it up to their killer instincts.

author: John Bleasdale
summary: Scary and funny by turns, Green Room has the potential to become a cult hit, with a genuine midnight movie appeal, and furthers the growing reputation of this young director.

author: Benjamin Lee
summary: Saulnier’s ability to take a well-trodden road and fill it with grisly surprises is quite something.

author: James Berardinelli
summary: Green Room is a simple movie with a straightforward premise. The film works for two reasons: Stewart’s presence and Saulnier’s execution.

author: Lawrence Toppman
summary: The whole movie has a matter-of-factness that extends not just to the final photographic montage but the last line of dialogue. We can’t ask for more from this genre, and we often get much less.

author: Roger Moore
summary: A ferocious, bloody, primal and pitiless gut-punch of a movie.

author: Soren Andersen
summary: Green Room is one nasty piece of work. And I mean that in a good way.

author: Peter Hartlaub
summary: The cinematography and direction are particularly compelling; the complicated sequences on the tight sets must have forced camera operators to play cinematic Twister in impossibly small corners.

author: Peter Travers
summary: Green Room is way more than crass exploitation. It's a B movie with  an art-house core.

author: Lou Lumenick
summary: Patrick Stewart has a blast playing against type as a soft-spoken white supremacist holding a punk rock band as his temporary prisoners in Jeremy Saulnier’s nicely crafted, low-budget comedy-thriller.

author: Carson Lund
summary: The film is an unambiguous endorsement of violent revolt as the only effective response to such inhuman savagery.

author: Tim Grierson
summary: There may not be a lot of depth to Green Room, but that doesn’t mean there isn’t sufficient thought and care.

author: Leslie Felperin
summary: As action, it's niftily executed, the suspense neatly built, and the shocks expectedly surprising.

author: Simon Abrams
summary: You have to take the bad with the good here: Green Room may be too schematic to fully capture the essence of its characters' groddy milieu, but it's also economically paced, and gorgeous.

author: Mike Scott
summary: Another feather in the cap of Saulnier, who -- now with two impressive features under his belt as director -- is emerging to become one of the more intriguing new voices in Hollywood.

author: A.O. Scott
summary: Once the violence starts, Green Room settles into horror movie logic, becoming steadily more gruesome and less terrifying as the body count grows. You know some people are going to die, and figuring out who and in what order feels more like a brainteaser than like a matter of deep moral or emotional concern.

author: Guy Lodge
summary: Characterization and emotional investment, however, are in disappointingly short supply, while crucial tension is permitted to dissipate in an anti-climactic final third.

author: Giovanni Marchini Camia
summary: While Green Room features a number of ingeniously crafted set pieces, it quickly winds up as an excessive, borderline pornographic revelry in extreme violence.

author: Michael O'Sullivan
summary: Aficionados of gore and guts may not mind the comfortably lived-in feel of this blood-spattered Green Room. But anyone looking for the ferocious originality, and unexpected humanity, of “Blue Ruin” will be disappointed by Saulnier’s uninspired cover version of a song we all know.

author: Rex Reed
summary: Before the carnage ends, the entire cast has been tortured, mutilated and murdered by so many weapons it’s hard to keep them straight. When the shotguns, box cutters and machetes run out, it’s time to cue the flesh-eating attack dogs.

author: Soren Andersen
summary: The acting and script are so strong that the picture is an outstanding achievement even in the 2D version that most people will see.

author: Owen Gleiberman
summary: There’s a grand paradox at work in Billy Lynn’s Long Halftime Walk. The film isn’t simply a technological experiment; it’s also a highly original, heartfelt, and engrossing story. And part of the power of it lies in the way that those two things are connected.

author: Mick LaSalle
summary: Taking place mostly over the course of a single day, it’s a smart and languorous film that finds time to luxuriate in conversations and to create a feeling for small-town American life.

author: Jesse Hassenger
summary: This is an uncharacteristically unsubtle work from Lee — yet in the end, it’s not ineffective.

author: Bill Goodykoontz
summary: It’s an interesting film, no question. But too much of the message gets lost in the medium.

author: A.O. Scott
summary: The satire may be a little too gentle, but there is something disarmingly tender about the way Mr. Lee dramatizes young Billy’s predicament. You may be surprised at how sweet this movie is and also, in retrospect, startled by how bleak its vision turns out to be.

author: David Rooney
summary: An absorbing character study, even if it's ultimately not one that justifies its much-vaunted technological advances.

author: Amy Nicholson
summary: No Iraq movie has better captured our country’s nationalistic nonsense, and the inner chaos of the men and women returning home to this noise.

author: Peter Rainer
summary: This is a technological breakthrough, all right, but a breakthrough to what?

author: Dan Mecca
summary: Billy Lynn’s Long Halftime Walk, proves both messy and inspiring.

author: Eric Kohn
summary: So long as “Billy Lynn” remains focused on his ambiguous mindset, it remains an engaging, somewhat theatrical character study. But Lee’s ongoing need to complicate his approach yields a movie trapped between conventional narrative tropes and questionable attempts to deliver something that registers on a more visceral level.

author: Peter Travers
summary: The film's technical achievements are indisputable (a military salute to camera wiz John Toll). But Billy Lynn comes off as artificial when we most need it to be natural, organic and whisper-close. Maybe there's a future film that will use size and sharpness to express an epic and intimate truth. Not this time.

author: Christopher Gray
summary: It does astounding work animating the mind of its young soldier, but it runs into technical difficulties whenever it tries to grasp the bigger picture.

author: Ian Nathan
summary: A flawed work held together by Alwyn’s tender presence.

author: Matt Donato
summary: Ang Lee’s depiction of life after war (or on leave) is a respectful one not without derivative roadbumps, but honest in appeal.

author: Justin Chang
summary: The sharp satirical edge that earned Fountain’s novel comparisons to “Catch-22” feels duller and more sluggish on the screen as Lee strains to weave his story’s dissonant tones and subplots...into a movie that works as both a compelling psychological portrait and an astute political argument.

author: David D'Arcy
summary: It’s a radiant debut for young newcomer Joe Alwyn, who plays a Texan war hero uneasy in his own land. It’s a shakier curtain-raising for Lee’s ambitious weaponising of new technologies.

author: Steve Persall
summary: It's just another example of technology intruding upon storytelling, that's been happening since kinetoscopes cranked one frame at a time.

author: Rodrigo Perez
summary: Billy Lynn has its moments, but its critical and unexpected folly is that the cutting-edge technology diminishes the picture emotionally, its ungainly look trivializes the drama and indulges it with an undesirable air of superficiality.

author: Marjorie Baumgarten
summary: Billy Lynn’s Long Halftime Walk is a hobbled parade.

author: Roger Moore
summary: Plays more like a sermon than cinema, a sermon delivered by uninspired preachers. And everybody knows America gave up sermons and thinking about Big Questions on Sundays for football and mindless entertainment decades ago.

author: Kate Taylor
summary: As a 21st-century account of the soldier’s enduring alienation from the home front, Billy Lynn is highly effective. It’s what surrounds that account that doesn’t work.

author: Bilge Ebiri
summary: In 120 frames a second, both Alwyn and Stewart came off as hopelessly stilted; at 24 frames, they breathe with life. But lose the flicker, and you lose the spell.

author: Stephanie Merry
summary: The film’s subtly observed moments are more powerful than any of its technical wizardry.

author: Calvin Wilson
summary: This halftime walk is more like a long slog.

author: Tirdad Derakhshani
summary: Like Clint Eastwood’s masterful 2006 WWII drama "Flags of Our Fathers," Lee’s film is as much about how we spin war stories as it is about war itself. Both involve a group of heroic soldiers sent home by the Pentagon to help drum up popular support. Both are made by filmmakers keenly aware that stories have the power to justify a war or turn the public against it.

author: Ty Burr
summary: Directing the film version, Lee gets lost in the grotesque pomp of the halftime spectacle and its lead-up. He gets fine performances from the actors playing the soldiers and a terrible one from Stewart, who flails her arms like an amateur. Martin’s role is beneath his talents, while Vin Diesel’s, as a Zen warrior of a sergeant, is almost beyond belief.

author: Michael Phillips
summary: An interesting misfire. It's also the victim of lousy timing.

author: Rene Rodriguez
summary: In his debut, Alwyn comes off as a likable, sympathetic screen presence capable of handling more difficult material. He’ll have plenty more opportunities. Billy Lynn’s Long Halftime Walk, though, will be forgotten in a month’s time.

author: David Edelstein
summary: The main problem with Lee’s Billy Lynn’s Long Halftime Walk is superficial, literally. Lee has opted for the rare 120-frames-per-second format, allegedly because he thought it would deepen our connection to the characters. He thought wrong.

author: Godfrey Cheshire
summary: Ang Lee is a great director whose last film, the Oscar-winning “Life of Pi,” made ingenious and very effective use of 3D technology. But that film had a much better story than Billy Lynn's Long Halftime Walk.

author: Joe McGovern
summary: The weirdest and rarest misfire in Lee’s illustrious career.

author: Nina Corcoran
summary: Don’t let Billy Lynn’s Long Halftime Walk‘s technical achievements carry the full weight of its errors. The plot and its poor execution leave the camerawork struggling to find much to dazzle with.

author: Stephanie Zacharek
summary: Everything in Billy Lynn’s Long Halftime Walk should work — and yet the picture falls flat. It’s a story enslaved by a director’s approach rather than served by it. His mannered placement of the camera is hard to ignore, and the actors suffer for it.

author: Stephen Whitty
summary: Real films breathe, alive with imperfections, accidents, with everything that Lee's worked so carefully to guard against. Billy Lynn's Long Half Time Walk is long, all right, but only half-alive — as careful as a diagram, as chilly as a statue.

author: Joshua Rothkopf
summary: Irony can’t survive in Lee’s airless vacuum; he’s not an experimenter at heart, and as a result, his movie feels heartless.

author: Daniel Engber
summary: It just looks and feels too different from every other movie we’ve seen in the multiplex.

author: Erin Whitney
summary: The movie gives us fragments of characters and rich flashbacks, but they’re not supported by a fully-formed narrative. Lee has boldly introduced a new technology, but that technology was a bad fit for this project.

author: Benjamin Lee
summary: It’s just a film that never really finds its footing, a problem that would have been noticeable with or without the increased frame rate. It’s just that at 120 frames a second, it’s so much more noticeable.

author: Dan Callahan
summary: Billy Lynn’s Long Halftime Walk winds up being a wearying experience, not because of its emotional content but because of its lack of cohesion and its ultimate collapse into gross and unearned sentimentality.

author: Brian Truitt
summary: A disappointing effort from a master filmmaker, Billy Lynn’s Long Halftime Walk trips in all the wrong places.

author: Kyle Smith
summary: Dramatically inert, satirically inept and thematically insufferable, Billy Lynn’s Long Halftime Walk is the most disappointing film of the year.

author: Michael Rechtshaffen
summary: Jane Got A Gun may not have reinvented the wagon wheel, but it rolls out as a sturdy, well-crafted genre piece despite its rocky road to the screen.

author: Joe Leydon
summary: A solidly made and conventionally satisfying Western.

author: Lisa Nesselson
summary: The motivations and the performances are solid in Jane Got A Gun, an attractively mounted post-Civil War revenge drama with plenty of shooting and a well-placed twist or two.

author: Alonso Duralde
summary: Jane Got a Gun takes long pauses in the action to chronicle through flashbacks how this love triangle comes to defend a single home. The film’s greatest surprise is that these unabashedly emotional flashbacks work.

author: Peter Sobczynski
summary: Jane Got a Gun has its good points and less demanding fans of the Western genre may find some value in it, especially considering how few films of its type actually get made these days.

author: Jamie Graham
summary: The arid landscapes are handsomely shot, the set-pieces punchy and intimate, and the performances robust, with Portman reminding us just how good an actress she is as her no-nonsense Jane gets on with the business of survival.

author: Jesse Hassenger
summary: Even when the movie focuses on its imagery rather than its plot mechanics, it seems intent on covering its bases rather than committing to a particular look or mood.

author: Roger Moore
summary: The action is visceral and exciting, but everything between the shootouts, especially the mostly-insipid flashbacks (A pre-Civil War romantic hot air balloon ride in Missouri? Really?) just makes you impatient for Jane to get that gun and get on with it.

author: Matt Brennan
summary: It constantly blunders into stylistic choices and narrative clichés that sabotage the sturdy two-hander at its center.

author: Blake Goble
summary: "Jane" eventually comes alive, even if Jane never truly does.

author: Rodrigo Perez
summary: Deeply over-reliant on flashbacks, and ones that don’t particularly transition well, Jane Got A Gun is nearly a holding pattern movie.

author: Chris Nashawaty
summary: Since the film’s last-minute rewrites, casting switcheroos, and musical chairs behind the camera are irrelevant to the actual quality of the movie, I’ll avoid rehashing them here, save to say that the disarray shows on screen.

author: Tom Huddleston
summary: Overall, the film just feels too much like an obligation, as though everyone involved had spent too much time and money to back out, so they forced themselves to grit their teeth and get on with it. You may feel the same.

author: Marjorie Baumgarten
summary: You have to feel a certain sympathy for a project as cursed as this one, but there’s no denying that Jane’s gun barely grazes its target.

author: Glenn Kenny
summary: Whatever feminist angle the film might have once aspired to is lost in its listless shuffle.

author: Jordan Mintzer
summary: A handful of plot twists are not enough to compensate for an overtly heavy, often dreary affair that rides straight into the final standoff with little elegance and a wagon train of pathos.

author: Anthony Lane
summary: Put the evidence together, and it’s no surprise that this poor little movie fires blanks. It never wanted to be a Western at all.

author: Owen Gleiberman
summary: The Bounce Back was co-written, directed, and edited by Youseff Delara, and for a while he creates some lively screwball tension.

author: Marjorie Baumgarten
summary: A quicker overall pace and trimmed dialogue might have lent the film more sparkle and zest, but it still makes it to the finish line with its decency intact.

author: Richard Roeper
summary: This is no history lesson, but it’s mainstream Hollywood entertainment that respects the history and seems to invite discussion and debate.

author: A.O. Scott
summary: Mr. Ross consulted some of the leading experts in the era...and has done a good job of balancing the factual record with the demands of dramatic storytelling. The result is a riveting visual history lesson, whose occasional didacticism is integral to its power.

author: Brad Wheeler
summary: Instead of captivating us with swagger, McConaughey chooses to go grim and dogged. Director Ross does the same.

author: Kyle Smith
summary: Free State of Jones is enticingly difficult to chart. It’s anti-war, anti-plutocracy and anti-racist, but it’s also pro-Bible, pro-gun, anti-tax and sympathetic to the poor whites who usually get tagged as racist. Its hero is an avowed Republican named Newt.

author: Ty Burr
summary: The result is rather a mess, but it’s an honorable one, and very much worth wrestling with.

author: Mick LaSalle
summary: Free State of Jones is an extraordinarily ambitious film, and for that reason, it’s not perfect.

author: Lawrence Toppman
summary: The movie remains quiet and deliberate, a synonym for “boring” in some minds (though not mine). In the end, it becomes an allegory for the times in which we live.

author: Joe Dziemianowicz
summary: The film gets predictable and loses its firm grip a third of the way in. Too bad, since the film directed and co-written by Gary Ross (“The Hunger Games,” “Seabiscuit”) gets off to a bang-up beginning.

author: Peter Rainer
summary: In supporting roles, Gugu Mbatha-Raw as Rachel, the equally valiant house slave Newton makes his common-law wife, and Mahershala Ali as Moses, the leader of the renegade slaves, provide some powerful moments.

author: Kimber Myers
summary: Everyone here means well and wants to make an epic war film, but it lacks a narrative strong enough to make it essential viewing for those beyond the genre’s fans.

author: Tirdad Derakhshani
summary: Mixing elements from documentaries, biopics, war flicks, and Hallmark romances, Ross' film is a living history tour, but with gory special effects and a smoldering smattering of sex appeal.

author: Godfrey Cheshire
summary: As inherently astonishing and powerful as this little-known episode is, it has not been well-served by Ross’ lumpy, ill-conceived script, which ends up wasting Matthew McConaughey’s terrific lead performance and other strong acting contributions.

author: John Hartl
summary: Unfortunately, it’s so ambitious that it’s constantly straining to find a focus.

author: Roger Moore
summary: Ross keeps his camera in McConaughey’s face, too. Every dirt stain, every twitch, every glower, wink and wince, is hard to miss. It’s not a bad performance, but it is an absurdly busy one.

author: Calvin Wilson
summary: Aspires to greatness but fumbles badly.

author: Michael Phillips
summary: Ross' smooth, steady film is just interesting enough to make you wish it were a lot grittier, and better.

author: Joshua Rothkopf
summary: Writer-director Gary Ross (Pleasantville, Seabiscuit) knows how to please crowds, so there's fascination in his consistently wrongheaded impulse to add more historical details: lengthy scenes of exposition, even a leap decades into the future for a courtroom drama involving Knight's persecuted offspring. He's lost sight of the powerful drama at this story's heart, about the ennobling swirl of momentous events.

author: Jimmy Geurts
summary: Anyone visiting Free State of Jones merely hoping to learn more about an interesting anti-slavery rebellion will likely come away sated, but those looking for an exciting, vital piece of filmmaking will have to wait for another opportunity.

author: Robert Abele
summary: That you may learn a good deal about an unusually driven man, but never quite feel emotionally connected to him, means Ross has hit a workmanlike middle, crafting a handsome textbook more than a blood-pumping portrait.

author: Jordan Raup
summary: Free State of Jones has a story worth telling, it just doesn’t know how to effectively do so.

author: Jesse Hassenger
summary: Ross may not be a great director, but he has written some very good screenplays, none of which sprawl out like this one.

author: Ann Hornaday
summary: As gratifying as it is to see forgotten history brought to light, it’s disappointing, too: There’s an epic story to be told within Free State of Jones, but this white-knight tale isn’t it.

author: Bill Goodykoontz
summary: Free State of Jones is a well-intentioned slog through a potentially fascinating bit of Civil War history, brought to life only by Matthew McConaughey’s performance, and then only occasionally.

author: Marjorie Baumgarten
summary: As it is, Newt Knight, the forward-thinking white liberal, is the only character with whom we might connect. And that’s a shame because this compelling episode of American defiance is so much richer than that.

author: Bilge Ebiri
summary: Diligent and informative but also fragmented and inert, it plays like a series of scenes and notes for a longer, more fleshed-out movie.

author: Jake Cole
summary: After its bracing opening, the film begins to indulge the worst impulses of well-meaning liberal cinema.

author: Joe McGovern
summary: Ross wants to shake up the format­—notably with a few scenes set 85 years after the war—but like so many directors who have tackled ­historical social issues before him, he confuses noble, cornball sermonizing for art.

author: Todd McCarthy
summary: A compelling and little-known story of the Civil War period is studiously reduced to a dry and cautious history lesson in Free State of Jones.

author: Owen Gleiberman
summary: For all the ravaged surface appeal of McConaughey’s performance, the character is a little too good to be true, but then, that’s just the sort of movie Free State of Jones is. It’s a tale of racial liberation and heroic bloodshed that is designed, at almost every turn, to lift us up to that special place where we can all feel moved by what good liberals we are.

author: Tim Grierson
summary: Although occasionally stirring, the film rarely rises above the level of intriguing anecdote, resulting in a deeply drab drama enlivened somewhat by Matthew McConaughey’s empathetic performance.

author: Clint Worthington
summary: On top of trying to be a Big, Important Film, Jones is also meant to be a showcase for McConaughey’s post-Oscar relevance as a dramatic actor, and he turns in a solid but unmemorable lead performance.

author: David Ehrlich
summary: Too robust to sink into the rhythms of a character study, but too financially limited to tell a story that matches the sweep of its director’s vision, Free State of Jones is a film divided against itself, and it cannot stand.

author: Matt Maytum
summary: After a visceral opening battle, endless speeches dull good intentions, and the characters lack depth.

author: Dan Jolin
summary: Too long, arduous, lecturey and patience-testing for even the all-new Matthew McConaughey to rescue. Director Ross is apparently so swamped by a sense of historical righteousness he hasn’t noticed he’s smothered a decent story.

author: Erin Whitney
summary: The last thing America needs is a historical movie correlating white people problems with those of people of color.

author: Mike Scott
summary: Rather than focusing on the most fascinating part of the story -- that would be the establishment and subsequent dissolution of free state after which the film is named -- his film devolves into a series of belabored points, high-minded pontifications and audience manipulation.

author: Joe Morgenstern
summary: Strong acting often lends authenticity to writing that lacks it, and Mr. McConaughey is, to be sure, an exceptionally strong actor. Yet this screenplay is so arid in its didacticism, so pallid in its would-be passion, that it defeats his efforts and our involvement.

author: Peter Travers
summary: Like the worst civics lesson, this movie bores away at you till your reactions are dulled.

author: Bill Zwecker
summary: While the actors do a yeoman’s job in presenting their characters with aplomb (especially Jesse Metcalfe, as Wesley’s lawyer), the entire film simply comes off as a two-hour, jazzed-up movie version of a sermon.

author: Dave White
summary: Its pulls back from the original film’s cruelty and comeuppances for non-believers, yet its non-Christian characters are still parodies of human evil: greedy, bitter, violent, and out to prove that “God is dead.”

author: Roger Moore
summary: In a righteous world, the better-acted, upbeat and faith-affirming “Miracles from Heaven” would eat this angry tirade for lunch.

author: Sheila O'Malley
summary: There are serious movies about the Christian faith, about the persecution of the faithful, and about the intolerance that goes both ways. God's Not Dead 2 is not one of them.

author: Dominick Suzanne-Mayer
summary: There is a tone of anger that sneaks out of the film in even its moments of levity.

author: Vadim Rizov
summary: The first film pandered to a heavy persecution complex; this installment’s relatively subtler, but there are dog whistles aplenty.

author: Jordan Hoffman
summary: God’s Not Dead 2 is a much better movie than God’s Not Dead, but that’s a bit like saying a glass of milk left on the table hasn’t curdled and is merely sour.

author: Nick Schager
summary: Dramatically speaking, God’s Not Dead 2 operates at the level of your average middle-school play – except with far greater levels of upside-down logic and bald-faced intolerance for anyone not enraptured by the New Testament.

author: Katie Walsh
meta_movie_name: Middle School: The Worst Years of My Life
moviename_x: Middle School: The Worst Years of My Life
summary: It's a fun, rebellious romp that celebrates creativity and outside-the-box thinking, though parents might hope that their children won't be too inspired to copy the elaborate pranks that these characters pull off.

author: Joe Leydon
meta_movie_name: Middle School: The Worst Years of My Life
moviename_x: Middle School: The Worst Years of My Life
summary: The fleeting counterbalance of seriousness makes the funny business marginally yet appreciably funnier.

author: Frank Scheck
meta_movie_name: Middle School: The Worst Years of My Life
moviename_x: Middle School: The Worst Years of My Life
summary: Delivers an easily digestible and amusing portrait of youthful hijinks that should well please its target audience.

author: Marjorie Baumgarten
meta_movie_name: Middle School: The Worst Years of My Life
moviename_x: Middle School: The Worst Years of My Life
summary: The film mixes vivid cartoons coming to life from the pages of Rafe’s sketchbook with the live action. The film is reminiscent of some of the best aspects of John Hughes’ teen movies: playful albeit with strong emotional centers that ground their suburban teen rebels.

author: Susan Wloszczyna
meta_movie_name: Middle School: The Worst Years of My Life
moviename_x: Middle School: The Worst Years of My Life
summary: Better than middling as it sidesteps the trap of simply pandering to its youthful demo with cheap laughs and silly mugging.

author: Keith Watson
meta_movie_name: Middle School: The Worst Years of My Life
moviename_x: Middle School: The Worst Years of My Life
summary: Unimaginatively directed and indifferently shot, the film never establishes a distinctive voice for itself.

author: Andy Webster
meta_movie_name: Middle School: The Worst Years of My Life
moviename_x: Middle School: The Worst Years of My Life
summary: The find here is Alexa Nisenson as Georgia, Rafe’s know-it-all little sister, who takes cars out for a spin. She is blessed with the best lines, comic and dramatic, and appears delightfully cognizant of the fact. If only the movie had more of her.

author: Brad Wheeler
meta_movie_name: Middle School: The Worst Years of My Life
moviename_x: Middle School: The Worst Years of My Life
summary: Ironically, Middle School’s message is about encouraging kids and grown-ups to think outside the box and yet, the filmmakers themselves do precisely the opposite.

author: Peter Hartlaub
meta_movie_name: Middle School: The Worst Years of My Life
moviename_x: Middle School: The Worst Years of My Life
summary: It's a so-so film with jarring tone changes and a plot that sputters before a predictable ending. But there are moments of inspiration and authenticity.

author: Jesse Hassenger
meta_movie_name: Middle School: The Worst Years of My Life
moviename_x: Middle School: The Worst Years of My Life
summary: Though its title and general tone lament the stifling atmosphere of the years between childhood and full-fledged teenhood, the movie misses the animal hostility and physical awkwardness of genuine tweens.

author: Roger Moore
meta_movie_name: Middle School: The Worst Years of My Life
moviename_x: Middle School: The Worst Years of My Life
summary: The wimpy kid here isn’t interesting, the “worst years” a dull exaggeration and the movie not worth the 92 minutes it takes to sit through.

author: Tom Russo
meta_movie_name: Middle School: The Worst Years of My Life
moviename_x: Middle School: The Worst Years of My Life
summary: The film’s lone strength is the fleeting dramatic scenes offering a little back story — and pathos — on Rafe’s home life with his sweetly understanding single mom (Lauren Graham, who you’d guess wouldn’t have bothered otherwise).

author: Alonso Duralde
meta_movie_name: Middle School: The Worst Years of My Life
moviename_x: Middle School: The Worst Years of My Life
summary: The film’s attempts at comedy and sentimentality are equally unsuccessful, resulting in a movie that feels more like a third-rate “Saved by the Bell” knock-off than a legitimate teen flick.

author: Mick LaSalle
summary: This is a profound saga that makes for a great American movie.

author: Tirdad Derakhshani
summary: The film delivers what it promises - an education and a thrill.

author: Brian Truitt
summary: Race makes its title's double meaning all too clear, and at a time when the Oscars and movies, in general, struggle with finding racial balance, two guys of different skin colors coming together for some sports-movie magic is a fitting and truly welcoming lapping of the competition.

author: Calvin Wilson
summary: James makes for a charismatic hero, and former “Saturday Night Live” star Sudeikis is a revelation as the steadfast Snyder.

author: Christian Holub
summary: Credit Race for showcasing its hero’s human flaws, but the movie unfortunately lets him get away with them a little too easily (his grand makeup gesture to Ruth comes off more creepy than romantic).

author: Soren Andersen
summary: What the picture lacks is a certain spark. It’s a workmanlike effort that diligently covers a lot of bases...but never achieves a transcendence that befits a figure like Owens.

author: Tasha Robinson
summary: Race is exactly the kind of film the Academy loves to honor: bland, uplifting, respectable, engaged with historical social issues, but not too controversial or directly tied to the present.

author: Stephen Holden
summary: If Race is a standard inspirational biopic that exalts the legend of an athletic hero, at least it doesn’t soft-pedal the racism that Owens encountered at every turn.

author: Inkoo Kang
summary: The Jesse Owens to cheer on here is, sure, the fastest man in the world, but also the canny would-be celebrity who knew exactly how to bet on himself in a world that had little use for his dignity and intellect. If that’s not an inspirational story, I don’t know what is.

author: Blake Goble
summary: Race is a film best enjoyed for its mild ambitions and accomplishments, which easily beat out its missteps.

author: Marjorie Baumgarten
summary: As Owens, relative newcomer Stephan James delivers a stirring performance, and as his coach, comedian Jason Sudeikis turns in a solid and smirk-free performance.

author: James Berardinelli
summary: Race, like "42," does a workmanlike job of bringing the lead character to life and explaining his historical importance, but it fails to transcend the genre.

author: Kate Taylor
summary: Having managed Berlin rather gracefully, Race often plods along the home front.

author: Peter Travers
summary: Race is at its best when it fills in the corners of a story we only thought we knew.

author: Odie Henderson
summary: Race takes a complicated, messy story and shapes it with the bland cookie-cutter mold too often seen in the biopic genre.

author: Kyle Smith
summary: Hitler didn’t actually snub Jesse Owens at the 1936 Olympics, but the story is too good not to tell, so Race tells it anyway — adding the (true) detail that Owens was snubbed back home. By someone called “the White House,” because this supposedly truth-telling movie can’t bear to spell out the words Franklin D. Roosevelt.

author: Alan Zilberman
summary: The film is handsomely mounted and provides a window into the tough choices Owens faced, yet its dramatic licenses oversell its message.

author: Sheri Linden
summary: Owens’ triumph is long overdue for big-screen treatment, and director Stephen Hopkins delivers stirring moments amid the tension-free stretches, particularly once the action moves to Berlin.

author: Andrew Barker
summary: Stephen Hopkins’ film offers a safe, middlebrow slice of history that beats a snoozy lecture any day. Making a few admirable attempts to complicate what could have been a standard-issue inspirational sports narrative, Race is better than it has to be, but not by too much.

author: Steve Persall
summary: Like a struggling sprinter, Stephen Hopkins' film suffers from wasted motion, too much going on. It's the difference between a merely competent movie and one justifying more discussion of Hollywood's commitment to reward diversity.

author: Jesse Hassenger
summary: The rest of Race has other moments of engagement in a slickly produced and watchable package. But ultimately, it offers history told as a series of passing anecdotes.

author: Scott Tobias
summary: Were it not so committed to telling the official story in bullet points, Race might have found a more provocative angle about athletes and artists who work through and around the powers that be.

author: Roger Moore
summary: An overlong, all-inclusive and all-too-tepid bio-pic of the great Olympian.

author: Bilge Ebiri
summary: As Jesse Owens, [James] mixes confidence, bewilderment, and subdued rage into a powerful whole. It’s not a big, show-offy performance. Quite the contrary: He’s surprisingly quiet, watchful. Everything seems to be submerged, but still present.

author: Michael Snydel
summary: Race is the rare biopic that needs more of its own main character.

author: Ty Burr
summary: Race wants so badly to get every last bit of the big picture that it dashes past the little details that actually tell a story. Like an over-trained athlete who pulls a hamstring in the big race, the movie tries to do it all and comes up short.

author: Richard Roeper
summary: There’s a memorable movie to be made about the amazing, inspiration and controversial life of Jesse Owens. This is not a bad film and it’s a decent history lesson for those that don’t know the story of Owens and the ’36 Games, but it’s a long, long way from greatness.

author: Tim Grierson
summary: Neither director Stephen Hopkins nor star Stephan James can bring Owens’ story to passionate life, resulting in a drama that’s well-meaning rather than riveting.

author: Elise Nakhnikian
summary: This is a complication-smoothing take on Jesse Owens's elegant riposte to Hitler's racism at the 1936 Berlin Olympics.

author: Michael Phillips
summary: What's the point of telling Jesse Owens' story if you don't get into what made him tick, and drove his success as an athlete?

author: Rene Rodriguez
summary: Race never delves under the skins of its characters, because they’re intended to be used only as symbols — reminders of an important chapter in history rendered quaint by this noble but patronizing movie.

author: Joshua Rothkopf
summary: Race is the most timid, lackadaisical movie that could have been made out of potentially classic material.

author: Mike Scott
summary: It's hard to escape the feeling that Hopkins left a lot on the table -- and that there's a better Jesse Owens film to be told.

author: Joe Morgenstern
summary: For all the luster of its subject, though, this earnest biopic lacks the spark of life.

author: Stephen Whitty
summary: A movie that really mined that story would be worth the gold. This one barely doesn’t even capture the bronze.

author: Lawrence Toppman
summary: In a world full of recyclable superheroes and mindless “empowerment” comedies, we’re finally getting a movie about reality. We’re surrounded by surveillance and the threat of violence, and this film asks us to judge the proper balance between liberty and security – and the amount of collateral damage acceptable to maintain the latter.

author: Tricia Olszewski
summary: Mirren, as ever, is both polite and brusque, her petite va-va-voomness never undermining her credibility as a tough military top-ranker. And Rickman — oh, that dryly sarcastic voice.

author: Leah Greenblatt
summary: Aaron Paul has key scenes as the drone pilot who actually has to pull the trigger, but it’s the late Alan Rickman, as Mirren’s superior, who steals the film.

author: Stephen Holden
summary: A grim, suspenseful farce in which unpredictable human behavior repeatedly threatens an operation of astounding technological sophistication.

author: Joe Leydon
summary: A rivetingly suspenseful drama that deftly intertwines elements of ticking-clock thriller and tragic farce.

author: James Berardinelli
summary: Eye in the Sky reminded me of "United 93" - not necessarily in terms of the subject matter but because of the apolitical, clear-headed manner in which it approaches an act.

author: Calvin Wilson
summary: This is the kind of intelligent, thought-provoking mainstream film that’s in danger of becoming extinct. Eye in the Sky is miles above the average multiplex flick.

author: Lou Lumenick
summary: South African director Gavin Hood (“X-Men Origins: Wolverine’’) pulls off some really tricky tonal shifts.

author: Steve Persall
summary: Eye in the Sky remains gripping even when Hibbert tosses in one or two side-taking circumstances too many.

author: James Mottram
summary: Tense and thought-provoking in equal measure, this is first-rate – a modern-day Dr. Strangelove played out on video screens.

author: Olly Richards
summary: It's a tight thriller played out smoothly but tying the viewer in moral knots. A film to think about for days, with little hope of finding a comfortable answer.

author: Stephen Whitty
summary: As the colonel, Mirren is terrific — a fierce warrior willing to bend as many rules of engagement as it takes. As her commanding officer, the late Alan Rickman is just as dedicated but a little tired of bloodshed.

author: Benjamin Lee
summary: Eye in the Sky aims to thrill and covertly manages to inform simultaneously.

author: John DeFore
summary: This picture satisfies fully on entertainment terms without cheapening its real-world concerns.

author: Marc Savlov
summary: Eye in the Sky maintains nerve-racking suspense throughout its running time and explicates some of the unknown nuances of drone warfare. Plus, you know, Alan Rickman is reason enough to see it.

author: Roger Moore
summary: Eye in the Sky is a tasty ticking-clock thriller parked at the intersection of politics and propaganda, military technology and combat morality. It’s not the first movie about the ethics of drone warfare. The low-budget nail-biter “Drones” beat it to the punch by a couple of years.

author: Molly Eichel
summary: Mirren is icy and fierce. Rickman brings both levity and sorrow to his role as a soldier who has seen war from both sides: the conference room and battlefield.

author: Brad Wheeler
summary: The political buck-passing from all entertains and creates the film’s time-sensitive tension.

author: Dominick Suzanne-Mayer
summary: It’s a film with no easy answers, and rightly, Hood doesn’t strain to offer them. If the film’s attempts at barbed satire don’t land as well as its graver moments, it’s nevertheless an effective look at the new kind of war.

author: Richard Roeper
summary: The acting is world-class in Eye in the Sky, a timely and tense but sometimes heavy-handed drama set in the modern world of drone warfare.

author: Moira Macdonald
summary: At times, the film approaches gallows comedy...perhaps a little too much so; at others, it’s a tense, chilling look at a seemingly unbearable choice — refreshingly, without telling its viewers what to think.

author: Ann Hornaday
summary: This is the rare military drama that conveys both the graphic physical effects of war and its lingering psychic cost.

author: Mick LaSalle
summary: Eye in the Sky is refreshing in its lack of a political message. Mirren is chilling as the cold-blooded colonel.

author: Ty Burr
summary: Its strength and limitation is that it’s a gimmick that works.

author: Godfrey Cheshire
summary: While Hood’s film says very little about American policy in this area, it does suggest that its terrible subject is likely to be with us for a long time to come.

author: Peter Travers
summary: The suspense is killer as military minds in the US and the UK come together only to lock horns on a drone operation in Nairobi.

author: Matt Brennan
summary: Director Gavin Hood treats the aesthetics of high-tech surveillance as the opaque membrane through which the prosecution of the War on Terror must pass.

author: Bill Goodykoontz
summary: Subtle it's not, but the film is effective both as a thriller and as a war film with something to say.

author: Andrew O'Hehir
summary: The conscientious precision and painstaking identification in Eye in the Sky is presented as morally murky; Mirren’s character leans hard on a subordinate to give her an acceptable estimate of collateral damage, so the politicians will say yes. Even so it may be an overly reassuring picture.

author: Joe Morgenstern
summary: Eye in the Sky is literally all over the map in its depiction of drone warfare, and right on target, if flagrantly contrived, in examining the ethics of killing by remote control.

author: Adam Nayman
summary: Like Brian De Palma’s underrated "Redacted," this is a film that doesn’t want to be easily pegged, either in terms of its politics or generic allegiances. Such ambiguity is a virtue, but for all his technical facility, Hood doesn’t really have the finesse of a great, fearless satirist.

author: Kevin Jagernauth
summary: While certainly imperfect, there is something to admire about the film’s attempt to present the tangled logistics of a single military operation, where it seems everyone wants success but none of the responsibility of the tough decision making involved.

author: Tom Huddleston
summary: There’s wit, integrity and insight here, but it cries out for a lighter touch.

author: Tim Robey
summary: Eye in the Sky is a tick-tock suspense exercise as well as a neat little ethical echo chamber, a plea for reason in a world exploding too vigorously to give it the time of day.

author: Rex Reed
summary: Its eye is on the dirt floor of dullness.

author: Daniel Schindel
summary: The film insists upon its own relevance, but has none.

author: Tim Grierson
summary: While Eye In The Sky is effective in building suspense and making a talk-y drama compelling, these techniques are in service to high-minded, heavy-handed filmmaking that buries troubling wartime questions in simplistic rhetoric.

author: Mike Scott
summary: Despite the occasional outbreak of tension, it all ends up becoming repetitive as Eye in the Sky gets bogged down in the morality of it all, spinning its wheels for long stretches.

author: Michael Nordine
summary: The problem with movies depicting the banality of anything, of course, is that they tend to be pretty banal themselves; in setting out to be the exception to that rule, Eye in the Sky only proves it.

author: Christian Holub
summary: Masterminds has been “coming soon” for so long it would put "Batman v Superman" to shame, but the end result is an entertaining comic thriller with physical showcases for many of Saturday Night Live’s best recent veterans.

author: Matt Zoller Seitz
summary: If smart dumb comedies hold a place in your heart, you'll like Masterminds. The main characters are masterminds only in their own heads, and the thoughts that tumble out of their mouths are as nonsensical as they are sincere.

author: Mick LaSalle
