summary: Some of it is so predictable you could set your watch by it, but there is a welcome (and surprising) layer of complexity running through the film that makes it a little bit more than your standard fare. The likable and funny ensemble helps too.

author: Glenn Kenny
summary: The scenarios and their attendant psychologies are utterly conventional, but the characters and cast are appealing in equal measure.

author: Katie Walsh
summary: The facade the film offers is a lovely, and mildly diverting one, but there’s little insight to be found below the surface.

author: Dylan Kickham
summary: As if to make up for the predictable main plot, The Perfect Match is bogged down with a slew of uninteresting B-stories.

author: John Fink
summary: Neatly wrapping it all up in a bow, right down to big reveals and reconciliations, The Perfect Match offers not nearly enough twists on a tired formula.

author: Alonso Duralde
summary: It doggedly follows the well-worn rom-com path, down to saving all the personality and occasional laughs – very, very occasional ones – for the supporting cast.

author: Scott Tobias
summary: An attractive and appealing cast helps this formulaic pablum go down easy, but the genial tone buffs the edge out of every element.

author: Jesse Hassenger
summary: Plenty of romantic comedies lack any demonstrable knowledge of actual human behavior. The Perfect Match lacks any demonstrable knowledge of movie behavior, too.

author: Joshua Rothkopf
summary: By allowing viewers to step into the shoes of a wall-climbing Jackie Chan, a parkour-sprinting Daniel Craig or a bullet-spraying Ahnold, it does something that live action has never attempted before. The carnage flies—it’s possible to miss a lot of it. But if action movies are meant to be stunning, Hardcore Henry can proudly take its place among the giants. Even better, it lets you stand with them.

author: Josh Kupecki
summary: The film is an exhilarating and inventive spectacle that makes every other action film from the last 10 years look as obsolete as the Lumière brothers running that train at you back in 1896.

author: Brad Wheeler
summary: Is it much of a movie? Not really. It’s more of an experience – a passive sort of virtual reality – that uses a bare-bones narrative as a vehicle for a big-time body count.

author: Stephen Garrett
summary: A head-spinning, whirling dervish of an action movie.

author: Ed Gonzalez
summary: The film's unbelievably precise choreography of action seeks to tap into a universal feeling of powerlessness.

author: Dennis Harvey
summary: Hardcore feels like umpteen post-“Star Wars” action blockbusters trash-compacted into one — and whether that fundamentally appeals or not, the ingenuity of effort is undeniably high.

author: Stephen Dalton
summary: Hardcore blasts along like a supercharged computer-game shoot-em-up, bursting with sick humor and splatterpunk violence.

author: Ethan Vestby
summary: It feels longer than 90 minute because, despite changing locations frequently enough, Ilya Naishuller‘s debut feature never really has a strong sense of structure nor escalation to make it as truly kinetic as it wants. Yet, at least to some degree, the right spirit is there to lift it through some of the deadening stretches.

author: Dave White
summary: Presented with a moral universe where annihilation is all, it’s difficult to invest in the film as anything more significant than a breathless series of punishing vignettes.

author: Peter Travers
summary: It's all about the ride, the relentless wallop and whoosh. But, hey, sometimes that's all a cine-junkie needs for a fix.

author: Simon Abrams
summary: Hardcore Henry is like a good roller-coaster in that it does not require a complex reason to be: it's there, it's fun, you ride it, and that's about it.

author: Eric Kohn
summary: It never crystallizes into a singular experience, and instead collapses in a rush of well-intentioned innovations.

author: Chuck Wilson
summary: You have a movie with everything it needs save one crucial element: emotion.

author: Chris Nashawaty
summary: A hypercaffeinated first-person action flick that teeters somewhere between gonzo insanity and a nausea-inducing endurance test.

author: Michael O'Sullivan
summary: The sense of goofy, if gory, good humor [Copley] brings to Hardcore Henry goes a long way toward mitigating the film’s tedious barbarity.

author: Tom Russo
summary: When the action is at its sharpest, such as with Henry’s mid-chase leap from a detonating truck onto the back of a motorcycle, it’s spectacular.

author: Michael Ordoña
summary: If one can accept the story’s videogame logic and cope with the kinetosis, “Hardcore” is often exhilaratingly extreme.

author: Sarah Kurchak
summary: The film starts to risk adrenaline fatigue after the first hour.

author: Ignatiy Vishnevetsky
summary: Shot with head-mounted GoPro cameras, the Russian-made action flick Hardcore Henry mimics the experience of watching someone else play a very derivative first-person shooter with sub-Duke Nukem humor.

author: Russ Fischer
summary: Sure, there's a bit of spectacle to the film's utterly ridiculous violence. Even that dulls, however, without character or stakes to inject urgency into the parade of broken bodies.

author: Robert Abele
summary: Hardcore Henry is a single-gear novelty that never achieves real liftoff.

author: Glenn Kenny
summary: Its dour eccentricity gives Hardcore Henry a potency above and beyond that of standard-issue show-off action fare. That doesn’t mean it’s not still obnoxious, though.

author: Joe Morgenstern
summary: The film turned out to be plodding and boring. No one can accuse Hardcore Henry of being plodding. It does get to be boring, but in the high-tech, cutting-edge mode of first-person-shooter videogames that dazzle your eyes, spark your synapses and numb your brain.

author: Ben Nicholson
summary: The visuals are undeniably impressive at times, as Henry parkours around the city or during a particularly tense shoot-out, but they also struggle with inevitable motion sickness of the frenetic handheld camerawork.

author: Jordan Hoffman
summary: Naishuller’s technique is one that could be well served as a shorter gimmick; a solitary action scene in a larger film. Hardcore is unrelenting and unforgiving in its commitment to be loud, fast, destructive and gross.

author: Tirdad Derakhshani
summary:
Never again let it be said that an action movie is just like a video game.
Hardcore Henry, a frenetic, dizzying, and ultraviolent actioner from Russian rocker-turned-director Ilya Naishuller is one - a first-person shooter writ large for the big screen.

author: Roger Moore
summary: Hardcore Henry is jarring and so a-cinematic that I couldn’t enjoy much of the technical razzle-dazzle this ticking-clock monstrosity was hurling at me.

author: Barbara VanDenburgh
summary: While its audacity is laudable, the film ultimately has all the thrill of watching someone else play a first-person-shooter video game.

author: Kyle Smith
summary: It’s breathtaking. It’s dazzling. It’s world-altering, is what it is. For the first time ever, a movie has actually done it. Hardcore Henry has precisely replicated the experience of watching someone else play a video game.

author: Stephen Whitty
summary: Stupid as a bag of hammers and twice as loud, Hardcore Henry sounds like the title of the worst Kissinger bio ever. Actually, it's an action movie that feels more like you are trapped in a video game. A really, really bad video game.

author: A.O. Scott
summary: In Ms. Nair’s hands, Phiona’s story has a richness and unpredictability that separates it from other, superficially similar movies. It also has the buoyant, cleareyed feel for the particulars of culture and place that is among this director’s great gifts.

author: Claudia Puig
summary: This humanistic tale, helmed by a masterful filmmaker, offers a potent — and yes, inspirational — story of triumph against huge odds.

author: Michael Phillips
summary: Nair's film, her best in a long time, is hardly the first to use a chessboard as a symbol of one life's struggles. It is, however, one of the best.

author: Moira Macdonald
summary: Just try to resist the charms of Mira Nair’s Queen of Katwe, a triumph-of-the-human-spirit movie that’s ultimately, well, triumphant.

author: Tasha Robinson
summary: Nair's film is a joyous triumph in the way it makes the story accessible, without losing sight of the specifics that make it not just a true story, but a complete and real one.

author: Blake Goble
summary: Queen of Katwe shows that a film doesn’t have to give up on the tenets of genre, but has the potential to win big if it can enliven them in new ways.

author: Matthew Anderson
summary: Nair gets the very finest from her cast and although like Phiona we can see a number of moves ahead, the director's graceful, heartfelt retelling of this miraculous story makes Queen of Katwe a wondrously uplifting film.

author: Robbie Collin
summary: Put simply, you care about the Katwe kids because he does, and in the same way, too – not with high-strung melodramatic concern, but a warm glow of empathy in your gut. That’s stoked up in part by the film’s keen eye for telling, truthful-feeling detail.

author: Olly Richards
summary: Its plot isn’t going to win any prizes for originality, but Nair tells the story with immense warmth and cheer. You can see just about every move coming, but it’s making all the right ones.

author: Joe Morgenstern
summary: It’s family entertainment in the freshest sense of the term, a biographical drama, based on a true story, that vibrates with more colors — emotional as well as visual — than I can name.

author: Stephen Whitty
summary: Although the script is a little flat — just because the story is true doesn't mean it should feel so predictable — Nair gives the film tons of energy and joy.

author: Catherine Shoard
summary: For what is, in essence, a by-numbers Disney sports flick, there’s endless freshness and vivacity to Mira Nair’s picture – her best in years.

author: Cath Clarke
summary: If you’re the person who watches weepies with a cynical curl of the lip, this  isn’t the film for you. Everyone else, prepare to have your heartstrings plucked.

author: Marjorie Baumgarten
summary: Rises above the usual underdog sports cliches to become something quite affecting and distinctive.

author: Lawrence Toppman
summary: The honesty of the performances more than makes up for slight amounts of hokiness in the telling.

author: Rex Reed
summary: A rewarding family film indeed, at a time when we badly need one.

author: Roger Moore
summary: It’s overlong and rarely surprising, but Nair skillfully plays the limited board this story gives her, a queen among filmmakers making all the right moves.

author: Jimmy Geurts
summary: The film is able to overcome some of its narrative familiarity just by showcasing characters, locations and music we rarely see on screen. Having Monsoon Wedding director Mira Nair at the helm also brings a visual vibrancy and communal energy to the proceedings.

author: Peter Travers
summary: The British, Nigerian-born Oyelowo has proved himself an actor of extraordinary power in roles as diverse as Dr. Martin Luther King in "Selma" and the resentful son of a White House servant in "The Butler." As Robert, the actor radiates warm humor and quiet strength.

author: Peter Rainer
summary: Well, it is shameless, and it tugs the heart in all the obvious places, but it has a winning vivaciousness and a trio of performances by its lead actors that transcend its “inspirational” niche.

author: Tirdad Derakhshani
summary: This terrific film and its inspirational message have been filtered through an individualistic, American point of view, suggesting that anyone can make a better life for themselves if they are willing to work. And that's not the case everywhere.

author: Brian Truitt
summary: There is no lack of Disney-fied melodrama, for sure, yet Queen fights through all that with outstanding acting, deft filmmaking choices and the introduction of a new talent in Madina Nalwanga.

author: Matt Brennan
summary: The film is a mere fulfillment of familiar tropes, but it approaches sports movie's conventions with a light, funk-inflected touch.

author: Calvin Wilson
summary: An inspiring but formulaic film about triumph over adversity.

author: Ty Burr
summary: Lupita Nyong’o (“12 Years a Slave”) finally gets a movie role worthy of her status as an Oscar winner. She isn’t hidden behind pixels, as in “Star Wars: The Force Awakens” or “The Jungle Book.” You can see her. She’s magnificent.

author: Katie Rife
summary: In some ways, the more novel element is the film’s depiction of chess, which in Katwe is a popular sport on the level of football. And while that might seem unlikely, it’s accurate, at least in the wake of Mutesi’s success.

author: Richard Roeper
summary: This still works as a solid Disney sports movie because of the remarkable story, Mira Nair’s energetic and uplifting direction, and one of the most endearing casts I’ve enjoyed in any movie this year.

author: Gregory Ellwood
summary: The picture is genuinely entertaining and moving, but the fact it even exists in the first place is something you simply cannot dismiss.

author: Brian Tallerico
summary: It seems unlikely that Phiona Mutesi ever imagined her life would one day be the subject of a Disney film. But she certainly learned that life is full of surprises. When it comes to movie surprises, Queen of Katwe is a truly pleasant one.

author: Erin Whitney
summary: It shirks the typical Disney model of an untouchable, picturesque fantasy by telling a more grounded, human story coursing with love and earnestness.

author: Matt Donato
summary: Queen Of Katwe is pretty typical Disney magic, but dynamic performances add a little more oomph to Phiona Mutesi's amazing true story.

author: Bilge Ebiri
summary: Nair's immersive, energetic style, combined with her talented cast's ability to invest even the most obvious lines with genuine feeling, gives Queen of Katwe a powerful clarity.

author: Geoff Berkshire
summary: The film’s strongest assets are undoubtedly its actors.

author: Sara Stewart
summary: Sometimes, it’s enough to walk out of a film with your heart warmed — even if your brain’s still craving a little something more.

author: Stephanie Merry
summary: Subtlety isn’t the strong suit of Queen of Katwe. But beneath the hackneyed aphorisms, there’s a thrilling story worthy of our attention.

author: James Mottram
summary: While there’s sweetness, the big, sweeping emotions you hope for never quite arrive.

author: Sheri Linden
summary: Even with director Mira Nair’s typically vivid sense of place and the charismatic central performances by David Oyelowo, Lupita Nyong’o and a striking newcomer, the film hits every note of plucky positivity so squarely on the head that it leaves little room for audience involvement.
Nyong’o’s gravitas is undercut by a script teeming with wooden platitudes, special lessons learned, and the overbaked dialogue of a Joan Crawford melodrama.

author: Eric Kohn
summary: No amount of strong performances and good vibes can hide the sense that we’re just watching a paint-by-numbers routine. Nair puts so much effort into galvanizing the movie’s central figures that the slightest hints of conflict register as little more than an inconvenience.

author: Tim Grierson
summary: Perhaps it’s simplistic to say that director Mira Nair has fashioned a good-looking but Disney-fied version of actual events, and yet the studio’s predictably uplifting-at-all-costs blandness slowly but methodically drains the material of its richness.

author: Peter Debruge
summary: Whether dangling characters off the edge of a cliff or zooming around Crusoe’s rickety wooden waterslide, the story is constantly on the go, launching objects and characters along the Z axis — and out over the audiences’ heads.

author: Sheila O'Malley
summary: The film tries to pack in a little bit too much in its running time, and there isn't a comedic moment until well into the film, a strange choice in a movie for kids, but The Wild Life has its moments of charm, hilarity, and slapstick that worked really well.

author: Helen T. Verongos
summary: The Wild Life is pretty to look at, with its skies and ocean, calm or stormy, and it has a driving soundtrack. But the story lacks that extra layer of complexity and meaning that parents can appreciate.

author: Jordan Mintzer
summary: It’s all rather trite if easygoing entertainment aimed at the 6-and-under set, with A Turtle’s Tale creator Ben Stassen (credited as producer) and director Vincent Kesteloot delivering a colorful 3D adventure that lacks the sophistication of a Zootopia or Kung Fu Panda, but thankfully avoids some of their snark as well.

author: Katie Walsh
summary: The Wild Life is a family-friendly take on the story of Crusoe, with a twist, and kids no doubt will be drawn to the colorful animal characters, but there's a lack of emotional connection that makes the film just another cartoon flick, not a special favorite or animated classic.

author: Raakhee Mirchandani
summary: Felines, too often maligned as conniving and sly, get no love in The Wild Life, a tale that's inspired by Robinson Crusoe and perpetuates dangerous kitty stereotypes. And that's the best part of the movie.

author: Mike McCahill
summary: Each helter-skelter turn throws up story and design elements you’ll have seen better programmed elsewhere.

author: Steve Davis
summary: Any adult attending this film with a pre-K offspring may need to reassure the child afterward that little Tigger back home won’t devour him in his sleep. No kidding. They’re that scary. The Wild Life is an ailurophobe’s nightmare.

author: Andrew Parker
summary: It’s dreadfully boring to anyone over the age of 4, but at least it isn’t trying to sell kids anything. I guess that’s a plus.

author: Tom Russo
summary: The Wild Life, while pleasant, is just too flat to meet the challenge.

author: Roger Moore
summary: The colors are vibrant, the sea, palm trees, birds, bird-feathers and Crusoe’s red hair are almost photo-realistic. But as a kids’ cartoon, Wild Life is a an utter dud.

author: Stephanie Merry
summary: A few minutes of excitement can’t compensate for an hour and a half of unimaginative storytelling and dull characters.

author: Soren Andersen
summary: All things considered, this pitifully plotted Belgian-French production represents the nadir of animated movies released so far this year, a farrago of frantic action and mindless cacophony.

author: Sara Stewart
summary: So dull, the kids in my audience didn’t laugh until 45 minutes in — And that was at a coconut head-bonk, a gag so timeless it almost doesn’t count.

author: Michael Ordoña
summary: It’s bland. It’s benign.

author: Ignatiy Vishnevetsky
summary: The sort of uninspired international pre-sales item that usually goes straight from a basement booth at the Cannes film market to a Netflix parent’s peripheral vision. The sole interesting thing about NWave’s animation is its use of the camera, which plays to 3-D’s pop-out factor.

author: Claudia Puig
summary: Nothing feels remotely fresh, let alone savage or zany in The Wild Life. It’s a dull, uninspired and frantically tedious animated re-telling of the Robinson Crusoe story, complete with a menagerie of ditzy, caterwauling beasts.

author: Darren Franich
summary: Here’s what you didn’t expect: That The Brothers Grimsby, an upstairs-downstairs spy comedy, would be Cohen’s best work in a decade.

author: Gersh Huntzman
summary: If you like dumb gross-out comedies featuring men fellating each other, double entendres about penises and feces, and an obsession with the anus straight out of elementary school, you’ll love Sacha Baron Cohen’s latest effort. If you don’t, what, pray tell, is wrong with you?!

author: Robbie Collin
summary: Grimsby doesn’t ever wound quite as devastatingly as Borat or Brüno, but it’s a vital, lavish, venomously profane two fingers up at Benefits Street pity porn and the social division it fosters. I laughed, winced, gagged, then laughed even more.

author: Bilge Ebiri
summary: Mostly, The Brothers Grimsby simply wants to make you laugh. And it will. Whether you're laughing because the jokes are actually funny or because you can't quite believe that you just saw what you did...well, that's between you and your god.

author: Tim Cogshell
summary: The raunchy awfulness of The Brothers Grimsby is overwhelmed by a constant flow of chuckles, guffaws and flat-out belly laughs it elicits throughout.

author: Blake Goble
summary: Grimsby’s provocative, but not stupid. It knows what kind of humor it wants to achieve, and often scores big.

author: John Fink
summary: As far as straightforward crude comedies go, The Brothers Grimsby succeeds at times, even if the confines of narrative cinema restrict just how wild Sacha Baron Cohen can be.

author: Demetrios Matheou
summary: The comedy is as broad as it could be, knee-deep in political incorrectness and bad taste. But as ever with Cohen, it's fueled by such imagination and daft abandon that what ought to be offensive becomes hilarious.

author: Barry Hertz
summary: When the film’s pace slows down every now and then, and Cohen gets room to breathe, the film is a genuine riot.

author: Rene Rodriguez
summary: No, it’s not all that sophisticated. But compared to glib junk like Zoolander 2, The Brothers Grimsby is practically high art. Unlike Ben Stiller, at least Cohen is trying.

author: David Edelstein
summary: Parts of The Brothers Grimsby are very funny.

author: Stephanie Zacharek
summary: Nine out of ten gags in this crude pub crawl of a comedy are indefensible. Maybe ten out of ten. Tragically, perhaps, I laughed anyway: It’s so hard to know what to laugh at anymore, and what it’s OK to laugh at.

author: Dave Calhoun
summary: Nobby is hardly a character for the ages. He's a basic fool. The movie, too, is chaotic and crude. But its lack of sophistication, like its odd mix of souped-up action and base comedy, ultimately feels like a badge of honour.

author: Fionnuala Halligan
summary: Sacha Baron Cohen didn’t become a household name by pulling his punches. While his latest subversion Grimsby is ostensibly a routinely lowbrow British comedy, it’s also a something of stealth device to test the waters as to how far down he can bottom-feed.

author: Nick Schager
summary: Cohen’s willingness to do, or say, anything in order to elicit a chuckle at least somewhat salvages The Brothers Grimsby — right up to a riotously nasty climactic gag shoved down the throat of Donald Trump.

author: Jesse Hassenger
summary: Eventually, though, The Brothers Grimsby runs out of room to fully work as a hit-or-miss comedy — and perhaps most disappointing, doesn’t reserve any of its hits for co-stars Isla Fisher, Rebel Wilson, Gabourey Sidibe, and Penelope Cruz; it’s a great, diverse female cast assembled to do not very much.

author: Robert Abele
summary: It's not unfunny in spots, but it huffs and puffs (among other bodily functions) more often than it splits the sides.

author: Peter Travers
summary: It's the strafing satire that's MIA.

author: Leslie Felperin
summary: Baron Cohen and Strong are both robustly physical performers, and their finest moments are when they’re grappling with each other, producing a great tangle of limbs and teeth. But the script, credited to Baron Cohen, Phil Johnston and Peter Baynham (based on a story by Baron Cohen and Johnston), is not especially generous to the other members of the cast.

author: Jordan Adcock
summary: Grimsby fails in its satirical mission due to a hodgepodge of generic action and ill-advised comedy.

author: Neil Smith
summary: The strange thing about Grimsby is that it works much better as a Bond-spoofing actioner than it does as a politically incorrect rib-tickler.

author: Guy Lodge
summary: Baron Cohen’s unflinching ability to play dumb is still good for a few chuckles, making some of the film’s funniest moments out of its most innocent quips.

author: Peter Bradshaw
summary: Grimsby has the occasional laugh and a succession of finely wrought grossout spectaculars which are reasonably entertaining.... But with its cod-Bond and mock-action material it carries a weird overall feel, like kids’ TV but produced on a lavish scale with added filth.

author: Glenn Kenny
summary: As a full movie experience this did not drop my jaw in a consistently enjoyable way. And the movie’s Trump joke is pretty ineffectual. Sad!

author: Elise Nakhnikian
summary: The film doesn't do much to satirize the spy genre, instead using its flimsy plot mostly as a scaffolding for a barrage of jokes.

author: Brian Truitt
summary: Isn’t nearly as funny as it thinks it is spoofing spy tropes and buddy films and making a mockery of AIDS, politicians, movie stars and working-class Brits.

author: Kyle Smith
summary: As a comedy, The Brothers Grimsby is weak and scattershot, but it’s useful as an unintended self-indictment of the chattering classes’ disgust and disdain for white working folk.

author: Stephanie Merry
summary: The Brothers Grimsby is fitfully, sometimes outrageously, funny. But Cohen’s shtick of showing the backwardness and stupidity of unprivileged characters is starting to feel lazy, not to mention classist itself.

author: Manohla Dargis
summary: Mr. Cohen just seems off his game in “Grimsby,” and it may be that the movie’s high concept proved too constricting for someone who has done some of his best work (as in the “Borat” film) with a looser, more episodic format.

author: Roger Moore
summary: 83 minutes of excruciating, nauseating, boundary-pushing “comedy” that never for a second feels like it’s anything but visual evidence of the end of Sacha Baron Cohen’s comic leading-man career.

author: Helen O'Hara
summary: It may occasionally shock a laugh from you, but between those moments your face will be a rictus of horror.

author: James Berardinelli
summary: This movie is so atrocious I kept waiting for Nick Cage to show up.

author: Marc Savlov
summary: This is Baron Cohen’s worst film, period.

author: Drew McWeeny
summary: An entirely laughless affair and easily the low point of Cohen's career so far.

author: Odie Henderson
summary: This down-to-earth approach works surprisingly well because Southside with You never loses sight of the primary tenet of a great romantic comedy: All you need is two people whom the audience wants to see get together—then you put them together.

author: Steve Persall
summary: Even if their names were John and Mary, the two people soon to be a couple at the center of Southside With You could make viewers swoon. Richard Tanne's walk-and-talk slice of budding romantic life is that good at expressing those small moments when love begins taking hold.

author: Peter Travers
summary: Both Sawyers and Sumpter are terrific, world-class charmers who suggest the powerhouses they're playing without undue mimickry.

author: Moira Macdonald
summary: It’s a sweet-natured, gentle film that might remind more than a few watchers of a special date in their own life, long ago.

author: Richard Roeper
summary: Southside with You is a sweet, intelligent, well-crafted, wonderfully romantic, no-frills re-imagination of the first date between Barack Obama and Michelle Robinson.

author: Drew McWeeny
summary: Southside With You is quietly romantic, but more than that, it burns with a deep sense of optimism.

author: A.A. Dowd
summary: The first feature from writer-director Richard Tanne is sweetly speculative historical fiction — a date movie with some very recognizable lovebirds.

author: Sam Adams
summary: For all its presidential trappings, the movie is most powerful as a straightforward romance with two endlessly charming black leads, of a kind that, as far as movies go, is outrageously rare.

author: Matt Maytum
summary: The flow of the date doesn’t roll as smoothly as Linklater’s best walk-and-talkers, but that doesn’t mar the effectiveness of this refreshingly smart date movie.

author: Bernard Boo
summary: The measured performances make Southside With You feel sincere and rooted in human emotion rather than a wink-winky account of an important day in American history.

author: Robbie Collin
summary: Southside With You all but begs you to unpick every line and gesture for shivery echoes of the future, and it’s to first-time writer-director Tanne’s credit – and, equally, that of his perfectly chosen leads, Parker Sawyers and Tika Sumpter – that the film not only withstands but thrives under such scrutiny.

author: Dave Calhoun
summary: It’s a small, successful sketch of now-great lives.

author: Edward Douglas
summary: What makes Southside With You work so beautifully is that it could be a romantic comedy about two strangers, but because the characters are based on two people we feel we know pretty well, it adds another layer to the unfolding relationship drama.

author: Todd McCarthy
summary: The result makes you realize how few realistic and three-dimensional date movies have been made in an era of throbbing hook-up encounters and R-rated horny teen gross-outs.

author: Justin Chang
summary: Richard Tanne’s writing-directing debut deepens into a pointed, flowing conversation about the many challenges (and varieties) of African-American identity, the need for both idealism and compromise, and the importance of making peace with past disappointments in order to effect meaningful change in the future.

author: Steve Davis
summary: As in Richard Linklater’s lovely "Before Sunrise," the film’s principal pleasure comes from watching two people connect as they get to know each other over the course of several hours.

author: Barry Hertz
summary: A simple film only designed to charm.

author: Tirdad Derakhshani
summary: Relative newcomer Parker Sawyers (Zero Dark Thirty, Survivor) is terrific as Barack, embodying the character in each line and gesture without mimicking the real Obama.

author: Kyle Smith
summary: A pleasingly low-key effort pitched at fans of the first couple.

author: Mick LaSalle
summary: Southside With You proves once and for all that a romantic film doesn’t rely on suspense. We know these people are getting together. What holds us to our seats is wondering how it will happen.

author: Peter Keough
summary: Their non-specific excursion unfolds like a blithe Woody Allen movie without all the name-dropping.

author: Leah Greenblatt
summary: Southside doesn’t hang on epiphanies; instead, it delivers something more modest: a tender, unrushed love story.

author: Michael Phillips
summary: Southside with You is best taken as a reminder of the value of the slow relational build, of taking your time and actually talking, and actually listening, with someone new. Even if there's not a staggering political future in your shared future.

author: Ann Hornaday
summary: Like the warm summer day it chronicles, Southside With You possesses a mellow, languorous vibe, an infectious easygoing charm that insinuates itself gently, then seductively, as the couple at its center experiences the stirrings of what might be true love.

author: Roger Moore
summary: Tanne has crafted a winning film of smart, probing conversation that plays like an affectionate going away gift to the Obamas.

author: Eric Kohn
summary: While a bit too enamored of the foreshadowing built into its premise, Tanne's impeccably acted two-hander examines the Obamas through an infectious, talky script loaded with keen observations, not unlike the appeal of its subjects.

author: Noel Murray
summary: The movie holds to a steady but too-straight rhythm, hitting all the expected romantic-drama beats, right down to the occasional argument that threatens to stop the date cold. But Southside With You is also winningly sweet and earnest, and refreshingly frank about the problems that minorities face when they try to get ahead in a culture dominated by white males.

author: Michael Roffman
summary: Southside with You is a rewarding bite-sized drama, rich with characters who we already know, but also don’t really know.

author: Jordan Raup
summary: Most nuanced and effective in the feeling of getting to know someone the first time, when the evident foretelling is put to the side, this is simply an absorbing love story.

author: Dana Stevens
summary: Sumpter nails the first lady’s air of warm but reserved composure and the slow, careful way she enunciates her words, as if putting an extra measure of thought into choosing each phrase.

author: Erin Whitney
summary: Southside With You’s greatest assets are its performances.

author: Kenneth Turan
summary: “Southside” does have its standard, conventional aspects, but it was a popular Sundance item despite that, in large measure because of the performances of its finely matched pair of stars.

author: Barbara VanDenburgh
summary: When the material falters, Sumpter and Sawyers suck you back in with their pitch-perfect performances.

author: Tim Grierson
summary: Though sometimes achingly on-the-nose in its attempts to foreshadow these characters’ destiny, Southside With You radiates enough wistful charm to overcome the well-meaning earnestness.

author: Oliver Jones
summary: It is just that when some of its lines fall flat, pulling in portents of a future we all know well, it wakes us from a dream few of us want to be over.

author: Kenji Fujishima
summary: The film may not announce itself as hagiography, but it’s hero-worshipful to its core.

author: Matthew Anderson
summary: Southside with You doesn't leave a lasting impact because it plays all elements altogether too safe.

author: Olly Richards
summary: Even if you didn’t know what comes next, this story of the first days of the Obamas would still seduce as a sweet, smart romance.

author: David Edelstein
summary: The movie is charming even when it’s stilted, and it’s often stilted.

author: April Wolfe
summary: Both actors occasionally hit stumbling blocks with the wordy script and Tanne's direction, neither of which allows quite enough room for the characters to think and feel onscreen.

author: Jordan Hoffman
summary: Southside With You uses our affection for the Obamas to add urgency in the otherwise simple script.

author: Manohla Dargis
summary: Mr. Tanne has clearly made a close study of his real-life inspirations, yet his movie is soon hostage to the couple’s history. His characters feel on loan and, despite his actors, eventually make for dull company because too many lines and details serve the great-man-to-be story rather than the romance.

author: Joe Leydon
summary: Offers a relatively fresh take on standard-issue exorcism-melodrama tropes, along with a performance by Aaron Eckhart that is more than persuasive enough to encourage the investment of a rooting interest.

author: Noel Murray
summary: Dense with plot and mythology, the film is refreshingly unpredictable — if only because guessing what comes next would require understanding what the hell is going on.

author: Katie Rife
summary: Incarnate is a comic-book movie in search of a comic book.

author: Matt Donato
summary: Incarnate is just another buried Blumhouse special, and I assure you its neglect is with good reason.

author: Marc Savlov
summary: Incoherent mashup of previous demonized tyke films and unfailingly inept pseudo-science and the result is about as devoid of suspense, much less genuine horror, as this specific sub-genre can be.

author: Frank Scheck
summary: Incarnate, much like its central character at key moments, barely seems to have a pulse.

author: Roger Moore
summary: Dullness “Incarnate,” in other words.

author: Sam Fragoso
summary: Issues of continuity and logic pale in comparison to how the film forces Eckhart to act. It’s rare that we see someone as talented as Eckhart be relegated to work this shoddy and dispiriting.

author: Peter Sobczynski
summary: Incarnate is such a pointless bit of hackwork that it almost makes the recent horror dud “Shut In” seem focused by comparison.

author: Chris Hewitt (1)
summary: The premise sounds like an off-Broadway play gone wrong. Far from it — this is extraordinary, vital, and fuelled by great performances.

author: Jeffrey Bloomer
summary: Hilarious, deranged, and always alive with possibility.

author: Lawrence Toppman
summary: If I understand the intentions of writer-directors Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert, the film moved me profoundly. I’ll let you come up with your interpretation – or I’ll share mine privately, to avoid spoilers – but it’s a unique look inside a troubled mind.

author: Soren Andersen
summary: Sometimes hilarious, ultimately poignant, Swiss Army Man is a picture like no other.

author: Matt Zoller Seitz
summary: The Daniels have made a film that's at once a labor of love and a work of sheer arrogant nerve, one that is as likely to be described as a classic, an ambitious misfire, and one of the worst films ever made by any three people who see it together. How many movies can you say that about?

author: Eric Kohn
summary: This is pop art by way of lowbrow slapstick, with a premise that suggests "Cast Away" meets "Weekend at Bernie's," but really feels like a lunatic's idea of a big, broad studio comedy — or maybe a mad scientist's.

author: Paul Bradshaw
summary: Juvenile? Weird? Gross? Yes. But also the best flatulence-themed indie-comedy-musical-drama you’ll see this year.

author: Tim Robey
summary: Both actors, unfazed by the sheer oddity of their task, rise energetically to the occasion.

author: Jeannette Catsoulis
summary: Impossible to categorize, this stunningly original mix of the macabre and the magical combines comedy, tragedy, fantasy and love story into an utterly singular package that’s beholden to no rules but its own.

author: Steven Rea
summary: Swiss Army Man is a quest movie of sorts, and also a sort of modern-day piece of absurdist theater. Samuel Beckett by way of Monty Python, it is a story that is at once rooted in the fixations of adolescence (sex, the idea of sex, bodily functions, more sex) and in the loftier firmaments of the mind.

author: Richard Roeper
summary: You might walk out of Swiss Army Man. You might tire of the flatulence and the erections and the self-conscious whimsy. But if you stick with it, there’s a chance it’ll grow on you as it grew on me — and you’ll be rewarded with maybe the best ending of any movie so far this year.

author: Calvin Wilson
summary: If you’ve been looking for a film that puts a daringly surreal spin on “Cast Away,” you’ll be in paradise.

author: A.A. Dowd
summary: The easy elevator pitch on Swiss Army Man is that it’s "Cast Away" meets "Weekend At Bernie’s." Weird as that movie may sound, it’s not nearly as weird as the one actually cooked up by “Daniels,” a.k.a. Dan Kwan and Daniel Scheinert, the branded directing duo making its feature-length debut.

author: Christopher Gray
summary: Even as it invites snarky ridicule, the film dares you to buy into its singular earnestness.

author: Justin Gerber
summary: Frenzied, kinetic filmmaking is hit or miss, but The Daniels are showcasing their talents as opposed to showing off.

author: Bill Goodykoontz
summary: There are obviously a lot of parts here, and they don’t all fit together successfully; the shift in tone toward the end is particularly unsettling. But it’s not for lack of ambition on the part of the Daniels, nor the performances by Dano and Radcliffe.

author: Peter Debruge
summary: At times deliriously dynamic, at others patience-grating in the extreme, the constantly inventive film fires off ideas that are as exhilarating as anything American audiences will see all year, only to lag in long swells on either side.

author: Leslie Felperin
summary: It’s entirely to the directors and the two lead actors’ credit that what sounds like a bunch of overextended body humor gags of the most juvenile variety evolve, by sheer repetitious attrition, into something bizarrely poetic and strangely touching.

author: Marjorie Baumgarten
summary: It’s all kind of amusing, and that would be fine but for the fact that the filmmakers offer many openings where they seem to be in search of deeper meaning.

author: Stephanie Merry
summary: [The film] isn’t for everyone. But the story is astoundingly original. During the summer months, when theaters are occupied by superheroes and sequels, that’s something worth celebrating.

author: Roger Moore
summary: Whatever its qualities and shortcomings, Swiss Army Man makes one promise it most certainly keeps. You have never seen anything remotely like it.

author: Sara Stewart
summary: Daniel Radcliffe continues to propel himself further from his Harry Potter past, this time via straight-up flatulence: Swiss Army Man nearly makes up with juvenile glee what it lacks in plot and coherence.

author: Peter Travers
summary: There are times when this mindbending bromance actually achieves a twisted tenderness. There are also times when you'd like to ride Manny's farts to the nearest exit. It's your call.

author: John Bleasdale
summary: For the most part Swiss Army Man is a visually unique gas and only feels bloated when it tries to hitch its wayward originality to some sort of real world application.

author: Mike Scott
summary: You might love it or you might hate it, but you won't soon forget it -- and you won't be able to say you've seen a movie quite like Swiss Army Man before.

author: Alonso Duralde
summary: If Swiss Army Man were a silent, scoreless effort, presented as otherworldly slapstick, or if it had employed Lil Jon to yell some obliquely connected, thematic exhortations and non sequiturs, it might have reached the heights of its music video predecessor. As it plays out, though, it smells a little too much like teen spirit.

author: Tim Grierson
summary: Swiss Army Man is a powerfully audacious and wilfully odd odyssey that is too nervy and strangely emotional to dismiss outright but, ultimately, isn’t satisfying enough to provoke a full-throated defence, either.

author: Jordan Hoffman
summary: It’s coarse and it’s stupid, but it is, thanks mostly the two good performances and some stylish use of music and editing, a little bit moving.

author: Chris Nashawaty
summary: A hot, strange mess that never quite comes together the way it should.

author: Jordan Raup
summary: Swiss Army Man is an exceptionally unusual, one-of-a-kind achievement, worthy to seek out for that factor alone. However, if as much time was spent on refining the script as was the world-building, this could have been a magical realism fever dream like few others.

author: Barry Hertz
summary: That the film – part dark comedy and part cinematic dare – is the most unusual sight you’ll encounter at the movies this year is not up for debate.

author: Ty Burr
summary: This is a buddy movie in which one of the buddies is dead. Yet, if anything, the emotional bonding is — or wants to be — more resonant than ever.

author: Robert Abele
summary: Even with all the design-rich invention and admirably committed weirdness on display in “Swiss Army Man,” we’re still in the land of immature males, poor-me feelings and superpowers. While the movie focuses on one end of the body, you might be left sighing from the other.

author: Russ Fischer
summary: Swiss Army Man is a big swing — there's no denying the risk in putting two well-known actors in a film where one plays a barely-mobile corpse — but also a big whiff that rarely connects its characters and situations to humor or empathy.

author: Stephen Whitty
summary: Swiss Army Man's greatest challenge is to its audience. Just, exactly, how much will we sit still for? Endless scenes of Dano in role-playing drag, sporting a rag-mop wig and giving dating tips to a corpse? Frequent closeups of Radcliffe's furry flatulent buttocks?

author: Joshua Rothkopf
summary: A ridiculously infantile film, one that flatters itself by intimating a deeper comment about suppressed masculinity or romantic passivity.

author: Sheri Linden
summary: The thrilling premise of Morgan eventually gets muddled amid standard thriller-action, blunting the intended impact of a final sequence that should produce chills, but instead merely provides information. Still, those seeking smart, edgy genre fare will find plenty to savor in this well-cast drama.

author: James Berardinelli
summary: It’s an attempt to wed philosophical science fiction concepts with bloody horror - a dubious endeavor that somehow works. The movie doesn’t seek to be a mindless gore-fest but neither does it show restraint when it comes to violence.

author: Ellen Brait
summary: This isn’t to say Scott doesn’t occassionally rely on classic scary-movie thrills – but, mostly, it concentrates on developing its intriguing narrative and believable characters.

author: Katie Walsh
summary: The failure of Morgan is in its lack of restraint. The first half of the film is as tightly controlled as the lab facility, with small moments of foreshadowing planted expertly, if obviously. The second half descends into a violent bloodbath, and the twists in the story that lie just below the surface waiting to be discovered are spoken aloud, taken from theory to fact

author: Soren Andersen
summary: Anchored by Mara’s rigidly controlled performance and Taylor-Joy’s tremulous yet quietly menacing work, Morgan is an effective tension generator that unfortunately falls apart at the end.

author: Chris Nashawaty
summary: Is Morgan hardwired for violence, or is “she” just a synthetic naïf with a bloody glitch? Taylor-Joy and the rest of the ace cast make you care about the answer to that question. The script? Less so.

author: Randall Colburn
summary: Morgan isn’t hard sci-fi. It isn’t trying to solve the questions that have suffused the genre since its inception. Rather, it couches those ever-more-timely concerns in scenes of high action and affecting character connection.

author: April Wolfe
summary: Even if his film's plot is predictable, the younger Scott is returning the ensemble thriller to its roots with something far more important than an airtight story: compelling, well-drawn characters and the talented actors to play them.

author: Jesse Hassenger
summary: The director, Luke Scott (son of Ridley), doesn’t exactly elevate this material, but he does see it through. The voice of Brian Cox goads the action into Bourne territory to counter its "Ex Machina" overtones, but the movie works best when it riffs away from its antecedents into even more pitiless territory.

author: Alonso Duralde
summary: Whatever its flaws, this is a rare genre movie that allows two women — both Mara and Taylor-Joy are coolly riveting, particularly when they’re playing off each other — to take center stage in both the drama and the action, both of which get pretty intense.

author: Tirdad Derakhshani
summary: Anya Taylor-Joy, who delivered a heartrending breakout performance in "The Witch," is entrancing as this exotic being, Morgan.

author: Cath Clarke
summary: What Morgan lacks in philosophy and ideas, it makes up for in bone-crunching violence.

author: Bill Goodykoontz
summary: Scott does a nice job with the first part of the film, setting the stage for what is ultimately a disappointing conclusion.

author: John Anderson
summary: A mixed bag of a thriller that exploits two primal fears—of artificial intelligence, and precocious children.

author: Michael O'Sullivan
summary: In order for the trick of the film to work, however, one must hold Morgan to a standard that the movie is unlikely to live up to.

author: Peter Hartlaub
summary: The film tries to split the difference between thoughtful science fiction and action-driven horror, and blows the chance to truly succeed at either. Morgan is an enjoyable enough experience in the moment, but it never quite coalesces.

author: Susan Wloszczyna
summary: My diagnosis of why Morgan malfunctions as a chilling plunge into blood-splattered mayhem is that, before the midway point, it is pretty obvious what the eventual outcome and supposed big reveal will be. This is not the fault of the actors necessarily — there are highly respected talents involved here. It is just that we have seen most of this unfold before.

author: Tom Russo
summary: At its best, the movie is provocative, sleekly assured, and a legit showcase for its intriguingly deep ensemble

author: Fionnuala Halligan
summary: As more information is dispensed  - much of it in a rush in the final shots – the strength of Owen’s screenplay becomes clear but the issues it raises are largely left un-examined.

author: Owen Gleiberman
summary: It’s little more than a schlock replay of “Ex Machina.” It toys around with some of the same situations, but it doesn’t know where to take them. Instead of developing its themes, it uses them as grist for an overload of “commercial” action.

author: Kenji Fujishima
summary: The film's makers lose trust in the intellectual heft of their material and chose to prioritize empty sensation instead.

author: Amy Nicholson
summary: When no one is making believable choices, who cares who’s human? It’s all just lines of script.

author: Michael Snydel
summary: Morgan struggles to make even a single fight between two people not look like it was edited with a shredder.

author: Allen Salkin
summary: A lot makes me uneasy about where biology and technology are going. But Great Scott! Is Morgan really the best you can do?

author: Helen O'Hara
summary: It’s well designed and shot, but in service of a story that never coalesces into something intelligent or compelling.

author: Jeannette Catsoulis
summary: Dipping no more than a toenail in the philosophical waters surrounding personhood, the movie is at once ideologically vague and maddeningly self-serious.

author: Justin Chang
summary: It’s bland enough to serve as a kind of palate cleanser at the end of a long and punishing moviegoing summer.

author: Tasha Robinson
summary: This is a familiar tale: man creates monster, monster runs amuck, man regrets playing God. It's just never remotely clear what Scott and Owen found so compelling about this story that they wanted to tell it again, without meaningful variations, and in the immediate wake of better, smarter, more thrilling versions.

author: Roger Moore
summary: The story sets up a clumsy psycho-sexual dynamic and a faux family, but the film doesn’t develop those.

author: Kyle Smith
summary: A dull, listless, derivative chunk of celluloid lacking any spark or even basic storytelling ability.

author: Richard Roeper
summary: The only thing worse than the first three-quarters of Morgan is the supposed payoff, which veers from the dumb to the really dumb to the so-dumb-you’ll-hardly-believe-it. This is one of the worst movies of 2016.

author: Kate Erbland
summary: The film mistakes stiff, literally buttoned up acting — you’ve never seen so many starched and fully done up dress shirts in one film in your entire life — as somehow being clever, but there’s scarcely a moment of Morgan that is genuinely shocking (though the undercurrents with Amy are at least unnerving).

author: Steve Davis
summary: The entire plot exists for the sole purpose of the yawning revelation in the film’s last five minutes.

author: Ben Travers
summary: While it may seem instinctual to want an R-rated “Batman,” especially from a graphic novel that would deserve the rating without alterations, Batman: The Killing Joke is borderline unsettling — and not in a good way.

author: Richard Roeper
summary: Director John Madden (“Shakespeare in Love,” the “Exotic Marigold Hotel” movies) expertly juggles the various subplots while never losing his main focus, which is to showcase Jessica Chastain’s nearly infinite palette of acting shades.

author: Nick Schager
summary: Jessica Chastain is a great actress, but with Miss Sloane, she also proves that she’s a great movie star.

author: Joe Walsh
summary: While Chastain, and the surrounding cast, drive the narrative there is no denying that as time runs on it begins to unravel frustratingly, reaching an unsatisfying conclusion. Yet, Chastain's performance is one that lingers in the mind.

author: Tim Robey
summary: It’s addictive fantasy, satisfyingly snappy even in its absurdity, and something no Chastain fan can afford to miss.

author: Neil Smith
summary: Chastain stalks the corridors of power with steely aplomb in Madden’s coolly compelling incursion into House of Cards territory.

author: Justin Chang
summary: See this smart, showboating movie now, before its simmering sense of justice begins to feel like a thing of the past.

author: Todd McCarthy
summary: So intriguing are the driven, smart and compromised characters, and so infinite are the dramatic possibilities at the intersection of big business and politics, that a vastly expanded small-screen take built around these characters, and others like them, would be quite welcome..

author: James Berardinelli
summary: As a dramatic thriller, it does what it needs to do to keep the audience involved and interested, even if some of its most theatrical tricks and twists are more the products of a writer’s invention than actual Washington D.C. activities.

author: Calvin Wilson
summary: If you’ve been wondering how Washington really works, this film is required viewing.

author: Mick LaSalle
summary: Miss Sloane is one of the year’s handful of great actress vehicles, and Chastain takes this role by the throat, smashes it against the wall about ten times and then devours it while it’s still quivering. You want to see star acting on a grand scale? Miss Sloane is the movie to see.

author: Pat Padua
summary: This taut political thriller, set amid the soulless office architecture of K Street, has an ostensibly liberal bent, but its antiheroine’s Machiavellian methods turn the film’s subject away from its cause, portraying lobbyists and politicians in a dark light.

author: Brian Truitt
summary: The intelligent, timely and twisty thriller Miss Sloane introduces an antiheroine feared by both Republicans and Democrats. Jessica Chastain is all hellfire and high heels as powerful Washington lobbyist Elizabeth Sloane.

author: Leah Greenblatt
summary: Chastain fully commits to her boss-bitch persona, even if we only obliquely learn why she might have chosen such a lonely, mercenary life.

author: Peter Travers
summary: Sloane is a nasty piece of work. Yet Chastain draws us in, making us see what the character keeps inside by the sheer force of her fireball performance. There are times when Miss Sloane plays like a pilot for a TV series. No knock on that. If Chastain stars, I'm in.

author: Stephanie Zacharek
summary: Storytelling efficiency is one of Miss Sloane’s most effective calling cards — that, and Chastain.

author: Stephen Whitty
summary: Jessica Chastain plays Sloane, and she's the kind of Washington power-player who'd scare off half the cast of "Scandal" — towering heels, pulled-back hair and a taste for the kill.

author: Peter Debruge
summary: Miss Sloane is a talky, tense political thriller, full of verbal sparring and fiery monologues, undone by a really dumb ending. But that doesn’t mean it isn’t smart for most of its running time.

author: Randall Colburn
summary: Miss Sloane is a smart, thorough film about a rare subject that is also as breathless, broad, and crowd-pleasing as your standard Grisham thriller.

author: David Ehrlich
summary: In a movie that likens passing legislation to pulling off a massive heist, eventually departing from reality altogether in a series of late-game twists so intricate they would make Danny Ocean blush, the sheer velocity of Chastain’s performance holds it all together.

author: Roger Moore
summary: Miss Sloane is a Capital Hill tale in the “State of Play/House of Cards” mold, a melodramatic thriller more realistic than “Scandal,” slightly less riveting than “Scandal.”

author: Peter Keough
summary: It answers most questions by the end, except the most important one: Is the devil in Miss Sloane, or is Miss Sloane the devil?

author: Lawrence Toppman
summary: The portrait of Elizabeth Sloane grabs your interest, partly due to the presence of Jessica Chastain in the title role.

author: Sheila O'Malley
summary: The film is not so much tone-deaf as old-fashioned, emerging from a more innocent time (say, three weeks ago) when "politics as usual" actually had some meaning.

author: Kenji Fujishima
summary: The screenplay's enigmatic nature holds one's interest throughout, even as the film veers into pat moralism.

author: Anna Smith
summary: Hard to root for but mesmerising to watch, Sloane is expertly portrayed by Chastain in this dialogue-heavy lobbyist thriller that should please fans of both actor and genre.

author: Bill Goodykoontz
summary: It’s fun enough in places, outrageous (in mostly a good way) in others. Ultimately, however, the plot falters enough that it’s more like a two-hour audition for Great Actress. Chastain passes with flying colors, even if the movie doesn’t.

author: Matt Donato
summary: Rarely is a performance so strong that it’s able to carry an entire production, but – thankfully for John Madden – Chastain wills Miss Sloane into relevance through nothing but sophistication, spunk and champion grit.

author: Cath Clarke
summary: Chastain is a wonder. Her character could give Cersei Lannister in "Game of Thrones" lessons in cunning and wreaking vengeance.

author: Abbey Bender
summary: Miss Sloane, with all its Capitol Hill gloss, sometimes feels too much like a primetime political television drama.

author: Nigel M Smith
summary: Chastain single handedly prevents it all from veering off the rails by dominating Miss Sloane with her forceful presence. She grounds her heroine to ensure you’re with her.

author: Tim Grierson
summary: Miss Sloane is a shallow but lively thriller which becomes undermined by its makers’ misplaced belief in the profundity of their topical tale.

author: Steve Persall
summary: Chastain plows through this tangled scenario with an icy ferocity that's entertaining. You get the feeling that Miss Sloane would work better as a streaming or cable series, allowing more time to explore characters and issues, giving actors more room for dense dialogue. Maybe come up with a better way out of that corner.

author: Alonso Duralde
summary: Rather than take the time to let us really get to know and understand its complicated title character, the movie instead goes for cheap, gotcha plotting that undermines the entire project.

author: Kate Taylor
summary: Miss Sloane is a powerfully conceived thriller with something dead at its centre: there is no reason a female protagonist must be good or well-behaved, but she must at least be interesting.

author: Tirdad Derakhshani
summary: A disquieting and ultimately disappointing political thriller.

author: Kimberley Jones
summary: The film is less successful at exploring the chinks in her armor – the stuff that makes her human, and a person of interest. Chastain is great – she’s always great, right? – and the brittle braininess she radiates is the film’s crowning seduction.

author: Stephen Holden
summary: Partly because Miss Sloane is more a character study than a coherent political drama, it fumbles the issue it purports to address, and it eventually runs aground in a preposterous ending.

author: Jesse Hassenger
summary: The main problem is a dialogue-heavy script by first-time screenwriter Jonathan Perera that mistakes quantity of verbiage for quality.

author: Daniel Schindel
summary: It looks and feels less like a film and more like a feature-length pilot for a new TV series which happens to have a stacked cast.

author: Mike Scott
summary: Visually and tonally, Miss Sloane -- like Chastain's one-note performance, in which she does little but bark and glower -- is slick but soulless, a film that takes itself far too seriously and misjudges how smart it really is.

author: Kyle Smith
summary: Heavy-handed message movies don’t come more harrumphing than “Miss Sloane,” a clunky dramatization of the gun-control argument liberals still don’t understand is being conducted solely among themselves.

author: Christian Holub
summary: There simply aren’t enough scares to build tension throughout.

author: Jesse Hassenger
summary: Disappointments has the strange confidence of a much slicker, more decisive movie, and all of its sort-ofs don’t add up to much.

author: Stephen Farber
summary: Caruso’s direction is slick and fluid enough, and gifted cinematographer Rogier Stoffers (Quills, School of Rock) makes the most of the house’s dark, eerie corners. But the performances are highly variable. Beckinsale delivers the goods, but Mel Raido as her impatient husband David never generates much sympathy.

author: Joe Leydon
summary: There is more mood than matter to be sampled in “The Disappointments Room,” a spooky psychological thriller — or, perhaps, a psychological thriller with spooks — that is initially intriguing but ultimately, unfortunately, lives down to its title.

author: Marc Savlov
summary: The Disappointments Room lives (and dies) up to its name.

author: Katie Walsh
summary: The script telegraphs things, but also often descends into incoherence. It tries to be too many things at once, and ends up being nothing.

author: Robert Abele
summary: Named as if it knew its destiny, The Disappointments Room brings together those horror movie standbys that just can’t quit each other — a creepy old home and a troubled family — for some truly convoluted, non-scary, and execrable psychological mishegoss surrounding a hidden chamber and the noxious historical shame it holds.

author: Steve Persall
summary: Vallée's movie itself begins falling apart after being so artfully put together. Yet Gyllenhaal's performance is the center that holds, making Davis' melancholic obsession and irrational acts seem like the sanest things anyone could do. His disintegration is the actor's triumph.

author: Gregory Ellwood
summary: This sort of storyline could go wrong very quickly, but thanks to some fortuitously funny moments, Vallee’s assured direction and Gyllenhaal’s spectacular performance it’s surprisingly compelling.  And, let’s be absolutely clear: it’s Gyllenhaal who keeps it all together.

author: Kate Taylor
summary: The trouble here is that neither Bryan Sipe, who wrote this highly original script, nor Vallée, remain true to the bitter whimsy with which they began.

author: Sarah Kurchak
summary: Much like the characters themselves, all of these off-kilter and seemingly disparate elements come together far better than they should and something just a little beautiful happens as a result.

author: Alonso Duralde
summary: Demolition strikes a tricky balance; it’s a comedy of manners that never judges its hero’s bizarre behavior. Had it stuck to its emotional guns, it would stand much taller, but even its ultimate flaws can’t erode its sturdy foundation.

author: Peter Debruge
summary: Gyllenhaal grounds Davis’ wildly unraveling psyche, finding both the humor and heart in a man who admits to having spent the past 10 to 12 years incapable of feeling.

author: Jordan Mintzer
summary: It’s a unique take on what could otherwise be a morbidly depressing tale of loss and grief, dishing out tons of energy and spats of devilish humor, though not always fitting its numerous parts into a succinct whole.

author: Kate Erbland
summary: Demolition spends its goodwill early on, eventually giving itself over to cheap-feeling twists and a problematic final act.

author: Ann Hornaday
summary: The oddball grief drama Demolition proves that an actor who could easily be dismissed as just another watchable face is actually possessed of subtle, fascinatingly protean chops.

author: Ty Burr
summary: What keeps you interested in Demolition is accompanying Davis as he solves the mystery of himself. What keeps you checking your watch is that the character’s not terribly interesting to begin with.

author: Kyle Smith
summary: Demolition, written by Bryan Sipe is, like director Jean-Marc Vallée’s previous films “Wild” and “Dallas Buyers Club,” a tale of interior repair sought through obsessive and near-penitential acts, but it’s stranger and at times more interesting than those other two.

author: Soren Andersen
summary: By the end, it’s falling apart under the weight of all the extraneous divergings, but thanks to Gyllenhaal’s performance, Demolition stands out as a powerful meditation on the unhinging effects of deep grief.

author: Ian Nathan
summary: Vallée’s post-traumatic stress comedy is more scientific than genuinely moving. Nevertheless, Gyllenhaal continues his post-Nightcrawler upgrade with another vivid performance in the key of strange.

author: Joshua Rothkopf
summary: As scripted by Bryan Sipe, Demolition buries its lead actor under a rubble of clichés.

author: Bilge Ebiri
summary: Gyllenhaal and Watts's yin-yang performances help things along.

author: Mike Scott
summary: It feels very much like part of a big-screen franchise. Couple it with such films as "Donnie Darko" and "Nightcrawler," and you've got a series that collectively could be titled "Inside Jake Gyllenhaal's Head."

author: Bill Goodykoontz
summary: Unfortunately Jean-Marc Vallée’s film doesn’t measure up to Gyllenhaal’s performance.

author: Chris Nashawaty
summary: Jake Gyllenhaal’s wild-card performance is the only reason to bother with "Dallas Buyers Club" director Jean-Marc Vallée’s manipulative downer.

author: Peter Rainer
summary: The best I can say is that it’s another tour de force for Gyllenhaal, although his intensity isn’t matched by the movie itself, which sacrifices much of its power by too often settling for easy, nut-brain effects.

author: Ignatiy Vishnevetsky
summary: Despite a few electric moments, the movie never makes anything of its stylized displays of frustration, ending in a whiff of narrative and emotional cop-outs. Say what you will about "American Beauty," but at least it had a climax.

author: Roger Moore
summary: It’s an indulgent movie, drifting through grief on a sea of cliches.

author: Anthony Lane
summary: There is much to savor here, especially the unforced performance of Judah Lewis — one more recruit to the terrific roster of younger actors who are streaming into the movies. Yet the film lacks the courage of its affliction.

author: Glenn Kenny
summary: While Watts is reliably vulnerable, it’s Judah Lewis as her son Chris who does the heavier emotional lifting.

author: Stephanie Zacharek
summary: Vallée, working from a script by Bryan Sipe, packs in too many symbols and potent signifiers – some are harmless, others are literally sledgehammer heavy. The movie doesn’t need all that when it’s got Gyllenhaal.

author: Peter Travers
summary: When humor is served black, they call it dramedy. When it's done in this movie, I call it indigestible.

author: Calvin Wilson
summary: Offbeat and unpredictable, Demolition takes a wrecking ball to audience expectations.

author: Michael Phillips
summary: Gyllenhaal certainly holds the screen; at this point in his career, he has found a way to rise above whatever needs rising above. But midway through Demolition, I longed for a sequel to "Nightcrawler" instead.

author: Lawrence Toppman
summary: Demolition is a rarity: A film with a profound emotional truth at its heart that lies to us, scene by scene, from start to finish.

author: Walter Addiego
summary: There’s nothing wrong with stretching audience credibility, but, to quote another movie that dabbles in the highly improbable, these things must be done delicately.

author: Marjorie Baumgarten
summary: The filmmakers insert their own bulldozer midway through the story, rendering the metaphoric literal and the literal absurd.

author: Christopher Gray
summary: It takes its literalism to such an extreme that, at points, it's difficult to determine whether or not the film is operating with a semblance of irony.

author: Daniel Schindel
summary: Demolition might just be this year’s poster child for disaffected faux-indie insincerity.

author: Kenneth Turan
summary: Demolition is a well-meaning misfire, terribly earnest but unconvincing for all of that.

author: Stephen Whitty
summary: Demolition is a wreck.

author: Tim Grierson
summary: Though it’s laudable that Vallée and his cast tried not to make just another story about someone wallowing in his grief, their alternative coddles Davis’s mourning with a rampant colourfulness that’s suffocating.

author: Tim Robey
summary: Stuffed with so many strenuous editing ideas you suspect the influence of something illegal, Demolition is mainly casting about for a point, when it doesn’t feel like a wrecking ball aimed squarely at itself.

author: Benjamin Lee
summary: A frustratingly aimless soul-search that veers uncomfortably between quirk and melancholy.

author: James Berardinelli
summary: Demolition founders and its overt symbolism feels forced instead of organic. The production is uncomfortable and artificial, lacking internal logic and tonal consistency.

author: Richard Roeper
summary: What a mess. What a pretentious, uneven, off-putting, not-nearly-as-clever-as-it-thinkd-it-is MESS.

author: Rene Rodriguez
summary: Demolition is so busy trying to be profound, the film doesn’t have much use for humor.

author: Stephen Holden
summary: Mr. Gyllenhaal’s strong performance still doesn’t add enough substance to a film that is hollow at the center. It’s mostly the fault of Mr. Sipe, who seems to believe that saying nothing is saying something.

author: Kevin Jagernauth
summary: The film’s attempted cathartic payoff is inauthentic and unearned, and it’s a shame considering that Gyllenhaal once again gives a committed turn.

author: Peter Keough
summary: Tom Hiddleston puts in a performance as Williams that ranks with that of Joaquin Phoenix as Johnny Cash in “I Walk the Line.” And Hiddleston gets to do it in a better movie.

author: Lawrence Toppman
summary: The British actor, best known as Loki in the “Thor” and “Avengers” series, disappears into the character’s skinny body and twangy voice.

author: Paul de Barros
summary: If you don’t already care about Hank Williams, this movie isn’t likely to change that.

author: Richard Roeper
summary: Even when I Saw the Light is giving us standard-issue concert scenes or simple interior sequences such as young Hank and his band playing live on the radio, the saturated colors and the subtle camera moves make every scene pop.

author: Rex Reed
summary: It’s in the music that I Saw the Light best demonstrates how a tormented man named Hank Williams revolutionized the essence of country songs into a joy embraced by millions.

author: Brad Wheeler
summary: Perhaps a better name for Marc Abraham’s well-crafted biopic would be His Cheatin’ Heart, for this motion picture concentrates on the marital distress between a philandering Williams and his flat-singing wife (played with vibrancy by Elizabeth Olsen).

author: Tom Huddleston
summary: Perhaps inevitably, the film as a whole doesn't stack up to its central performances.

author: Chris Hewitt (1)
summary: Hiddleston and Olsen impress, and the music remains golden, but this is just another by-the-numbers biopic.

author: Kenneth Turan
summary: I Saw the Light is solid but not spectacular, a retelling of a sad story that never catches fire.

author: Jordan Mintzer
summary: It’s unfortunate that Light feels both too traditional and too concerned with showcasing life behind the music, instead of trying to explain why Williams was one of the greatest American musicians of the last century.

author: Jared Mobarak
summary: The extended musical performances showcase Hiddleston’s chops, but the script can’t provide enough assistance for us to care. He embodies Williams and the singer/songwriter’s story is up on screen, but I can’t say I remained interested beyond his transformation.

author: Connie Ogle
summary: I Saw the Light, though, doesn’t live up to Hiddleston’s efforts; it’s shallow and disjointed, handicapped by a weak, cliche-sodden script.

author: Steven Rea
summary: The feeblest kind of costume drama, where the costumes have more impact than the drama and where the period details serve only as distraction, reminding audiences that things looked different back then and not much else.

author: Sarah Kurchak
summary: It should be impossible to turn this kind of raw material into such an interminable slog, and yet somehow writer and director Marc Abraham...managed to do just that.

author: Mick LaSalle
summary: Surely, there’s the potential here for a kind of Country and Western “Amadeus.” Instead we get I Saw the Light, which will do until something better comes along.

author: Calvin Wilson
summary: If you’re interested in Williams and his music, this film is better than nothing — but not by much.

author: Michael Phillips
summary: Hiddleston, his eyes full of fire and melancholy longing, was an inspired choice. Everything not-quite-right with most movies, however, goes wrong long before the actors arrive on set.

author: Marjorie Baumgarten
summary: British actor Hiddleston transcendently captures the sound of Williams’ voice and his performative swagger, and it’s something that’s worth seeing for its amazing conjuring act.

author: Tricia Olszewski
summary: Hiddleston, who does his own singing, doesn’t get to show off his chops very often. But when he does, the film comes alive, particularly when Williams finally makes it to the Opry.

author: Glenn Kenny
summary: The particularly outstanding cinematography is by Dante Spinotti, the craftsman who also shot the likes of “Heat” and “L.A. Confidential.”

author: Roger Moore
summary: Hiddleston can’t pull off the folksiness that was Williams’ public persona.

author: Fionnuala Halligan
summary: Hiddleston’s intense performance lends a little frisson to an otherwise familiar, if gorgeously-mounted tale about a troubled musical genius who is inevitably, gruellingly, felled by his demons.

author: Noel Murray
summary: Abraham the writer lets down Abraham the director, and ultimately lets down his stars and Spinotti, too.

author: Gregory Ellwood
summary: Despite the worthy efforts of stars Tom Hiddleston and Elizabeth Olsen, the Hank Williams biopic I Saw The Light is a shockingly bad movie.

author: Paul Bradshaw
summary: When Abraham leaves the camera on Hiddleston and Olsen long enough to let them chew on their characters, the film offers flashes of something much more interesting: a handful of domestic scenes prove that the actors, not to mention Hank, would’ve been much better served by a ballsier script and braver direction.

author: Mike Scott
summary: It is powerful, it is affecting and it -- that is, Hiddleston's eerily accurate performance, from start to finish -- is easily the best thing about director Marc Abraham's Shreveport-shot biopic of the country music legend.

author: Bill Goodykoontz
summary: The problem is the movie itself – the script, the editing, the construction, all of which combine to make the whole thing feel flat, lifeless and confusing.

author: Manohla Dargis
summary: Part of what defeats Mr. Abraham and may help explain why Mr. Hiddleston’s performance, however appealing, never gets below the surface, is that Williams is one of those artists whose eloquence is expressed through his work.

author: Alan Scherstuhl
summary: I Saw the Light ignores Williams's composing, denies us his voice, and is too spooked by sentimentality to show us just what his music touches off in people.

author: Andrew Barker
summary: Despite a thoroughly committed, impressive performance from Tom Hiddleston as Williams (and an even better one from Elizabeth Olsen as his first wife, Audrey), the film tackles the life of one of the 20th century’s most seminal musicians with all the passion of a stenographer, making for a dull, unfocused slog through what should have been an effortlessly cinematic story.

author: Kyle Smith
summary: I Saw the Light is as vital as a two-hour shrug.

author: Carson Lund
summary: A flaccidly directed film that basks for two hours in a carefully art-designed simulation of the past.

author: Michael O'Sullivan
summary: I Saw the Light isn’t just incohesive, but ultimately — and far more frustratingly — incoherent.

author: Peter Travers
summary: Hiddleston is not what's wrong with this movie. But damn near everything else is.

author: Kate Erbland
summary: I Saw the Light doesn't just fail to illuminate Williams' complicated life and his prodigious talent; it can't even capture the dark corners of a man with more than enough to peer into.

author: Robbie Collin
summary: When the film reaches its logical end point, Refn just keeps pushing, and eventually lands on a sequence so jaw-dropping...that all you can do is howl or cheer.
Portrayed by a mesmerizing Elle Fanning (Maleficent, Trumbo) in a magnificent, heart-stopping star turn.

author: Drew McWeeny
summary: The Neon Demon’s going to frustrate anyone who goes in looking for a conventional film or a thriller that has any interest in actually scaring you. This is a ride, a carefully crafted experience, and it is precisely because it is so immersive and controlled that I would recommend it.

author: Michael Roffman
summary: This is a film predicated on voyeurism, and while it’s arguably another big ol’ starefest from Refn, the viewer’s patience is earned with unquestionable tension made all the more palpable by its troubled protagonist.

author: Jessica Kiang
summary: Spectacular, gross and delicious (so unsavory it’s almost sweet), the film is more proof of Refn’s mastery of his trash aesthetic and more fun than anything this indulgent and empty-headed has any right to be.

author: Britt Hayes
summary: Set to an electrifying score by frequent Refn collaborator Cliff Martinez (which may be his best yet), The Neon Demon is as deceptive as shattered glass, with a brilliant beauty so mesmerizing that you don’t notice its murderously sharp edges until you’re bleeding all over the floor.

author: Justin Chang
summary: Languorously paced and literally dressed to kill, the movie is a corrosive attack on beauty — or at least our soulless, corporatized definition of the term — but it is also, above all else, a hypnotically beautiful object.

author: Andrew O'Hehir
summary: If you want a movie that eviscerates “The Hunger” and eats its bloody insides while daring you to look away, here it is.

author: Josh Kupecki
summary: He's like the bizarro version of Wes Anderson’s same meticulous attention to detail, but while you can tell Anderson wants to entertain you with a story, Refn is clearly more interested in mood and highly stylized provocation. With The Neon Demon, he more or less succeeds.

author: Rene Rodriguez
summary: The Neon Demon is a voluptuous provocation, a stylish free-fall down a gonzo rabbit hole that is as entrancing as it is maddening. Here is a rarity in this season of summer movie doldrums: A film that is guaranteed to elicit strong reactions.

author: A.A. Dowd
summary: Style doesn’t triumph over substance in The Neon Demon. It devours it.

author: Stephanie Zacharek
summary: The Neon Demon isn’t much of movie, at least if you’re looking for an actual story. Nor is it a moralistic fable about the emptiness of Hollywood—if anything, it’s a winking mockery of that sort of thing. But whatever the heck it is, it throws off a chilly, pleasurable sheen. This is visual hard candy.

author: Eric Kohn
